This place is the business. I've had the tikka masala, lamb curry and garlic/onion naan here and they have all been amazing. I believe it may actually be the best tikka masala I've ever had in my life. The servings are huge and it is crazy cheap for this type of quality of food.

It's very self-serve: order at the counter, get a number and take a seat. If you need to box up leftovers you get boxes/bags yourself from the counter. Pay once you're done at the counter.

I read in another review that my clothes would smell after coming here and thought this was ridiculous, however my clothes absolutely did smell and I had to air them out when I got home. There is a lot of smoke from the cooking of meats so your clothes will be super saturated in smokey goodness.

I've eaten here three times in the past two weeks and still want more!
author: James R.

description:
Rainy days, like today, remind me of my home and home cooked food. When that happens, Chutney is the only place I can think of. Warm, well lit, and filled with the aromas of Indian spices and curries, it is satisfaction guaranteed. 

Seating was never a problem. It has never been one either. Once I and my friends are seated, we place our order at the cash counter. Grab the number and some bottomless, complementary chai with it. The food was served promptly to our table.

A must have at Chutney is their Chicken Tikka Masala. Creamy, sweet, spicy and just a notch tangy, at $6.49 it is by far the most succulent Chicken Tikka Masala I have ever tasted.

Along with it we ordered a Chicken Seekh Kabab and a Tandoori Chicken for $2.99 each. While the Chicken seekh kabab, which is ground chicken marinated in spices and cooked in a clay oven on skewers, was juicy and tender the Tandoori Chicken seemed a little dry and chewy. 

To go with that we ordered Butter Garlic Naans, for just $2.00 each, perfect to soak up the awesome Tikka Masala sauce with! We all had a complete meal for just $8.61 each person! That is the cheapest feast you could ever have. 

Chutney holds its own in a neighborhood of Shalimar, Pakwan and Karachi Classics. And irrespective of the shady neighborhood, I know I'll keep coming back for more.
author: Mitalee D.

description: Some of the best Indian/Pakistani food I have ever had anywhere, and super reasonable. You can easily get dinner for 2 around $20. Our go-to order is the Chicken Tikka and Palak Paneer with 1 rice and 1 naan. Both are excellent with layers of spice and flavor. The restaurant itself is nothing fancy but sometimes you just want something casual and the servers are kind.
author: Amber F.

description:
I really like Chutney. My friend (who also wrote a yelp review for this restaurant) brought my friend and I here to try their food. I've been hearing my friend rave about this restaurant and boy, was I not disappointed! 

We ordered the chicken tikka masala, lamb curry, and some sort of cauliflower and potato dish (that I really enjoyed eating). They were all fantastic dishes. My favorite -- the chicken tikka masala -- did not disappoint. The lamb was soft and chewy. The cauliflower and potato was a good mix in my mouth. The naan is only $1 but I could eat four of them! It was that good. Well, I didn't eat four but I ate one and a third (shared the third with my friends). The free milk tea is awesome too. I put a lot of sugar in it to make it sweet.

My friends and I stayed in there for two hours (an hour to eat and talk and another hour where we just kept talking). None of the staff seemed like they wanted to kick us out (whew). There was a big party that came in for dinner but we left before they left. 

I am most-def coming back here to order different types of naan and curries!
author: Vicky P.

description:
I love CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA and fish tandoori when the fish was not burnt.

The chai tea is always too strong for me. Overall I like this place and will definitely be back for more.
author: Min L.

description:
One of my favorite Indian restaurants in the city! There are several dishes that stand out:

Chicken biryani - this rice dish is always very good with lots of spices and tender (bone-in) chicken. You may find a star anise here and there but that doesn't bother me.

Bengan bharta- Mesquite smoked eggplant cooked with onions, tomatoes and spices. I've had several different veggie dishes and this one stands out as the best in flavors and I like that it has a kick to it. 

Tandoori fish- hands down, one of my favorite dishes of all times. The fish comes out of the clay oven smoking hot, so you may need to wait for it to cool down a bit before digging in. The fish they use for this particular dish is very fatty, so I can't help myself but to suck on all the goodness.

Garlic naan- good

My only negative is the chicken tikka masala, which changed within the past year or so. The sauce is no longer creamy like before, the color is on the redder side, and it tastes like tomato sauce or bisque... 

But all in all, Chutney is a great restaurant!
author: Al B.

description: This is my first time ever trying g Pakistanian food and honestly I assumed it was going to be nasty but it was delicious!! Highly recommend
author: Alyssa T.

description:
I am not a big fan of Indian food but several people mentioned this restaurant and a 
friend and I decided to try it on a friday night and the man on the order desk
was very patient and accommodating explaining the menu and suggestion on what 
to order. BTW;l found out later he is the owners son and is school to be a doctor.
They were extremely busy and all tables were full, but the staff treated you like you 
were the only customers there. He and the rest of the staff ( when not taking orders) worked the room, clearing  dishes, filling water glasses  and making sure all their customers were happy.  There are  a lot of toff restaurants who staff should be
trained here. I cannot wait to come back. Neighborhood is "colorful and crusty so '
leave the bing at home.
author: Peter F.

description:
Best Indian food in San Francisco! Amazing food, incredible prices and they're open till
Kid night. Love their naan, chicken tikka masala, and kababs. Must visit if you like Indian cuisine.
author: Yazz A.

description: Coming from a huge Indian food fanatic, I thought Chutney was just A-OK (as indicated by the three stars). I came in with high expectations, so this may have played a large role in my disappointment. The chicken tikka masala was on the sweeter side and lacked the usual spicy kick that I expected. Give me more spice, Chutney!
author: MyLinh P.

description: The food was fast and pretty good but lacked a little flavor. The best part is they let us bring in our own wine with NO corkage fee. I'd go back for that.
author: Sally D.

description: Ordered food late at around 10pm and received the worst biryani I've ever had. It tasted more like tomato rice. If you don't have it available deny it ,don't dissapoint costumers. Would not recommend this place if you plan to have a biryani.
author: Ashish M.

description:
I love Chutney! I've been here twice and both times the food has been amazingly delicious! The mango lassi is a must! It's a thick mango smoothie that is not bland or overly sweet. It's just perfect! 

The set up of this restaurant is sort of like Corner Bakery. You order your food, get a number, get your own utensils and sauces, and pay AFTER you are done eating. The GREEN SAUCE is SO GOOD. It's spicy, but so good with everything you eat!

I love their garlic naan and chicken tikka massala. The chicken tikka massala comes in an orange creamy sauce. I can care less for the chicken... the sauce is so good. You can eat it with the naan or rice (which is also pretty good). I tried the lamb something... it came with huge chunks of lamb and potatoes in a creamy dark brown/green sauce. The menu said the sauce is spicy, but it isn't spicy. It was eh. The chicken skewers were really good. Although one part of the chicken was extremely burnt, the chicken was tender (Thank goodness because I HATE dry chicken). 

The prices are pretty decent for the amount of food you get, so if you are in the neighborhood and you want delicious Indian-Pakistani food, come  here!
author: Melanie L.

description: Food is 3 stars, nothing amazing. Service is absolutely terrible. Would not recommend
author: Amanda P.

description: I love this place, been coming here for years. This is the go to indo-paki place in the city and it is also halal. Everything i have had here is delicious, especially the tikka masala and the tandori chickens. The only down fall is there is no where to park but on the street which in the city can be hell or there's a garage near by. Service is great, food is great, and price is awesome. Got about 4 dishes and 3 naans for about 35 dollars which is more than fair. The place looks like a cafeteria and isnt fancy, but what it lacks in ambiance, it makes up in flavor.
author: Haithem I.

description:
A good place to eat, just not the best. Was planning on going to Lahore but it was closed Thursday. So we ended up coming here instead. The tables were wobbly, the Chai was watered down and the portions were small.

The tables were so packed together, we were hitting the people around us.
author: M C.

description:
Ordered chicken vindaloo and garlic nan. Also mango lassi to drink.

A disappointment. After reading so many rave reviews here on Yelp I had high hopes for good Indian food at a reasonable price.

Chicken vindaloo is usually a spicy hot dish but incredibly bland here. In fact, ALL the food at our table was bland regardless if anyone ordered it hot. The chicken was served with the bones in the meat and, Man!, were there A LOT of bones.

You get what you pay for and this meal was worth only slightly less than the $14 I paid.

Here's my suspicion about why this place gets such high marks. Most of the customers are in the 20s-30s and trying to live in one of the most expensive cities in the world. So, yeah, $10 or less for dinner? No problem. You will probably want a decent meal and you'll find it--elsewhere!

Overall a regrettable meal.
author: Rick S.

description:
I am not a happy camper if you serve me gross chicken tikka masala.

As I was scooping some onto my plate, I got the weirdest smell from the tikka masala....a cheesy sour smell.....(something I have NEVER experienced before with tikka masala) and from that first moment on I knew my dinner was ruined. 
chicken Saag (palak): the spinach was very watery 
Chicken vindaloo: no flavor.

Everything was either bland or tasted completely off. I was so disappointing because I noticed a lot of people giving this place high ratings. One of the bussers dropped a bunch of plates right behind me and hit me.....luckily I didn't get Indian food all over my backside. 

Came out smelling gross, and usually I don't care...but this time it really wasn't worth it.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Holy sh*t, this is some CHEAP Indian food. I can't get over the low price. 

You order at the front, cafeteria style, take a number and sit down to wait for your food. There is nothing going on decor-wise and the tables and kind of cheap and grotty looking. The floor wasn't the cleanest either, bits of naan on the ground by my feet. 

I ordered a vegetable tikka masala ($5.95), a tandoori chicken breast ($2.95, wow) and a plain naan ($1.00).

When you first sit down you are brought a free salad plate and a pitcher of water. Nice.

My order was somehow misplaced. I could see other patrons receiving all their food and mine wasn't coming. Sigh. The owner realized what happened and brought me out a mango lassi free of charge. Nice. The mango lassis here are PINT SIZED, huge!

When the food did come (only about 10 mins) it was pretty decent. Tandoori chicken a-ok. Naan, very thin and HUGE, also good. Vegetable tikka masala, slightly disappointing. Very fast foody, the sauce was quite plain and runny and there were not a lot of vegetables besides a few green beans and potatoes. 

When I went to pay, the owner said the bill was $12 but to only pay him $5 because my order took so long. 

Cheap, but you get what you pay for.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Lesson #1: do not judge a book by its over. This place is a diamond in the rough - you'd never imagine their food is to die for just by looking at it from the outside.

Lesson #2: Chiken tiki masala. Try it. Love it. Leave on cloud 9.

Lesson #3: the staff will not go above and beyond. Which is just fine. They are there to take your order, make sure your table is clean, and they leave you alone. You want water or tea? You get it yourself. I have absolutely no qualms with that.
author: Mirela L.

description: Amazing Indian food, best in town! I always come here and food is always fresh. Strongly recommend their Tikka Masala and potato naan. Bomb.
author: Alexandra T.

description: My friend had a complaint about the service and the cashier told her to "get fucked." Incredibly rude. Don't go here.
author: Devin B.

description:
We were in SF for the weekend for a seminar, and my friend was awesome enough to find places to eat for us. We battled the rain to walk several blocks to this place, and I'm so glad we did!!

I got the chicken tikka masala (about $6). the color kind of scared me (bright orange) but suprisingly, it was savory, full of flavor, creamy and delicious!! I ordered a naan for an extra dollar, and it was HUGE! it was difficult to finish on my own!! The place is a little dark and I was afraid to use their bathroom, but the food was superb and I would definitely go back! the food came out quickly, and the servers were very nice. :)
author: Eileen K.

description: Food is good. Service: terrible. And rude. Every time I have been here. Every time. Went to Pakwan a half block away--courteous and friendly. Chutney, never again.
author: Michele N.

description: Tried the nihari and chicken tikka masala. The nihari was really good and spicy. The masala was also good after we had to send it back to be heated because it was cold. My sister also tried the bhindi gosht which she said was good. Definitely a fun hole in the wall type place with great good. This is saying a lot coming from a picky person like me!
author: Aisha H.

description:
My favorite Indian spot in SF. 

I've tried a few plates here, and by a few plates I mean a few different types of the tikka masala. I just can't get enough of that creamy, thick sauce (that's what she said). I've tried the chicken (dry white meat but that's standard for indian food), veggie tikka masala (lots of different types of veggie but has a slightly different flavor than the standard tikka masala sauce), and my personal favorite, the paneer (cheese) masala. The biryani is decent but I always just order aloo (potato) naan or garlic naan, which are huge, fluffy, and flavorful. You can also order varying degrees of spiciness, but be wary as I've found even the mild has a slight kick.

Bonus points for the free salads they serve, the tasty cilantro-jalapeno sauce sitting on every table, and the unlimited free chai tea. The mango lassi is really tasty, too!

TIPS
-Parking sucks. You'll be fine on a weeknight but good luck on the weekend or weekend night.
-Don't go before an important date or meeting and don't wear clothes that you can't immediately dump in the laundry when you get home. Your clothes, hair, and every orifice on your body will smell like curry and barbecue. Eau de Chutney is not a bestseller.
-Be prepared to make friends with or be hassled by SF's infamous homeless. They're usually harmless but don't be alarmed if they walk up beside you and try to keep up a conversation.
author: Jan C.

description: Pathetic service and ambience. Served food too late and it also tasted aweful. Nowhere near a genuine Indian/ Pakistani cuisine. Hoe can a Mexican chef make such cuisine?
author: Navin R.

description: Chicken Tikka Masala is fabulous. The chicken Korma curry tastes great too, but the meat is full of little bone fragments etc, which is insanely annoying and takes all of the fun out an otherwise decent dining experience.
author: David Z.

description:
One of the best brain masalas I have ever encountered. 

Great hole in the wall Indian food. Skip Naan and Curry and come here. The food is flavorful (to say the least), without being overpowering. Cheap and delicious, where can you go wrong?

Order, sit, eat, THEN pay. Leave happy.
author: Coco C.

description: Very poor service and mediocre food. Also overpriced and in a bad neighborhood. Not good.
author: Grey Z.

description:
So far, this is my favorite Indian food in SF. Lamb vindaloo and chicken tikka masala were flavorful and comforting. Naan was crisp and delicious. I loved that they had complimentary self serve chai and sauce.

However, service was slooooooooooooooow... but friendly none the less. Worth the wait in my opinion. I'm looking forward to my next visit!
author: Annie H.

description: This place is terrible. I waited 40 mins only to be told that our order was "lost".  They have poor customer service and do not care at all for their customer's experience.  One of the worst dining experience, by far. Will not recomended this place if your not indian. Im just sad & hungry on cold new years day. They need a better costomer service plus+++ be attentive on orders.
author: Dhenise K.

description:
This was my third time visiting, and while the first two times were decent, the third time ruined it all.  I'm not coming back to this place.

The service here is AWFUL.  THEY LIED TO ME.  Here's what happened:

My GF and I had dropped in to grab some yummy curry for the tummy.  We had ordered some chicken shashkababas and those flat toasted pancake bread things (hah! j/k... yes I'm perfectly aware that they are actually called Naan), and some mango lassi.

Well, we were chatting it up and gossiping, and realized about 30-40 minutes later that we still hadn't gotten our food.  I guess they never wrote down our table number on the order, so the food just sat under the heat lamp.  When I walked over to the cashier guy to ask if that was our food, he said no, our food is being cooked.  Upon returning to our table, we watched the server casually bring over the same plates that had been sitting there.  When I looked over at the cashier again, he threw both his arms into the air of attitude, as if he was saying "what are you going to do about it?".  Lie, then attitude.  I was so angry that I had to step outside the restaurant for a little bit.

If a restaurant doesn't have the skills to cook good food, it's forgivable.  It's a matter of practice and learning, and to quote the Disney movie, "Anyone can cook".  Lying and lacking ethics, and having a terrible customer service mentality, is a whole another problem and such an ill mindset.  I can't come back here again for as long as my soul lives within me.
author: Eugene L.

description: Went there with a group of friends on a Saturday evening. The place is pretty cramped up. The tables are arranged with marginal spaces between them and so in the way of incoming people. The food was a bit bland to my taste. Our chicken tikka masala and paneer has too much cream. The biryani was spicy but not an authentic slow cooked dum biryani. Seemed like, they mixed the biryani masala (that you can find in any indian store) with chicken, rice and some veggies. However the sheek kabab hit the spot with its taste.
author: Soumyava D.

description: Went there to eat tonight. One word for it....PATHETIC. I have been eating here for the past 5 years, at least once a month. But there quality of both food and servic has gone down the hole. The guy at the counter taking the order was so rude. Except for the naan all the food we ordered was tasteless. When we complained about how bland and tastless the food was he tells us that he did not force us to come here. This place is for people who have not tasted real Pakistani or Indian food. Go to Shalimar or pakwan instead, at least the food is genuine. Get your money's worth there.
author: ali g.

description: Really love this place. Setting is spartan in the north of the Tenderloin and the cooks are somewhat gruff, but the food is fresh and so flavorful. Tandoori meat are amazing, as are the sauces for tikka and saag paneer. The nan is fresh and so good. The chai is free, scalding hot and bottomless.
author: Jason O.

description: Great Indian food for a fabulous price! I would have given five stars, except I ordered takeout and they forgot the samosa I ordered.
author: Darcey P.

description:
We totally fell for the reviews! Should have read the critical reviews more closely.

It's a hole in the wall kinda restaurant and a waft of delicious smell coming your way. The smell of hot naans being made and tandoori is what flipped the coin for us and we walked in despite the not so convincing surroundings.

The good - for what it is worth - everything was served hot.

Chicken tikka masala - Very very lame - The gravy was very bland and literally bad and the chicken never had a chance to lure the marination into itself.

Keema naan - horrible - it was a nightmare - Just the way it looked itself should have been warning enough but well..sigh!!  It wasn't cooked thoroughly. Almost all of the mid section was semi-cooked dough.
The guy at the counter bothered to ask us how our food was and when we told him about the naan, he took it off the price.

Nonetheless... I'm never stepping in here again.
author: Geena N.

description:
On the 8th day , God went to this restaurant and ate an epic bowl of spicy chicken curry, and everything was good.

This was HANDS down, the best Paki food I;ve ever had..And im Peruvian , so I dont know that much..but guess what..I was with 3 pakis, fresh from the land of Urdu and sweet outfits. Their words said : "ok..this tastes like my moms " That  ladies and gents mean food is indeed UBER EPIC.

The paying system threw me off. Go order, sit down and go back to pay?? Doesnt even make sense..but most important..why isnt people walking out without paying..its busy as hell, no one will notice.. I didnt understand this UNTIL  I tried the food. Why would you risk getting a permanent BAN from this spot?? thats why you will go to the cashier, pay and let them pet you so you can come back..well at least I did, and the petting part felt nice..

Service was below average...the guy that brought our food was a mexican guy that was mad at the world and transfered all that hate towards us. Forget about getting refills or getting something extra after your order is done.It just wont happen

If it wasnt for waiting and service this would be a 5 stars for sure, but with those 2 things I rather give it a 3.5 , but no can do.
author: Raul T.

description:
Hands down one of the BEST Indian cuisine restaurants ever! 

Some people may not like it, but I looooooove the smell of Indian food. Not only is it unbearably good, but it's always bustling with customers. I wouldn't be surprised if the line went out the door! Of course, the cooks in the kitchen are very fast to order and serve, so there's never a line that long. 

I love to try new things, but the chicken tikki masala, garlic naan, and chicken vindaloo are my favorite dishes. I've been to many Indian restaurants and this one just nails it. The naan is crisp, yet soft and the chicken are tender to perfection. Granted I come out of the restaurant smelling like I ran through a spice garden, but it's well worth

Of the few times I've gone, I've had a consistent good impression of them. 

Whenever my sister visits L.A. and asks me what I want, I just tell her to bring some in a sealed-tight bag. (Amazingly, she does it!) :)
author: Lily L.

description:
Tenderloin gem! 

My girl and I stepped into this bustling restaurant and were not disappointed.  

The food was really good and flavorful and really fairly priced.  We ordered a ton of stuff, I don't even remember what it was bit it was all good and the naan is frickin amaze.

After gorging ourselves on all types of naan and several dishes we still had leftovers for two days!  

 Plus, the girl grinding on the obese mans crotch against the wall across the street made the tenderloin experience all the more authentic!
author: Eddie A.

description:
After having been to most of the Indo/Pakistan restaurants in the Tenderloin, I was keen to try Chutneys. It went wrong from the beginning. 

Strike 1: First the owner came over to ask if we had ordered a particular dish. Without waiting for the response, he signaled over his server, and the dish was on our table instantaneously. When I told the owner he had it wrong, he mumbled something, and was off again before I had time to reply.

Strike 2: Despite ordering 2 entrees, the food didn't come out for 45 minutes. The place was not very busy. People behind us in the line had already eaten, paid and left. Finally I asked the owner where the food was, which prompted them to quickly deliver (it had been sitting on the counter). At this point, the chicken was almost cold. Against our better judgment, we ate it. 

Strike 3: Next day consisted of vomiting and stomach cramps for me and my friend. Thank you Chutney. 

You're Out: There is a lot of competition in the Tenderloin. If the owner continues to allow bad service, and serve dangerous food, Chutneys will slowly become yet another 'has-been' restaurant, who had their 15 minutes of fame.
author: Fooda H.

description:
THE ONLY THING TO KNOW:::::
Chicken Masala
Naan (garlic maybe)

Avoid the tea, its NOT good (but it is free...and I don't like chai?)

Cheap, and Delicious.
author: Clinton J.

description:
Let me just preface this review by saying that I wish floo powder were real so that I could teleport to this restaurant whenever I'm craving Indian food...so like, every other day. 

I ordered the Aloo Gobi which was deliciously savory with a hint of spice and tang. My friend had the Paneer Masala which was creamy and also delicious. She licked her plate clean! Both dishes were so good with the Garlic Naan so make sure to order a basket!

It was our first time there so the seating and payment situation was very confusing. We stood by the counter for about 10 minutes before realizing (on our own) that customers were walking through the door and seating themselves. Clearly, there was room for improvement regarding service and communication. However, we didn't let that ruin the experience as the staff was polite.

A man at the table next to us took notice that we were new to Chutney so he recommended that we go to the back table to grab some complimentary Chai tea on our way out. I really enjoyed the Chai and it was definitely great on a chilly SF night. 

I cannot wait to go back to visit SF and eat at Chutney again!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Anyone who gives this place a four or five star rating is nuts. I got a huge bowl of chicken tikka masala with maybe two pieces of chicken in it, the rest was soup. I also got the palak paneer and it had three small cubes of cheese in the entire bowl. Flavor was pretty subpar, also. Garlic naan was ok.
author: Vio O.

description: This place is BYOB and the food is amazing. Bring your friends and a bottle (or 5) of wine and enjoy some quality Indian.
author: Will F.

description: A decent place to have nice Indian food. Could be much better in terms of hygiene & customer service.
author: Vipul Z.

description:
After reading the reviews, thought I try it...got a take out order.  Half of my order was good, the other half was so-so.  And they forgot to give me my naan.  

The Good:
Gobi Gosht--lamb with cauliflower was spicy, nicely flavored.  The lamb was tender.
The Rice Pullao as simple as it is, was delcious

The So-So:
Chicken Tiki-Masala--was more sauce than chicken and the sauce was a melon orange.  The chicken chunks were on the dry side even though it was swimming in sauce.

Paleek Paneer--this spinach with head cheese dish has always been a favorite of mine to order at Indian restaurants.  Theirs was somewhat odd--the spinach was pureed to death--consistency of a smoothie.  And the head cheese was really firm.  Not my cup of tea in terms of looks and texture. 

Would I go back? Maybe just for the the top two dishes but I would try the other Indian restaurants in the area first.
author: Nancy H.

description:
Like this place.
Smoky. Casual. BYOB. No corkage. 
Naan is chewy and great. Lamb Vindaloo tender. Tandoori fish a bit over-charred, but I'm forgiving. Friendly service. My style eatery for sure.
author: Anthony R.

description:
My favorite part about this place was the excellent service. The man who was taking the orders was so welcoming and warm. 

The place itself seemed to lack cleanliness which scared me, but I got over it because for prices this decent I shouldn't complain. I had garlic naan, paneer tikka masala, and aloo ghobi. The naan was amazing, but then again it's really hard to mess that up. Paneer tikka masala was a little too watery and not spiced enough. Aloo ghobi lacked pizzazz. 

I want to come back here to give it another chance because the service was wonderful; I want to order different things to see if they're any different/better. To be continued!
author: Idk A.

description:
Solid 2 stars.

For first-timers aka lost souls, here's the process:
1) Order you food and get a number
2) Seat yourself (and get free self-served chai tea)
3) Food will come to you
4) Eat
5) Take number, go to register, and pay

No one will help you figure this out. So, there you go!

Chicken Tikka Masala... aka SAUCE CENTRAL with NO chicken. Maybe three small pieces, if you're lucky. And yes, I tasted the MSG, folks.

In other news, the place was clean and tidy.

"Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Mike N.

description:
The menu is copied from Shalimar. But they do accept Credit cards, which is good.
The rotis (naan/bread) and some tandoori items are made inside with no much ventilation. So lots of smoke everywhere. Food tasted ok. Parking was $15 indoor next door, but street parking is free after 6 PM. 
I hope they improve the ventilation. Toilets are bad.
author: Mr. T.

description:
While visiting San Francisco me and my girl friend went for dinner here today (we 
put up our indian restaurant night out clothes*: the clothes which are not needed in the tour because they will smell from one kilometre away of curry) the food was up to the mark , authentic , delicious for both of us (my girl friend being of european origion)
 Chicken biryani and Daal chicken both were delicious with refereshing mango lassi and sweet lassi. 

Cleanliness and enviornment was poor so don't expect much. Other wise nice staff and great price !!! 

Neighbour hood is creepy though!
author: Zubi G.

description:
We go to Chutney at least once per month, either for dine-in or take-out.  Anything with tikka masala is pretty good. The chana masala is super tasty, as is the bengan bhartha. The spinach and potato curry is spiced a little differently than other places, but it's also less greasy and has more flavor.

I've noticed that if you call in an order for carry out and they tell you it will be ready in 10-15 minutes, they almost always have your food bagged up and waiting for you at the counter when you walk in. If you're eating in, it seems like you wait a bit longer for your food.

On a recent visit, I got some karayla masala, which is bitter gourd or bittermelon. Compared to other times I've had bitter gourd, this tasted a lot less bitter. I think the spices did a good job of both highlighting the slight bitterness but also mellowing it out so that it didn't activate my gag reflex. At first, it was reminiscent of chayote, but the more I ate, the more I could taste the bitterness. Oddly enough, it was really quite pleasant, which I can't say for most of my bitter gourd experiences. I'll have to order it again to make sure it wasn't a fluke, but if this is what bittermelon can be like, then perhaps I've found a new favorite dish.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Bottom line: dirty (gave me diarrhea), disorganized, and hit or miss food.

Food: The food is cheap, hit or miss, and not authentic. The seekh kabab and chicken tikka we were served were bland and cold. The tikka wasn't even properly salted. The meat sits out on their counters waiting an eternity for the tandoor. I thought if it 'marinated' for that long it would taste like something at least. On the other hand my wife liked her samosas and the naan was decent.

Service: The restaurant is disorganized; with no service. They don't explicitly tell people that you don't need to wait in line to pay, but you need to line up when you order. One man answers the phone, takes orders and payments, and seats customers: the line is long. We had to ask a confused bus boy to remove the prior patron's food and dishes from our table. We were given glasses with dirt and food stuck on them.

BTW, the piece de resistance of this night out was the violent diarrhea I had to ran home to. So, no, I would not recommend this establishment.
author: Sajid R.

description: I've only EVER had the chicken tikka masala here paired with garlic naan and basmati rice.  All I got to say is that it's a no frills kind of place that's always busy.  Parking in the area sucks, but I only ever came to eat here before clubbing DT anyways and would not make the trip otherwise.  Good food, good price, and a perfect pregame food (which means I finished everything I ordered, every time). ^_^
author: Jae W.

description: No roaches that we saw, pretty clean actually. All-you-can-drink CHAI. If you care about the food after that last sentence, let me say that it was very good, with the only drawback being that my lamb was on the bony side. That said, the authenticity is way up there. Delicious and great service and cheaper than any Indian food in my hometown by at least $4 a plate. Would definitely go again.
author: Ariana B.

description:
I would give them a 3, because they are pretty much like every other Indian join in the neighborhood, but they forgot our take out order, causing us to wait.  And previously, when I had dined in, they had forgotten an order of for us as well and weren't so apologetic about it and instead was rather accusatory. 

But anyway, in the Chicken Tikka Masala taste test between Chutney, Shalimar, and Nu-Lahore, Chutney's was the most tomatoey and creamy (the color is here is definitely different than the other two; an almost neon orange hue). Not quite my taste preference.  They do have a much larger and cleaner space than the other two places though if you prefer to dine in.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
Well... after I figured out that another Indian restaurant's dishes contain the same base and they just add in different vegetables to it, I assumed it was time to start looking for a new Indian place and see how it matched up, having exhausted my options in two visits (I don't want to name names) (But I'm looking at you, 'hore) 

Chutney is like... Indian food for white people who can't handle a lot of ethnicity. 

The restaurant is polished, and the food is too. Its WAY less oily than the 'hores. But its much much more pretentious. I want my Indian food to be real homecooked Indian. Not Indian for white people. 

Seriously, I sat behind 4 indignant white yuppies. Not gonna happen at the 'hores. 

It's still great though- the Aloo Ghobi was less sauced and had more cauliflower than the 'hores, their garlic naan was fluffy and crispy and light, but how they make it garlic is to simply put raw chopped garlic on top. Fail. 

I'd go back to takeout, and if I had to take someone there who wasn't down with ethnic food. (Aka my mother)
author: Emily D.

description: Delicious Indian/Pakistani food. We used to go to Naan And Curry but this place won us over. Hard to beat. Free hot chai tea in the back.
author: Jamie M.

description:
This place has some seriously good and cheap Indian food. Despite being in the Tenderloin, it was totally worth it.

Between the five of us, we shared the:

garlic naan (five orders!)--big chunks of fresh garlic on top
mango lassi (delicious creamy mango drink)
Bengan Bharta (perfectly spiced)
tandoori fish (very tender and flaky!!)
rice pullao
lamb vindaloo (very tender meat)
chicken tikka masala (delicious!)

With all these dishes, the bill came out to less than $12 per person!
Plus they give you unlimited chai tea to drink! It was sooooo yummie!

Parking in the area can be difficult, but I say its worth it to come here at least once! People were constantly coming in while we were eating. The turnover rate is pretty quick so dont despair if you see that the restaurant is full.
author: Janet E.

description:
Quick fix for chicken tikka marsala and naan!

I was craving indian after Go Cars and we came here. We ordered and the food came quickly. I'm used to chicken tikka marsala being too creamy but this was excellent! I love the onions, lemon, curry dipped with naan! Naan is huge and the garlic naan has a LOT of garlic and chives, so delicious!

Be sure to bring your own napkin when going to use the restroom! It's really small and dirty. Other than that, I would come here again and try more of my favorite Indian dishes!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Food was alright. I liked Naan and Dal, however Paneer Makhni was just OK.  My biggest issue with the place was the strange smell that you find as you enter the place. The dishes could be cleaner. Loved that they serve Green salad and tea with meals. It can be a cheap option in SFO downtown, but nearest street parking was very expensive for Sunday. 
I think that this place has value for money, however if you are looking for something more authentic, then there are some better Indo restaurants in SFO downtown. This place can certainly use some updates as well.
author: Neha G.

description:
The food is goooood! but they are slooooooooow! I guess that's okay when it's good though. The only thing I didn't like was the couple watching some movie on their laptop together like it was their home in front of the TV.
Alright maybe I should say I just thought it was sad and I fear everybody will be doing this soon.
Everything is good here.
I took some Chai home with me.
author: Lizzy M.

description: Was disappointed with this place based on the reviews it got and its place in many a guidebook. Had the Chicken Korma Curry, wasn't really that impressed. The portions were small and there were bones in most of the chicken, making half of it inedible. Was still hungry after the meal. Naan wasn't as fluffy as I would've wanted and they refused to bring me a side order of daal, even though you pay at the end. The curry sauce was good, if a bit too spicy for my taste. Chicken was definitely not good quality. They also don't serve alcohol, which was frustrating. Have had much better Indian/Pakistani food elsewhere. I suggest you look around the city, since there were about 10 other choices that are probably better.
author: Erica S.

description: There are no words to describe how good this place is.  As my girlfriend noted, the only thing audible out of my mouth whilst eating was a series of grunts that confirmed the greatness of this meal.  If you like Indian food, Chutney is a must. In fact, Chutney is a requirement if you are in the city.  Now if I could only convince the owners to expand into the South Bay...
author: Mark S.

description: Chicken Marsala was creamy and tasty. Great naan! Went really well with the curry. Fast service and good attitude. Overall very satisfy. Fair price :D
author: anna w.

description: Not good a place. Ordered chicken tandoori salad, and it was a huge plate of wilted lettuce, soggy tomatoes, and the chicken was dry as sawdust. No dressing (all I got was plain yogurt), and no cucumbers. Salad was not as described on menu.  Other items were greasy and heavy tasting.
author: Jenny R.

description:
This is a really good place to come if you're feeling some Indian finger food. I usually come with 3+ others nd we all share 1-2 chicken tiki misalas nd a couple of naans. Enjoy it when its hot so dont lag on tha eatting! 

Mango lasse is really good if you don't mind drinking a mango smoothie with hot curry/chicken/naan. i like getting/trying a variety of naans to see which ones i like. So far its regular, beef, onion nd cheese. Also, i wrap my naans with tha meat nd vegies then dip it in tha sauce :D ... finger foods ! Yum
author: Michael N.

description:
If you don't find me at Shalamar (the best Indian in town) which is up the street, but find me here, it's because I don't have the time to shower before my next stop - in other words you won't smell like curry after you leave the restaurant.  The food here is wonderful, they clean (unlike at Shalamar) and the atmosphere is okay. You have to go...!

BTW, there are a number of excellent Indian/Pakistani restaurants very close-by; I think this and Shalamar are the best!
author: Dax F.

description:
Hour and 20 minutes wait for the food. By far the worst service I've ever experienced. 
The Chicken Tikka Masala was great, but even though the food was great I can't look past the crappy service and therefor I'm only giving Chutney 1 star.
author: Vilmundur S.

description:
My God the best Indian food ever .Only problem
Is they r too busy , and it takes a lot of patience which I don't have lol !!
author: Z A.

description: This place is totes amazeballs! BYOB, great PtFR (price to flavor ratio), and stellar service. It's in a sketch area but I'm 100% coming back here. For all you adventurous spirits bring a first date here - if she's cool she'll love you for it!
author: Michael T.

description:
There is never a reason to NOT come here. I want to eat here every day, but am horrified that if I ever burn myself out on Chutney, I will not have a reason to go on in life.  

I have had the Chana Masala (garbanzo beans), saffron flavored rice, Aloo Ghobi (cauliflower), Daal (lentils), Naan (bread), and Bhindi (Okra).   Don't worry, they were different visits! These are all vegetarian options, and still incredibly flavorful, and served piping hot.

They give you a plate of lettuce, onion, and tomato served with a lemon at first.  I still don't really know what you're supposed to do with it.  I get a little self-conscious that I am doing it wrong, but I always make a sandwich out of the garbanzo beans, bread lettuce and onion and when its delicious, I no longer care!

Also, if you like spicy, try the green sauce in the fridge.  Sweet, try the brown.  Both so good.

If I had to dig around and try to find something negative to say, I would say their soda fridge is not cold enough.  But in reality, I am not complaining, I just secretly hope they read this, turn down the fridge and make Chutney perfect.

you HAVE to go!!
author: Alyson L.

description: Outstanding Chicken Tika Masala. Also enjoyed the Lamb Byrani. Very inexpensive prices. Free Masala hot tea available in the back. This will likely be our go to Indian restaurant in SF.
author: Charles C.

description:
3 stars because this place has THE BEST Indian food in the bay (in my opinion). 

Customer Service is REALLY BAD though. We came close to closing time, so I'm going to assume that everyone just wanted to leave for the night, but all the servers were seemed to be just down right pissed everytime we would ask for something (just simple questions like where the sauce was/water/etc.). Look, we don't mind getting these things for ourselves, but you also don't have to be mean about it. 

On top of which, when they served us our food, the server TOUCHED THE KEBAB WHEN WE ASKED HIM WHAT IT WAS. I know that cooks touch our food when it's being cooked, that's just how it is. But don't touch it IN FRONT of the customer!

The Indian guy handling the counter was absolutely great! But the cooks/servers just had a really lousy attitude. 

I really want to love this place! But the service just really turned me off. I would still go back but ONLY FOR THE FOOD. Will definitely get it to go next time.
author: Sam B.

description:
Still doesn't understand why some people would rather pay more to go across the street to Shalimar when Chutney is cleaner, cheaper, and has better tasting food. 
Maybe for the  "Zagat rated" sticker outside of Shalimar window? Well, who knows!

Enough of the rant. 

My MUST have dishes at Chutney:
-Lamb or Chicken Tikka Masala (nice and creamy)
-Lamb or Chicken Biryani
-Lamb Wrap (best with Tikka Masala sauce)

I have never been to India but this is hands down the best Indian food I have ever had!
author: Fu D.

description: The food is very authentic and you can't get cultural Indian taste like that anywhere else in the city. The staff is very nice and make you feel at home. Things that I recommend are the chicken tikka masala, banjan barta, aloo gobi, and their chicken biryani. The naan always comes out hot and fresh from the oven and the chicken melts in your mouth. Fave hot spot.
author: Diana E.

description: Simply the best!! Servers are nice, food are excellent and reasonably priced!! Will be coming back again and again:)!!
author: William Q.

description: One of my two favorite Indian planted in the city. Convenient for being close to home. Brain masala is my favorite. Aloo Gobi is delicious. Excellent Chai but always seems to have yes leaves in the bottom of my cup.
author: S P.

description:
Why hello there, what's your name? Oh, Naan is it? Well you tasty, delicious, fluffy Naan, do you come here often? Because after one bite of you, I think this may be my regular spot.

Sorry for hitting on the naan folks, but it is that good. And sopping up all the sauces and deliciousness with it just makes everything (tikka masala sauce, eggplant curry, etc) better. This place is also super affordable, who cares that you have to step over a few bums and run away from a crack head or two, if you're like me and you like a bargain, it is worth it. 

You can also be sure to head here after a jaunt at Bourbon and Branch and pay less for your whole meal then you did for your one drink. You're welcome.
author: Shira O.

description: I've been going to Chutney for years.  Love it!  It's consistently delicious Indian-Pakistani food.  It's in a bad part of town and it's quite plain inside, but the food is always great.  I go threre with friends often.  We order:  Benghan Birtha, Gobi Aloo, Veggie tikka masala, Tandoori fish and tandoori chicken, plus other stuff.  And rice and various naans.  Chutney is at a good price point.  If you go there, you'll see moslty indians and pakistanis, so you know that the food is authentic and good, and well-priced.  Highest recommendation.  You order at the counter when you go in, and then you find a table and they'll bring the food in 5-10 minutes.  When you leave, you go to the counter and settle up.
author: JOhn H.

description:
i usually order lamb vindaloo and chicken curry to go. You'd better wait outside or you will smell like curry in 5 minutes:P
Love the food, a bit greasy but very flavory.
But you gotta be very careful when eating, there are some small pieces of bones in the dish which you won't notice, i bite on one once and it almost knock my front tooth off".........
author: Kate C.

description: The best Indian food in the city, hands down. I've tried manyyy other places in search of the best chicken tikka masala and garlic naan, but this place takes the cake.
author: Christian S.

description:
Seeing large number of yelpers raving about their food, decided to give this place a shot.

A small hole in the wall kind of restaurant which was supercrowded at dinner time. There are a variety of options in the menu (both veg and non-veg) to choose from. Generous portions, served hot. However, I just found the food to be average. 

We tried their Dal Masala, Channa Masala & Paneer Tikka Masala. I liked their preparation of paneer, rest of the dishes were just ok. I believe non-veg at this place is better because my non-vegetarian friends seemed to be more impressed by the food here than I. Naan/ Roti were thicker than what you find in most Indian or Pakistani restaurants ( i prefer thin Naan/bread). However, Onion Naan is good. 

To sum it up , Mediocre food at affordable prices. 

Tip: It's open till midnight so good place to satisfy your late night cravings.
author: Chiku C.

description: The Dahl and Tandoori fish were OK. However, the shrimp biryani tasted weird. I would have loved to have given more stars given that the staff were working so hard and the cashier was a lovely gentleman.
author: Nicky D.

description: This place has a food cult following and some of the best Northern Indian food in the United States. It's so good you will eat until it hurts so be careful. Be sure to get the Aaloo naan.
author: Deb L.

description:
Based on some of these reviews, I had lunch here yesterday with a friend.  I had the Chicken Tikka Masala and she had the Chana Masala.  We also got some basmati rice and naan.  No beer here, so I washed down my grub with some yummy Punjabi tea.

Although the doors were dirty, along with several tables when we got there, the staff had everything cleaned up within minutes of our arrival.  They must have just been slammed during the usual noon lunch rush, so no problems there.

The food was EXCELLENT AND FRESH.  My Tikka Masala was some of the best I've ever had.  Oh how I longed for a Kingfisher to wash it down but I'll be better prepared next time as I'll just bring my own.

Thanks Joanna for the recommendation!!  Namaste!!
author: Anthony D.

description:
When I come here, I always eat a chicken masala and some nan.
This restaurant is one of the most delicious food I've ever eaten.

Why don't you go and eat here !!
author: Atsushi S.

description: I was staying at the Serrano Hotel and was trying to find a close place with good food and cheap prices. I ordered the Aloo Vindaloo with 2 orders of Naan for $9.78 and I have to say it is some of the best indian food I have had in a very long time! I ordered online and it said the food would be ready in 20 minutes and I got there 10 minutes earlier and it was hot and ready for me when I walked in. And they took AMEX on their website, which was great. When I come back I will definitely be ordering from them again.
author: Victor R.

description:
It seems cumbersome to review a place that already has hundreds of reviews. What are the chances anyone will read this? Anyone?

For those that don't know the difference between Indian and Pakistani restaurant, here goes:

Indian restaurants do not serve beef or cow meat. Pakistani restaurants do. Having said that, there are some recipes that are always better at an Indian restaurant and vice versa.

So I went to this place after reading rave reviews of the Chicken Tikka Masala and was thoroughly disappointed. This is a Pakistani restaurant and yet again, the proof was in the pudding ... well ... Chicken Tikka Masala. It was just not that good. For that matter, neither was the Chicken Tandoori. 

The naan was amazing and the Seekh Kabab was delicious, but name one Pakistani restaurant that doesn't get those two dishes right. 

Perhaps I am being harsh. Maybe I should have tried the Chicken Karhai or the Haleem or even the Nihari - the latter two being exclusively Pakistani dishes.  

Anyway I thought this place was below average. Even the so called mango ice-cream they served was awful (it was vanilla with mango flavor and not in a good way).

For those that don't know, there is no service at this place. You place the order at the counter and they bring it to you, similar to other Pakistani restaurants in the area. 

With Pakwan and Shalimar across the street from this place, I opt for any of those three over Chutney.
author: Faisal L.

description: I love this place! The tandoori chicken is only $3.99 and its a large piece of chicken! It's perfectly seasoned and delicious. I haven't had anything I didn't like, and with it being so close to my apartment, it's always my go to for Indian food.
author: Ashley M.

description: I absolutely love this place. it's the best Indian food I've ever had. Curry is great. The Naan is great. Mango Lassi is great! It's great!
author: Raymond D.

description:
Big flavor at small prices - Chutney is quick, delicious, and very satisfying.

Friends had mentioned Chutney several times as a go-to place for Indian food in the area and I'm glad I finally stopped by one evening. My lamb curry had all that wonderful slow-cooked flavor that I expected from a spice stew. The naan bread, two times the size of my face, was fresh from the oven and served as the perfect delivery vessel for the curry from bowl to mouth. 

If you're worried about five-alarm fires in your mouth, have no fear. Chutney provides you with mixed greens (Lettuce, tomato, and onions) which helps take the spice down a notch. If all else fails, each table gets a whole pitcher of water too.
author: Jon L.

description: Horrible experience.  Ordered chicken saag and seems days old stuff. Had bad feeling all day in stomach.
author: Ashish S.

description: Terrible service, fantastic food, not too expensive, and open late (midnight!) Probably the better of the desi restaurants located on Jones St. Not in a family friendly neighborhood if that's your thing, but it's totes worth it.
author: Junaid S.

description:
If you are in the mood for Indian, this place is great.

We ordered takeout through OrderAhead on Friday night. The process was painless, just walked right in and the food was ready to go. 

Chutney definitely lived up to the hype. Overall, the food was delicious. We ordered:
Chicken Tikka Masala - Very flavorful and rich. We both thought it was delicious. 
Bengan Bharta (eggplant cooked with onions, tomatoes and spices) - We had never tried this before, but went for it because it sounded tasty. It did not disappoint. It was milder than the Chicken Tikka and balanced it perfectly. Would definitely get again.
We also go Naan and Garlic Naan.

Side note: we were expecting rice to come with the curries but it turns out that rice is not included. Luckily we had enough naan so it wasn't a huge deal. We didn't see rice on the menu as a side, but would try asking for rice as an addition next time we order from here.
author: Alden Q.

description:
I love this place! Probably favorite Indian food in the city. You order up front and seat yourself, and it's pretty relaxed. The tikka masala and saag are my favorite foods, but be aware they leave the bone on the meat. The garlic naan is delicious too. :) 
Their drinks are overpriced, and oftentimes the cans of soda or warm, but that's the only draw back to the place. Overall one of the best places in the TL.
author: Montana O.

description:
Great food, excellent service. 
Tandoori fish is really tasty, and the brain dish was an interesting try. Spicy and tasty, though after a while the texture got to me. 
Hot chai tea was great to wash it all down with.
author: Deanna L.

description:
We stopped here for dinner last night, after another unsuccessful attempt at the  lottery drawing for the Book of Mormon show at the Curran Theater. I was happy with the food and the very reasonable prices. Our bill came out to only $23, with our meal consisting of lamb curry, Chicken Saag, garlic Naan, and rice.  You know the food is authentic when you see a good number of Indians/Pakistanis in the restaurant as well. 
The service, however, is extremely slow.  It must have taken almost 40 minutes or so to get our food out.  If it wasn't for the (complimentary) salad and the mango lassi that came out early on, I would probably not have been as forgiving about the slow service. I am one of those people that really can't wait another minute when hungry. 
Great food, and the guy at the register was pleasant as well.  I'd come here again if I was in the area.
author: Celine S.

description:
I am a diehard fan of Shalimar in Fremont and Chutney has a similar service style and ambiance. We were in the city on Christmas day and ended up at Chutney based on their high yelp rating.

We ordered, found an unclean table in the packed restaurant and sat down. After 10mins of waiting, our table was finally cleaned. The cleaning was of course not thorough and some spoons and napkins were left behind under the table. I was willing to forgive them as all I wanted was some exceptional grub. Our 15mins of wait turned into 30mins. A larger table seated after us were also served food meanwhile. We kept waiting for 10mins more, after about 45mins of wait we finally asked the server if it would take longer. They had clearly forgotten us. We got our dishes in a couple of minutes after we asked.I can understand where they are coming from and service was clearly not their strong point. I was only looking for top notch food and did not care about the rest.

Anyway, the food arrived and the first thing I noticed were tomatoes in the biryani!! I tried to calm myself down hoping the tomatoes in their biryani elevated it somehow. Anyway, all they did was turn parts of the biryani they came in contact with into absolute mush. The chicken in the biryani had 80% bone and it was tough hunting for some meat. The only positive was that the little meat was falling off the bones easily, implying it was extremely well cooked.Taste wise it can best be termed bland.

We also got the special of the day- achari murgh, some chicken sheesh kebab and garlic naan. The naan was non greasy, fresh and soft. The sheesh kebabs were crying for some extra kick. The achari murgh was not too greasy and definitely tasted like achari murgh. The only negative I could find in the curry was the excessive use of whole peppercorns and coriander seeds. It is definitely nice to get some whole spices once every few bites. But, 5 of them in every mouthful is not good. The positive was that the chicken was easily falling off the bones like the chicken in the biryani.
author: Minu M.

description: Ohh it's basically Pakistani resturant it's open kitchen they don't have any chef and Spanish people cooking for us they don't even know what the taste should be like and even in vegetarian food they have leftover gravy from any non veg dish cooked the service is terrible as there is no such thing in the resturant will not suggest to non of my friends it's waste of money and playing with health
author: Raj S.

description: Good was very flavorful. The naan was very good and not over cooked! I obviously ordered the chicken tikka masala and wasn't disappointed. Ask for spicy though;)
author: Megan B.

description:
Maybe it's my new LA 'tude, but I have to dock Chutney's a star!  GASP!

I was back in San Francisco for only two days after not being here for almost two years since moving away.

I planned a lunch at Chutney's with all of my best friends!

We all ordered, sat, and waited.  The food that DID come out was just as delicious as I remembered it.  Really fantastic.  BUT the problem was a lot of the food didn't come out!

I had to get up and ask for our rice and naan twice.  A curry with no rice or bread is...  well...  soup.  And even after the second time of asking, it was still awhile before they came out, at which point my Paneer Tikka Masala wasn't hot anymore.

Sad belly means one less star.  Sorry Chut's, our reunion was lackluster.  :(
author: Jess R.

description:
OMG!! this place has AMAZING food, i love coming to chutney good chicken tikka masala, lamb biryani, naan bread!! I'm getting hungry just talking about it! 

when it gets busy this place does tend to get loud, hard to get tables too, if you see an empty table DON'T HESITATE! lol seriously.
author: Omar H.

description:
Well what can I say about this place. I've been here a few times when I visit my sister in San Francisco. They have delicious food and they are pretty quick to serve you. When you first walk in you stand in line to order and then you get and get a table. I went to stand in line with my younger sister and the guy taking our order I guess knew my sister who was a regular there. He proceeds to ask my sister if i'm her mother? I mean really? we are only a few years apart and you ask a customer that looks around the same age if I'm her mother. Well that got me in a tizzy. So I gave him stink eye and walked away. I guess he thought it was funny.

So our food came out and it was delicious. We got a curry and some chicken dish. I can't remember the name of the dishes but they were all very good. 

The dining room is a bit small but there is about 20 tables in there. I didn't see any street parking but like most san fran people you walk everywhere so that shouldn't be a problem.
author: Kelly Y.

description: This place was fantastic! I mentioned it later to a bartender and he also said he loved it. Based on other yelper's I got the chicken tika masala... it was delicious! The garlic bread was bigger than my face and I got the last 2 samosa's of the day! The mango lassi was so refreshing on a unseasonably warm San Francisco afternoon. The neighborhood however is not ideal. I would not walk there alone at night.
author: Sarah P.

description: Amazing food!!!  I am a big fan of Indian food, but very rarely this impressed with an Indian restaurant this good!  Tikka masala so delish. Service was great too, and prices surprisingly low.  In fact, the ticket got mixed up with another customers and we were accidentally over charged.  When he realized it he came running down several blocks with cash in hand to make it right. Wow.  That was a surprise.  Super impressed.  Will return for sure!
author: Misty D.

description:
Sub-par Pakistani/Indian fare. There are a whole bunch of these style eateries in the city where you get great non vegetarian, tandoori style cuisine that are hand over fist superior to Chutney even within a block radius of this one. No reason to go here!

Our food was distinctly "charred" and I'm not talking meat--the lentil 'Chana daal' was under cooked yet was yucky and charred. The rest of the food was lacking in salt and generally tasteless. The naans were good and the helpings are not bad. 

Won't go again given such wonderful choices in the city.
author: Sam M.

description: I don't like indian food usually my husband wanted to go there so we gave it a shot, OMG unbelievable,  the food is soo good and their bread is to die for, i will be definitely there again, specially for their tea
author: Ghenwa S.

description: The best Paki food...Love the brain masala & their naan r really good..I always drive from stockton to frisco to eat here!!!
author: W W.

description: Even it seems dirty,last class place the taste is over my all expectations and it is the only enough reason to give 5 stars.Lamb masala,kebabs,naan and free chai and so on. The best thing is the price. If you have late night eating habit,i heard that best time to go there is around midnight.
author: Hanifi S.

description: We stumbled out of a bar and walked past this place and checked out the menu in the window and suddenly we were Starving!!! we ran in and ordered our usual favorites. Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Saag, Rice, Naan & mango Lassi. Im not sure if it was the drunk munchies talking but it was terrific! We agreed the dishes were creamier than the ones we are used to, but it was so great! It was terribly inexpensive and perfect. I even asked the guys to come home with me and cook in our kitchen. (also the drunk munchies talking) They politely declined but were charming!
author: Chandra M.

description:
Chutney's one of those funky places where you order at the counter, your food is brought to you, and then you pay at the counter on your way out. Also one of those places that, given one too many whiskeys, you might stumble out post meal, light a cigarette, and remember that you should probably go back inside and pay.

The food here is awesome. All of the Tikka Masalas that I've tried have been great - my lady's hooked on the Bengen Bharta in a serious way. Usually a meal for the two of us (two dishes, rice and naan) comes to about twenty bucks, with enough left over for lunch the next day.

And wait. Did I mention the bottomless chai? The consumption of as many cups as possible during your visit is a delicate art - it goes fast, but keep an eye on it throughout your meal and they'll keep fillin' the thermoses in the back up with super hot, spicy delicious chai. (Don't forget to fill up a paper cup on your way out and take it for the road.)
author: Reishi A.

description:
been here several times and sure to be back.  Their chicken tikka masala is tasty, get it extra spicy.  Like their hot fresh garlic naan.

points deducted because service can be spotty (we were told to sit the first time we went there and then ignored.  A line formed at the counter and we were quickly forgotten) and also their water half the time tastes really awful.

it's a good place for groups though.
Oh, and apparently they have goat brain curry.  I'm not brave enough for that =)
author: Van W.

description: I was actually a little bit disappointed. Maybe I was expecting too much because of the high reviews but I don't think it lived up to its reputation.  My to-go order consisted of the Tandoori chicken salad - easy, simple and healthy.  I liked it and it was just the right amount to satisfy ones hunger.  I also got a naan and some samosas.  The naan was hot and fresh and while I've had really awesome fresh fluffy delicious naan at other places this was pretty standard and I thought it was alright.  However, the samosas.  It would have been ok if only it had been cooked thoroughly.  I got halfway through the first one before I noticed some stringy stuff in it.  Was it cheese? I didn't think samosas usually had cheese in it and besides, it didn't smell or taste like cheese.  And the other one didn't have it.  So I could only determine that it was still some uncooked dough.  That pretty much killed my appetite.  Luckily I chomped down my salad first and all my chicken was cooked perfectly.
author: Mercy D.

description:
Nevermind the hooker soliciting cheap thrills or the crackhead selling you his torn shoelaces as you enter 

Quite the treat in the unstoppable TL district, Chutney fills the stomach and satisfies the taste buds. And they have for the last several years I've visited this place

Although, on my next visit I'm going to be adventurous and try something new other than my FAVORITE usual items:

Chicken Tikka Masala ($6.49) SPICY with rich tomato sauce & grilled chicken

Palaak Aloo Methi ($5.49) Spinach curry with potatoes

Palaak Paneer ($6.49) Spinach curry with cheese...my FAVORITE among the dishes. Very flavorful and should be paired up with any of the naans I mention on the next item...

Aloo Naan ($1.99) Smashed potatoes stuffed in soft, warm naan bread. I enjoy Aloo a lot more than the garlic & onion naans just because Indian cuisines are generally rich in flavor particularly spices, so the very thick & filling Aloo naan can tone down the heavy flavoring of the curries, tikkas or gravies

Tandoori Chicken ($2.99) Very dry from the supposed tender grilled chicken but the spice and flavor were there

Don't expect intimate ambiance & state of the art lighting. It ain't DOSA & it ain't Naan n' Curry either... it's Chutney, a very simple, sit-down venue for people to enjoy the food without the presentation to reckon with. Plus, I appreciate the reasonable prices & fast service even though I bite my tounge as to mention that our waiter took my plate as soon I was just CLOSE to finishing my meal ... cool disappearing act...poof!
author: Charmian D.

description:
Pretty solid Indian food. The Began Bharta eggplant dish was excellent.  

The flavors are more simple and homey (less complex). I think they're dishes have good flavor based on the spice combinations, but they are not stewed as well. The chicken korma was very watery and simple.

This place has a lot less grease than Shalimar, but then again I love grease!
author: Katie Y.

description: I was apprehensive about trying this restaurant because my friend warned me of the location - a really bad neighborhood.  It wasn't bad because there was still light, and diners kept coming.  However, I wouldn't want to be there alone.  We tried a couple of chicken dishes and Tandoori Prawns.  However, the highlights, in order of greatness, were Mango Lassi, Naan and Chicken.  Food is good, but not necessarily better than other Indian restaurants I've tried.
author: Ross W.

description:
Weirdest system ever: 
1. Order at the counter
2. Sit down
3. They bring you plates, a pitcher of water, a "salad", and your food
4. Stand in line again to pay

Really wish I could just pay when I order to avoid wasting time standing in line a second time. I wonder how many people just get fed up and skip out on the bill?

In my opinion, the best thing about this place is the price. Most entrees are $6.99 and veggie entrees are $5.99! Naan and rice come separately for $1 each. Not bad!

The food is pretty 'meh', in my opinion. Almost all the chicken entrees except the Chicken Tikka Masala come on the bone. This wouldn't be so much of a problem if the pieces were cut better, but as it is I always end up with oddly-shaped pieces of bone floating around the dish! The baigan bharta (eggplant) is ok, but quite oily. I usually like the naan, but yesterday the naan was dry and overly floury. Not good.
author: Talia G.

description:
Dear Chutney,
I loved you so so much but why the hell did you do me wrong man? It breaks my heart. The last time I went to go visit you I drove 6 freaking hours for you to make sweet love to my mouth. But the douche in the front told me that you were all out of "tikka masala" sauce and that I had to order something else from you. How could you?! But what makes me more sad is that you let the douche in the front lie to me. I saw the girl at the next table (who ordered a minute after me) EATING PANEER TIKKA MASALA! How could you lie to me? How could you let  that douche treat me this way? This is why I decided to break up with you. Goodbye forever. 

Never again yours,
Cyndi
author: Cyndi C.

description:
Chutney's a decent cheap eats escape from the overpriced Powell Street madness a few blocks away. I recently enjoyed the lamb vandaloo (6.99) which was pretty good. The nan was meh ($1). And the rice was well rice ($1). 

This spot offers counter service with the twist that you return to the counter after your meal to pay, which means if its crowded you're waiting in line twice, once to order then again to settle up. Seems a bit flawed. 

In keeping with a counter-table service hybrid, someone beings your place settings, water, and a "salad" comprised of chopped veggies on a bed of romain lettuce. 

Chutney's relatively cheap and tastes okay, but honestly Trader Joe dishes would rival the cuisine. While I didn't leave unhappy, I'm not dying to come back.
author: Quentin J.

description: This place is my comfort food spot. The chicken tikka masala is all you need. Aziz always takes care of us and they care about their customers. They are also consistent with taste because I go there often, always 8 out of 10 times they are on point.
author: Sean R.

description: Pretty nice place . The curry and naan here are awesome. BTW, I would forget the kabobs.
author: Louie Z.

description:
Had dinner here on Friday night. It was about 7pm when we walked in the door and were able to sit down right away.

We went for the basics:

two orders of chicken tikka masala with rice
two mango lassi

The flavor of the chicken tikka masala was so good. This was my first time, but my bf had claimed it was the "best chicken tikka masala ever". I can understand why he claims it as so because the flavor was spot on. The chicken, however, was pretty dry. Even between the two bowls there was some inconsistency. So I'm holding out hope that the next time we go, the chicken will be tender and juicy. 

The mango lassi (lassis? how do you pluralize that?) were HUGE. And only $2.50 if memory serves me right. After destroying the tikka masala, the mango lassi was a lovely dessert/drink to finish it off. Filled me to the brim, too.

All in all, I'm pretty sure this will be a new staple in my diet when I'm up in the city.
author: Alison C.

description:
Saturday night 9pm. Very crowded. You got to find your own table. Ordered naan, roti and mutter paneer.
Naan was ok. Roti was like rubber. Mutter paneer was bland, tasteless, liquidy. owner said their main customers are non-desis. So I should tell them to make it spicy.
author: Sandy K.

description:
I'm constantly surprised by how many Indian restaurants this part of town can support. The tandoori chicken is very good and becomes even better when you squeeze a little lemon juice on it. It's one of the better tandoori chickens I've had. The chicken tiki masala was disappointing though, it tasted like it was cooked in tomato soup - not something I'd order again. We also ordered the palak paneer which had a strange consistency because the spinach was pureed, but it tasted good and was a great dip for the naan. 

There is water in the back as well as chai, but the tea is watery so I skipped it.

In terms of value, the prices are right for the food you get and is in line or more inexpensive than other places nearby. I'd rate it as a pretty good value.

I almost ordered the goat brain masala but random images of mad cow disease and the scene from indian jones where they eat monkey brains flashed through my head and I chickened out. Maybe next time. 

I'd give Chutney 3.5 stars if I could, unfortunately I can't. There isn't enough to give then 4 stars, so 3 they get.
author: Russ C.

description: Always end up eating here when in town.  Not impressed with the decor, but Good food, great price; what really matters.
author: Dominic C.

description: Terrible service and horrible food. They serve meat floating in oil and call that authentic Indian/Pakistani food!!!! The place is very noisy and dirty and unsuitable for dine in. We ordered samosa, achaaar chicken and goat curry. Dough of samosa was raw inside. All goat pieces had mostly bones and hardly any meat. In chicken achari they did not care to cut the meat into pieces. They served two bone in chicken thigh.
author: Proma B.

description: Their BBQ is one of the best in town. We tried oven clay fish tandoori and it was simply delicious having the taste of fish with light masala. Highly recommended.
author: Marry M.

description: Ordered lamb curry. The lamb didnt seem to be very fresh and left an unpleasant aftertaste. Also its very much self service. You get your own water sauce etc. shalimar was totally packed at the time.
author: YM L.

description:
We were starving after a whole day sailing and ran into this restaurant from my brother's friend suggestion!

Awesome food & it's really CHEAP! I went with my BF, two Indian friends, and my brother. The food was good, the tea was comforting.

Here is what we order:
1. Paneer Tikki Masala (cheese curd in tomato curry sauce): very tasty & the flavor is absolutely amazing. 
2. Mixed Veg Tikki (veggie in curry sauce): flavorful & very yummy
3. Dal (kinda like lentil): This is average!
4. Nehari (beef curry): Mind-blowing flavor and spice love this one
5. Lamb Biryani (like Indian style fried rice): yummy :)
6. Beef kabob & Chicken tandori: both very good!

We also had naan, butter naan, some chapatti & rice.

Total is $52.00 for all 5 of us and we had some left over! 

Gotta say, even though we are from Silicon Valley where there are great Indian food in Sunnyvale, Milpitas, etc. this restaurant is a keeper!
author: Van N.

description:
If I didn't have a long history with Chutney, this would be a 1-star review. 

Tuesday night, 8:30PM Call Chutney for take-out. I'm told it will be 10-15 minutes. 

8:45PM: Fifteen minutes later, I arrive at Chutney. I'm told my order will be done shortly. I'm double parked, so I decide to find a real parking spot for my car, but the Chutney manager tells me it will probably be OK (glad I did not take his advice). 

9:05PM: Food is finally ready, but I notice that the mint chutney sauce has exploded out of its container all over the bag. Chutney manager says he will fix it. I see him dish out a new container of rice. The cashier won't let me pay at this point even though I want to get out the door because he can't recall how much my bill is and won't tally it up again since the manager already did it. 

9:10PM: Finally get my food and pay and on my way. This is a full 40 minutes after I called and 25 minutes after the promised time. Out the door, I notice that the chutney sauce is still all over the bag. Ugh. 

9:25PM: Arrive home to see that the mint chutney sauce has seeped inside two dishes that I ordered, and there's pretty much unwanted sauce everywhere. 

Also, the bengan bharta (eggplant) turned out pretty gross. 

Chutney: I am so glad you are busy and your business is thriving, but why are you so inconsistent?? When you're on, you're really on, but when you're off, it's really horrible. 

Don't set expectations that it will be 10-15 minutes, when it's more like 45 minutes. All would be forgiven if the service was better - maybe a smile and "sorry it's taking so long" or actually caring that the sauces didn't explode all over my dinner and fixing it. Or even if the food was top notch, then I could forgive all these missteps but sadly, it's not tonight. 

I hope you fix your glitches.  I've been going to Chutney for a long time, and I want to keep coming. I'm sad to be writing this review.
author: kathy c.

description:
I haven't been here in awhile and so miss this place. This was the first place I tried Indian food (ever). The man behind the register suggested a few vegetarian items and they were all awesome. He even explained ordering rice, naan and a entree. Every time I have gone here, the people working here made awesome suggestions. I am a vegetarian so I have tried only the vegetarian menu items.
There is unlimited chai tea on tap.
This place can get very busy, especially at night and on weekends. I think the longest I had to wait for my food was 20 minutes but it was worth the wait.
Everything here is pretty cheap and if you like spicy, you can ask for the items made spicy. That is if you like it hot as I do.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Solid 4 star goodness.  Food is good and cheap.  They do have great Goat Curry.  I've heard the biryani can be hit or miss...today it was a hit.  Will be back for a late night curry craving.
author: Zoran L.

description:
Absolutely fantastic.

After months of trying to find an North Indian restaurant that had delicious food at an affordable price, I finally feel my prayers have been answered! We ordered for a pickup at my office, and everything from the food to the service was phenomenal. We ordered a variety of different dishes from Samosas, Korma to Palak Paneer to Chicken Vindaloo and I have to say there was not one thing we had that was anything less than delicious. 

I would highly recommend ordering from this place and definitely look forward to coming back here again soon!
author: Nav K.

description: I ate their couple of times. For some reason I find their food isn't real authentic indian food. The first time when I ate goat curry, I found something was missing in the taste. I realized it's missing that spicy element that I find in real goat curry. The second I ate chicken Karahi. I felt like those fried chicken was dipped into tomato sauce ? You kidding me ?
