I would recommend some other restaurants nearby coz I think they have authentic and real spicey indian food.
author: Krishna L.

description: Maybe the meat dishes are great here but for vegetarians you're better off going to another establishment.
author: Josie C.

description:
I love chutney! 
The service is great.The cashier is always soo nice to me, he knows my name and my regular order already! The place is clean, busy, and above all delicious. They don't deliver, but you can order for pick up at anytime.   
 
I've tried several items and these are my favorite ones 

I have to be honest, I'm kinda obsessed with their chicken Tikka Massala, it is so good and its only $6.50.The only down side is that it doesn't have enough chicken pieces, but it has plenty of the Massala dipping sauce!  I always order it with a side of Garlic Naan for dipping! So BOMB!

 The Seekh Kabab is a tender skewer of ground beef cooked in a clay oven that goes perfectly with their sauces, specially the sweet plum sauce!

The Keema Naan is really good too, its a Naan stuffed with flavorful ground beef. Perfect as a side order!
The other day, I ordered the Rice PUllao-- basmati rice with saffron, its a better option than their plain rice.

The only bad part is that some dishes are way too spicy. My mouth has been on fire--literally, felt like I was drinking lighter fluid and I had to drink a gallon of water to cool off-- specially with the Lentils (Daal Masala) and the Garbanzo beans (Chana Masala). I've even ask for a "mild" order, but still they were still inedible for me. Other veggie dishes are really spicy too, so be careful !
author: Angela R.

description:
People who love Indian-Pakistani food and of  Indian-Pakistani descent will not agree with me that this place has good food.

Why? They think the food is too Americanized and it does not live to its Indian-Pakistani name.

Well, I disagree. I love their food here - lamb baryani, naan bread, chicken tikka massala, panneer (that is spinach with goat cheese). I also love their mango lassi!

Recently, the owner and his son are treating us better! I guess they realized that  customer service comes first.

The con: No parking! It is Tenderloin area.

Come here and give it a try, you'll never know when you gonna bump into me.
author: Rokayah S.

description:
As you know, I am fearful of any place that has a menu -- where the word "spicy" is repeated more than a dozen times. When my boyfriend decided that we should go to Chutney - I whimpered. 

We ordered two garlic and onion naans, two mango lassi's, one side of rice and one chicken tikka masala. Yes, guess who decided she wanted to go to Saigon Sandwiches (review coming up) instead? My boyfriend insisted that I get something here and I insisted that I was not ready for Chutney to take away my Pakistani food virginity away.

Our food came out to $18 and we decided to get it to-go since I wanted to try Saigon Sandwiches. When we got our order, the smell of the Chicken Tikka Masala was so entrancing, I decided that I wanted to carry it to our car and that I was going to sit with it on the way home. It smelled that heavenly.

We decided to go to S.S. and then we went home. I decided to put my Vietnamese sandwiches away so I could eat some of the naan. What ended up happening was -- I ate all of the Chicken Tikka Masala and rice.  It wasn't even THAT spicy - never mind that I drank all of my Mango Lassi.

Chutney - I noticed that this is categorized under Indian and Pakistani -- does this mean conflict between two countries can result in some orgasmic food? Oh yes. Peace to the Middle East (and Asia).
author: Vanessa W.

description: Top notch home style Indian food. Wonderful ingredients and preparation. Some of the best paneer I've had in the US, and truly excellent sauces. I so miss this place when not in San Francisco. Highly recommended for foodies.
author: T. B.

description:
We were a little weary to try this place after seeing the location but after reading the Yelp reviews, we decided to give it a try. We're definitely glad we did! A little confusing when you first get there. You order up front but you wait to pay until after your meal. A little odd. You get your drinks yourself (pop, a pitcher of water, delicious hot chai) unless you order a different drink like Mango Lassi. A can of pop is only $1 and Mango Lassi is $2!

We ordered naan, palak paneer, chicken korma curry, and aloo ghobi. The meal also came with a plate of lettuce, tomatoes, and lemon for the table? But it didn't look like a salad, more like toppings for a burger? We didn't touch it and noticed most other tables didn't either. Anyway, the food came out after about 15 minutes and it was amazing! The spices they used were perfect, not underwhelming and not sweating-like-a-waterfall spicy. The palak paneer was different, it was more like pureed spinach with the same consistency of baby food. Nonetheless, it was still really good, just a weird consistency that I've never had in a palak/saag paneer dish. $27 for a meal for 3 people was pretty awesome too. Despite the quirks of this place and having to weave through a couple streets of homeless people, I will definitely be back here b/c the food is amazing and at the right price!
author: Allison F.

description:
Bad food, dont agree with yelp rating of 4 at all. Went on thur noon, ordered dal, matar paneer, naan, roti. Food had no salt , flavorless.
Was craving for indian food while in sf, this place crushed our expectations. Place doesnt feel very clean and is in a shady neighborhood. Wont go ever again. 
My advice, dont upset ur mood or stomach by going here.
author: Itisha J.

description:
This place is a must-go if you are a fan of Indian-Pakistani food. I have been going here for about 5 years and the food is constantly good. The place was recently painted about 3 years ago.

The chefs are mostly South American and they get the food right. The kitchen is visible from the dining area.

Once you go in, you have to go to the counter and order food there. Then they will give you a number and you choose your table. Once the food is ready, a runner will bring you the food or you can go grab it a the kitchen counter as well if you wish. 


Recommended dishes:
-Chicken Tikka Masala - a classic. Period.
-Lamb Biryani
-Shish Kebab
-Lamb/Beef Gobi
- The Naan is excellent too.

There are many other plates that are worth trying, and as you keep going you'll get the chance of trying a new plate each time. The hard part is not to order the same signature plates as before!!!


Enjoy!
author: Jaime S.

description:
This review is for the goat brain curry only.

This was just one of those things that we all just wanted to try but no one wanted to just eat the whole thing.  We got an order, and ate it outside.  It took a really really REALLY long time for them to make it.  Way too long, in my opinion.  Not sure what they were doing - maybe they went out to get the brains themselves that day from a goat at a nearby farm, I dunno.  As far as how it was, it tasted ok - consistency of tofu - not a bad flavor either.  We didn't try anything else, so can't really speak to any of the rest of the food there, but all I can say was the wait was killer, especially for a to-go order.
author: Jenna L.

description:
The chicken tikka masala had low spice and tasted like canned spaghetti O sauce. 

Very disappointed. 
I will try them again in a few weeks and hope they improve.
author: Zach L.

description: I've heard one can always tell a good ethnic restaurant by how many ethnic people eat there and every time I come here the place is packed with people of all backgrounds. It's like the United Nations on a Sunday night. I also love that I can see directly into the kitchen to check out how the food is being prepared and the service in the front is super friendly and fast. My favorites are the Aloo Gobi, tandoori fish and the chicken tikka.  It's consistently delicious which I have a great appreciation for.
author: Monica S.

description: Get the tandoori fish, because it is AWESOME. Not much for atmosphere at Chutney but with quick service, the best chicken tikka masala in town, and their tandoori fish, I gotta tell ya, Chutney will make you happy.
author: jodi s.

description: Just an FYI, though this business says that they "deliver" they only deliver if your order is $60 or over. Seriously?  Who is sitting at home on a Sunday night needing $60 worth of Indian food? Ridiculous. They really shouldn't pretend that they deliver.
author: Mariela C.

description:
Waited thirty minutes then food came without rice?
There food made my wife not be able to poop for two days 
I had stomach pain
It was all very weird tasting 
And then they overcharged us
author: M. B.

description: Had Daal Masala, Paneer Tikka Masala. Excellent food, albeit the Tikka was a bit too sugary. Good chutney. Mango lassi a touch too sweet.  Good level of spicyness for us (I like my spicy at 6 out of 1-10).
author: Mikko J.

description:
One of my friends swears by it - and apparently, he's not alone.

On a Thursday night, it was SWARMING with hungry customers.  It was good enough, and cheap enough, for a repeat visit.
author: Kristen S.

description:
This is up there with the tops. Around SoCal it is hard to find good Indian restaurants that cook food to order instead of having it sitting in a warmer/hot lamp for hours. 

Beware: The crazies come out at night.
author: Barry H.

description: I love this place. Definitely my favorite Indian Restraunt in the city. I have ordered many different items from the menu but I tend to always return to the always faithful Chicken Tikka Masala. Sadly I think they have changed the recipe, because it is still good but just a different taste than it used to be. I love this place though and will continue to come back!
author: Mandi H.

description:
Been coming here for almost 7 years I think.

Food is great. Place is small and cramped, but thats SF style. The bathrooms really need to look nicer, all it takes is a feminine touch and more attention to cleaning. 

I am writing a review after all this time to say that: the new guy who  mans the cashier knows how to treat a lady. hated the previous regular guy.

PS. I love how this place has no annoying TV barking an indian/pakistani drama.
author: Obeela O.

description:
Have been to this place many times, for my favorite - "Goat biryani", 
pretty much the exact level of spice that I desire, with sumptuous goat meat, and tasty biryani coupled with a complimentary cup of tea. 

While the location may not be a plus point, the food definitely is! I highly recommend having the 'goat biryani' at this place.
author: Animesh D.

description: I love this place!! Chutney in TL is by far the best Indian food I've had in San Francisco and its also a good deal. Just wish they opened one down here in Sunnyvale!
author: Karen W.

description:
Ordered takeout from here.. a mixed vegetable and naan.
The mixed vegetable was horrible.. the jeera and other spices tasted burnt, the gravy was watery and inconsistent, the vegetables were kinda hard, wayy too many peppers.. the overall dish was pretty horrible... I have nothing good to say about it.
The naan was ok.
This place would have been a pretty convenient Shalimar-alternative that falls on my route back home from work, but alas the food (atleast the dish i ordered) is not something I would want to eat again.
author: Aditya M.

description:
Absolutely disgusting.  We went on the 4th of July upon the recommendation of one of my dad's friends.  I'm also not sure why people gave this place such high ratings, they probably have not had much experience with real desi food.  In any case these were the problems we had:

1) Absolutely disgusting area.  Wierdos everywhere, not the place for a family.  If you're a single man it might be all right but I was with my entire family--horrible.
2) Low quality food.  One of the other posters also mentioned they put a lot of black pepper seeds--I can attest to that, the chicken jalfrezi was good but filled with it.  They also gave very little meat, rather they filled the dish with vegetables/sabzi. The chicken korma was horrible with no taste either.
3) We got ripped off on shrimp.  They charged 10 dollars for the shrimp dish and we got only 5 shrimp.  We asked for a fairer price, so they charged like 5 bucks.  
4) Slow service.  We asked for naan, it took them 10 minutes to get it, by that time food was cold.  

I would not go here again.
author: Mehdi K.

description:
First place I ate in SF on Friday. Wowzers. So amazing. Great prices.

I had the Chicken Tikka Masala, since it was chilly out it was like the most delicious soup in the world!!! Added on a Seekh Kebab for 1.99!!!! And Paneer Naan which was out of this world to dip in my curry and the mint chutney. Will totally go back!!!
author: Marcia A.

description: Not my GOTO place in SF however the Saag here by far better than some of its competitors.  I always order either lamb or paneer and its less greasy and finer consistency than any other Indian restaurants I frequent across the Bay.  Good service,  at least when I come.  My friend had them cater her wedding and henna party and that was wonderful!  Huge for like at least 300 minimum and it was heavenly.  I enjoyed that more than when I go to the restaurant.  Perhaps have them cater for you instead?? Still high ratings for me.
author: Nins D.

description:
Thought chutney was good, I definitely left a little disappointed, possibly due to the excellent reviews and personal recommendation of my hotel concierge.

My main issue with Chutney was the meat. My father ordered a special chicken curry (forgive me, I dont remember the name) and though he did say that the quality of the ground chicken meatballs was impressive, there were only three that were about three inches in diameter.  Another frustrating thing that was partially our fault: prices for specials weren't listed, so when we paid after we ate, it turned out the price of the special was significantly more expensive than the rest of the dishes.  I ordered the lamb tikka masala.  The taste of the sauce was great, but my lamb was primarily fat and there was a large piece of bone.  I felt a little cheated.

The naan was delicious and light, and the samosas, though not bad, definitely weren't the best I've ever has.

It was pretty good, but I would probably keep looking for my staple Indian restaurant if I lived in SF.
author: Gieselle A.

description:
Good food. Good prices. Bunch of liars.

I enter and I ask the employee if they take American Express. He says no so I say thank you and try to walk out. He stops me saying, actually they do take American Express, they just prefer not to because it costs more. He says it's fine. Are you sure I ask. Absolutely he answers.

I order my food and try to pay. He says I can pay later. In case I want to order more. I sit, eat and then I go up to pay.

Different guy at register. Don't see the guy who took my order. New guy (short, older Asian guy) says they don't take American Express. We go back and forth. Finally he takes my card and runs it saying how this is the only time and next time to bring a different card.

There will not be a next time for me. Why would I want to do business with an establishment that lies. Real shame as their food & prices are good.
author: Seattle F.

description:
This place is legit in the Tandoori Loin! Best dish of them all might be the chicken tikka masala. If sharing with multiple people, ask them for extra curry and it only costs maybe $1. You get the dish served in a bowl instead of a plate. That way you can order up some naan and polish off the rest of the curry. Another dish worthy of mention is the tandoori fish. It's catfish so you gotta make sure you're okay with that texture first. The beef kabobs sure dont look appealing but they go really well with the mint chutney. Drinks are self-serve in the back with complimentary milk tea if you dare. 

Don't be confused by ordering system - order first, get a number, eat, and pay at the end.
author: Dennis L.

description: I've gone everywhere in San Francisco looking for good Indian food... after one taste, I knew this was the place. The Indian food is rich in flavor and the service is excellent. Try the chicken tiki masala, the lamb biryani, chicken tandoori, and of course the garlic naan.
author: Samuel R.

description:
I've only been here once but I've been dying to go back. The first time I went, I absentmindedly followed my friends onto three buses and walked block after block. I have no idea how I got there or how I'll ever go back. Haha, chalk it up to my great sense of direction. 

I don't really like the way you have to order here. I was confused until my friends told me you have to go up to the cashier and order first. I got some veggie wrap without mayo. It was really cheap, under $10. The thing was huge! Being the fatass that I am though, I finished the whole thing. It was unbelievably good and had the perfect amount of spice to it. It was a little hard to eat just because it was so big and it had a hard time staying wrapped up. It was pretty messy. Haha.

There is water and milk tea in the back that you serve yourself. I didn't like the tea at all but my best friend loved it. 

I'll be back one day. Just as soon as I find out how to navigate myself through the streets of San Francisco.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Mmmmm Indian. Not my cuisine of choice, but every few weeks, I get a massive craving for Tikka Masala. Not normally the restaurant I go to, but for something different I said why not. My friend and I both ordered Tikka Masala (chicken for him, paneer for me), and garlic Naan bread. 

First off, garlic Naan bread?  Holy snickerdoodles, it's Naan with *HUGE* chunks of garlic spread all over. I've not had anything like that before. Yum yum!

The Tikka Masala was tasty tasty awesome. It's extremely saucy (SAUCY!) so I wound up taking advantage of the bread and rice far more than other restaurants with a similar dish. This is quite ok though cause the Tikka Masala sauce is tasty awesome in a dish.

Service is done a bit weirdly here... you order at a counter and then sit down, with a waiter bringing your food out. The issue is you don't actually pay until you're done eating. Because of the way it's set up, it's pretty easy to not actually pay and walk out. It's definitely a bit odd and easy to forget that you didn't pay at the counter. Make sure you do though! This place is quite good and worth the price (which, I might add, is pretty reasonable!)
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Just ordered my food..chicken tikka marsala..says its $8 and comes with rice..i also order naan for $2.. Rings me up and says its $13.50 .. I ASK HOW IS 8 +2 13.50? He says oh..rice is extra dollar.Ok, fine..so, $8+$2+$1 =$13.50? Right off the bat theyre ripping me off at the counter..not a good first impression..I sit down and they bring me a side salad..no dressing available..at all jus iceberg and tomato..one of the tomato slices is rotten.. OK..this place has a lot of good reviews I'll go with it..went out to smoke a cig ... came back and my table was cleared.. Really? I JUST came I'm Jere and was the only other table taken..not impressed w the customer service so far..  So my food just came let's see how this goes.. The chunks of chicken in the dish are quite large can't swallow them whole so I have to ASK for a knife..they only give you a fork and a spoon..u fucking kidding me? I also ask for a water and they bring me an empty cup ??????? Are these people fucking retarded? I have to ask to get water with my glass?? The food was OK ..jus ur average Indian place..with below average service.
.. Would I come again? No thank you..Fuck this place.
author: Don E. D.

description: Service was nice. And the ambiance was pleasant. Though from previous reviews I expected the best chicken tikka masala. It was ok in flavor but the chicken was tough. Sad face.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
If you can go to an Indian restaurant with an Indian and they like it, you know it's good.

I had a smattering of delicious, bargain Indian food.  I don't remember exactly which dishes I ate, but I do remember leaving very satisfied.  The hot chai was great!
author: Alex F.

description:
Perhaps it would have been better if I weren't sober.  Having known some great Pakistani kababs in my day, I didn't sample any of the curries on my visit so I could focus on the meats.  They were good, better than buffet-style Indian meats, but could have used more flavor and variety (would it kill them to add a bihari kabab?).  The tamarind sauce was too watery, but the cilantro sauce helped liven up the meats.

Seekh Kabab: Tasted a tad like meatloaf, could use more spices to balance out the strong beef taste.

Chicken Seekh Kabab: This one was nice because the chicken was subtle and really carried the spices.

Lamb Seekh Kabab: I'm a fan of ground lamb so was easy to impress on this one.  As with the other minced meat kababs, the coriander seeds weren't pleasant when you unexpectedly chomp on them...  could easily lose a filling!

Tandoori Chicken: The highlight of my order.  The outer edge (not skin, just meat) was full of spice and crispness.  The inside was moist and juicy.

Naan: Fresh and fluffy.  Simple to make, but also simple to screw up if serving old naan.  Glad this place does it right.
author: Adam B.

description:
Good solid food.  Very clean place and I like the kitchen is wide open to see.
However, of the bunch of similar places centered around this corner, my favorite is Pakwan.  Pakwan had more flavor and bigger portions.
On the positive side, Chutney is the least greasy and the ingredient quality seems very high.
author: Ric S.

description:
I got off early and decided to picked up my wife and her co-worker for an early dinner. Her co-worker suggested Indian cuisine. Nothing, but a little Mediterranean spices can't overcome my challenges. 

All three of our dishes were under $7.00. I had the Lamb Tikka Masala, wife had the Chicken Tikka Masala and her co-worker had a chicken dish that has spinach and some sauce (Obviously, I don't know the name). Each of us ordered a side order of Basmati Rice and an order of Naan. Despite having very little meat on our dishes, the sauce was very thick and spicy and absorbed very well with the rice and Naan bread. The thick Naan bread can absorbed any spill from any home's kitchen counter. 

Our meal also comes with a complimentary house salad and tea with milk. 

Wife's flashy Hello Kitty's Visa card was accepted here for our meal. This restaurant is one of the nicest and cleanest in the Tenderloin, but the dishes were just average and could be better.
author: Matt G.

description:
Fed two for lunch for under $18 and we did not order sparingly!  Location isn't amazing, but next time the line at Dottie's gets too out of hand, i'll just mosey across the street to Chutney!

We ordered:

--Chicken Tikka Masala ($6.49) -- Very creamy and lots of curry for your rice and naan if you're love dunking things in tikki masala like me.
--Tandoori Chicken ($3.50) -- Huge portion (one big chicke leg), but I would not recommended.  Frankly, it was pretty darn dry.  Could not taste the yogurt. 
--Garlic Naan ($1.99) -- Delish.  Not garlic flavord, but actual garlic bits all over the naan. 
--Bengan Bharta ($5.50) (smoked ggplant curry.) Perhaps my favorite dish of the meal.  A bit spicey but the eggplant was indeed smokey and saturated in curry flavor.
--Rice ($?)

...Last but not least *drumroll*...free Chai!!!  'm spoiled by the bad indian places in Berkeley, so that's a must-have to  me.

Only complaints -- food took a LONG LONG time to come out...and they ran out of Chai at some point.  I patiently waited until they brewed more :).
author: Kendra W.

description:
LOVED:
Chicken Tikka Masala: (though it would have been nice to have some more chicken in all the sauce).
The BBQ chicken: (I'm not sure what its really called) was literally the best chicken I've ever had in my life.  Not necessarily in terms of flavor, but the texture was absolutely perfect.  It was tender and flaky, and just perfect.
The price: $19 for all this, including sodas for two people.

LIKED:
Rice: Not bad... It's rice.

EH/NO.
Lamb: in lamb's defense, I don't like lamb.  But my husband swore that lamb is delicious in Indian cuisine.  Well we tried it, and it was rubbery. So, no.
Naan (Garlic):  It was kinda dry.... I love everything with garlic and cilantro.  But it was pretty dry.
Naan (paneer):  The cheese was really flavorless and had an odd texture.  Maybe that's what authentic should be?  But I wasn't too crazy about it.
Salad:  idk if it should even be called a salad.  Before we got our food we got a plate of lettuce, with three slices of tomato, and 2 slices of onion.  No dressing, nothing. It was kind of awkward lol.
author: Rox G.

description:
Should anyone ever ask, "Hey, Mari C., what do you think of Chutney in the TL?" 
I would say, "Chutney you found in the TL, or Chutney the restaurant, located in the TL?"
"Chutney the restaurant."
"Oh, ok.  Because if you just find it laying around, DON'T EAT IT.  But if you're talking about the restaurant, it's very nice and I would recommend trying it."

Thanks Russell W., for dragging a cantankerous group of hungry coworkers here for lunch, with the promise of circus elephants, hot air balloon rides, and free drugs.  We blindly followed.  

Once I realized how close we were to Lahore Karahi, I tried to make a run for it, but was ultimately convinced to give something new a try.  And it turned out to be a good idea. They offered decently priced dishes with self-service chai, which is a must-have at any Indian place.  We sampled the lamb curry, which was alright, the fish tandoori, which was bony and difficult to eat, the chicken tikka masala, which was the sweet hit of the table, and my personal favorite, a biriyani.  It was well-flavored, moist, and delicious.

Yeah, I'd eat that.
author: Mari C.

description:
After traveling to India on multiple occasions I find it hard to enjoy Indian cuisine.  I was pleasantly surprised with Chutney.

It wasn't as spicy as I expected but wow, was it flavorful!  They had a ton of traditional and non-traditional dishes.  Since I was someone's guest they ordered most of the dishes for us.  I wish I'd known what they were!  

We dined on a delicious and moist lamb kebob of sorts, tikka masala (because i love dipping and can't get over the sauce whether it's not common as a main course in India or not), and some eggplant dish that was to-die-for.  The garlic naan was perfect for eating everything with your hands.

The chai was okay though often unavailable.  It kept running out!  The place was exactly what I'd expect out of an authentic joint.  They wouldn't speak Hindi with me but that's cool.  I walked out fat, round, and thoroughly satisfied with the experience.  

I noted they recently added Paan as an option.  Next time I miss India...
author: Leslie A.

description: First time here very good garlic naan also with chicken tikka was like none I have had before just great recommend!
author: Johnny F.

description:
We love this place!  Chicken Tikamasala is bomb!  Best Mango Lasi i've had!

My hubby and I are regulars.  the only reason i dont give this place 5 stars is that the bathroom isn't clean.  I really think that this place is sooo much better than that, and it would raise their level if they would dress up the bathroom.  Paint it, put in a glade plug in, paper towls, and clean the floor please!!!!
author: Tashe S.

description:
Had dinner here last night.
Solid 4 stars.

Getting here was super easy, it was only a couple of blocks away 
from the hotel we were staying in. 

Anyways, a couple of things I'd mention:
Ordering was a little confusing.
You walk in and there's the register that says "Order here, pay here"
Yet, it was obviously a sit down place.
After we ordered the lamb vinadloo, chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, and an order of basmati, we got out number and took a seat.

Chutney is not a quiet place, which I liked for it being a Friday night.
Prime place to people watch as you're waiting for your food too. 
While we were seating, the we were given a couple of plates, utensils, and two empty glasses. But, out glasses weren't filled. 
Curiously, we saw pitchers of water in the refrigerator.
A couple of minutes later we were given a salad plate and out pitcher of water.  

Very much a self-service place, patrons treated Chutney like a second home.
The plates and utensils were just against a wall, so customers would grab any additional things they needed.
I also saw a couple of people grab their own pitchers and even a couple of sauces from the refrigerator. 

The food was delicious!
My lamb was fall of the bone cooked and the chicken tikka masala was some kind of wonderful. It had this orange color, which really did not disappoint in flavor. Rich, creamy, tomatoey..yum!
The side of rice we had was sweet and had a spice I couldn't place my finger on.
The naan was just okay. It was fluffy, but by the time we got it, it was cold.
No worries, just dip that sucker in the tikka masala sauce. 

I saw some of the customers go to the back and help themselves to some canteens in the back.
Not wanting to miss out on the experience, I did the same.
What I had was some delicious chai. 

Definitely a winner in my book.
For the price and location, I'm glad we stopped by.
author: Christal B.

description:
After stumbling around town in search of  of a cure for Happy Hour  my nose eventually drew me to the steps of Chutney. Nothing soaks up alcohol better after drinking all evening than a basket of Naan , Chicken Saag and a plate of Lamb Vindaloo

Maybe it was the alcohol, or maybe it was the appetite I had built from running around but this place is AMAZING. I still find myself suffering from residual foodgasms whenever I think back to those first several bites.

I'm not a an expert on Indian cuisine by any means, but anything this good HAS to rank pretty high up on any Indian's list.
author: Kevin T.

description:
There are tough choices here:
Pakwan
Chutney
Shalimar

(Lahore doesn't count because it is actually better than all of these and on its own category)

Although I haven't tried Shalimar yet.....Chutney by far wins it.  I've yet to hear something great about Shalimar besides that they too have BYOB that would make me go there instead of Chutney.  I did visit Pakwan and it was rather disappointing.

We had the following:
-Chicken Tiki Masala - the usual go to dish that didn't fail us
-Garlic Naan - pretty good
-Paneer Naan - awesome.  paneer naan is even better than the garlic naan
-Lamb Vintaloo - great flavor and really well tendered meat.

BYOB as always so bring a six pack.....or 30 and have a great meal and drinks.
author: Vincent K.

description:
My favorite Indian food restaurant.
A hole in the wall, surrounded by walkers, but definitely worth risking it all and becoming a zombie to eat its delicious tikka masala. I don't understand how there are some many drug addicts to bad stuff in SF when you could be hooked to the food of this place!
author: Alfonso C.

description:
Great prices.  $16 for two - (1) Chicken Tikka Massala, rice & garlic naan and (2) Chicken Tandoori & plain naan.  All of the dishes were delicious and the naan was big & chewy.  Plain naan is one of my favorite foods (Indian & otherwise) and Chutney has a great naan!

Be aware, it's the Tenderloin.  The best route is to walk in from Union Square on Geary; forget a late night snack here unless you know what you're getting yourself into.

My favorite SF places for Indian/Pakistani:
India Clay Oven
Chutney
Shalimar
author: Brian C.

description:
So, we were in SF in order to take my youngest to UCSF's cardiac department (you don't have to know all the dramatic details of this, I guess) and we were staying at the Hotel California thanks to my elder kid, and innocently wandered out into the streets. Since youngest kid can't walk far without strain, we were limited to whatever was really really close. I spied a Mexican place just across the street, which would have been our fallback, but we found ourselves outside Chutney. Gazed at menu in window. It looked good, and the place was busy, so we wandered on in.
I think we were the only pale folks there that night. All around us were groups and families speaking languages I didn't understand. Children now and then merrily dashing about. Laughter. It was fabulous, and even my sound sensitive youngest didn't seem to care that it was loud. We ordered Veggie tandoori and veggie korma and some rice and some garlic naan and some sort of wrap, and...oh my goodness, this was good, good, spicy, wonderful, delicious food. We shared it out, my youngest thought the provided lettuce/tomato/fresh onion, fresh lemon slices should be salad, so he gobbled a platter of that also, including the lemon slices, peel and all.
It was a lively, warm, deliciously satisfying stop
author: Kathy E.

description:
I don't know how justified my rating of Chutney is, for I have only been there 3 times.  However, each of the times I went I had nothing but great food and service.

The line gets long if you go around dinner time on a weekday, but I've always managed to get in right before that line forms, so I only ended up waiting when I went back to pay the bill.

The Chicken Tikka Massala is awesome.  Sure, they could give more than the 5 pieces of chicken with the order, but for the small price of the dish, I never had a problem with it, as long as I got rice & naan to go with it (the garlic naan of course).  I also splurged and got a mango lassi as well, which was consistent every time.  

All 4 things for a little under $14 seems perfect for a college student like me, and I pretty much left all three times satisfied and with left overs for later.

Bravo, Chutney :)
author: Brian M.

description:
I came with my boyfriend one evening when we were in the city anyway and decided to have dinner before heading home. 
We ordered garlic naan, tandoori fish, and vindaloo chicken.
The fish was excellent and was by far the best thing we ordered. It was charred black on the outside, which I didn't mind at all. However my boyfriend friend it only okay. I also enjoyed the garlic naan. 
But I'm giving this restaurant 3 stars because my boyfriend said the vindaloo chicken was by far the worst he'd ever had. He said it didn't have much flavor at all and seemed like it had been sitting for a long time. We've eaten a lot of Indian food, so for any dish to be the worst is certainly saying something.
However, the restaurant was clean and the staff was friendly. Aside from the one dish, everything was delicious. If you enjoy fish and don't mind removing the bones, I'd recommend the tandoori fish.
author: Tori H.

description:
Definitely won't be ordering from here again. I ordered lunch for my office through eat24 at 11am for a meal at 12:30. At 11:15, eat24 called to say that they had confirmed with the restaurant and that our meal would arrive at 12:30.
12:30 rolls around....no food.

I call the restaurant and they act like they had no idea our order existed (even though they confirmed). They say that they need to call eat24 then they'll call me back about my order....which should have arrived 10 minutes ago. They also said they'd throw in a free dessert...uh, thanks?
Meanwhile, I'm chatting online with eat24's help team. They contact the restaurant as well and tell me that it's going to be 20 minutes, although they agree that sounds incredibly unlikely since they didn't start cooking our meal until 12:45. They also negotiated with Chutney for a discount for their poor service because one free dessert was not going to cut it.
FINALLY, an hour and 15 minutes after it was supposed to be at the office, they show up. Our order is messy and they didn't follow the basic instructions I had put on the order. They didn't label any of the meals (seriously there are 14 meals, none of which are labeled and all look vaguely the same) and didn't differentiate them by levels of heat. I pointed that out to the delivery team (it took two people to deliver this meal an hour late) and they labeled them with post it notes. Super helpful guys. 

Overall, my coworkers said the food was alright, but not worth the wait or poor service. Alas, I must continue on my quest for decent Indian food in SOMA.
author: Natalie P.

description:
SHORT MENU AND INFO PROVIDED ON THE MENU ITEMS ARE WRONG!!!! Let me start of by saying yuck! Yes I said yuck. The food is mostly burnt, toasty, dry. I ordered Tandoori fish, Brain Masala, Naan and Lamb briyani. Why I say burnt because everything which I ordered came out to me burnt from hell. Watch out from their brain masala it's way too smelly and I don't even think they are using goat brain because the size of the brain meat served at your table looks way to big and over sized as of like a cow or maybe there using (bhains) AKA buffalo brains. I have seen goat and lamb brain it's very small compare to what I got was huge chunks I highly doubt that this restaurant serves some other animal brains for sure. Now lets talk about lamb briyani Yuck also! The meat provided for this lamb briyani was very huge as of again I am saying cow but if someone closely pays attention to lamb meat in the meat store and what you got in this restaurant is totally  different. The lamb pieces are huge and it also has a weird blood smell like it's not cooked right. LONG STORY SHORT DON'T GO!  IF YOU LIKE GETTING CHEATED FOR EATING SOMETHING WRONG ON THE MENU. I CAME TO THE BAY AREA WITH FAMILY AFTER SUCH A LONG TIME, SOME FRIEND SUGGESTED ME THIS PLACE BUT NOW I HIGHLY REGRET GOING. 

P.S : MAKE SURE YOU KNOW WHAT YOUR EATING. AS A DESI I CAN SAY I KNOW WHAT I ATE AND IT WAS YUCK BUT POOR WHITE AND OTHER ETHNICITY PEOPLE THINK THAT THERE EATING GOOD DELICIOUS PAKISTANI, INDIAN FOOD BUT.... THEIR BEING DUPED.
author: Sadaf K.

description: This is the best Indian restaurant. My favorite food is Tandoori Chicken & Naan.
author: George Y.

description:
Amazing.  Delicious Indian food with generous portions in a place I don't mind sitting down at for a long lunch?  AND free chai tea?  Check.

Okay, that last one isn't super hard to find but there ARE places that will charge a pretty penny.

I had the chicken tikka masala, chicken bodi, garlic naan, and basmati rice.  I'm not wild about the chicken bodi (my first time having it)... it seemed dry.  Maybe that's how it is.  The tikka masala was perfect; flavorful without being overly spicy or creamy.  I can't believe I hadn't been here before.  I've tried all the popular places and had settled on the expensive Mehfil as my go-to.  Chutney's the new go-to now.
author: Erika C.

description:
Slow service, creepy vibe - I was the only woman in there for a solid thirty minutes and I was alone, but should that matter - and they used spice to cover up a lack of flavor.

Not sure what the hubbub is about on here... Perhaps it was an off day?
author: Shauna S.

description:
Given that this place was rated pretty well on Yelp and was only a few blocks away, I decided to give it a try.

When other people talk about the service being lacking, they definitely aren't kidding. When it was finally my turn to order at the counter, the manager took a call right in front of my face for at least 5 minutes. I would've been perfectly fine if he'd just asked to be excused or apologized for holding me up while I stood awkwardly in line, but I guess it's what kind of service you'd probably expect anyways.

I had ordered a Chicken Korma Curry and naan, and I guess I was expecting something... more when my order came out. It was basically only pieces of chicken with curry that turned out to be mostly bone and tendon, which was incredibly disappointing. However, the curry and the naan were both great, so that kind of makes up for it?

I thought that my meal on the whole was pretty unimpressive (coupled with the shoddy service and wait), but I'll probably be back to give this place another try just in case I didn't order the right dish and service is better.
author: Jonathan H.

description: This place was a huge let down. Luckily they got the naan right. My chicken korma was mostly bone, fat and tendon with little amount of dark meat on chopped bones in a soup that sort of tasted like korma. Not a creamy almond/cashew curry like I'm used to. Rice...fine. Naan...fine. My friend's vindaloo looked and tasted the same as mine. The other dish, tikka masala was mostly tomato-ey and ok. 800+ reviews led us wrong.
author: Parker K.

description:
Very average Indian food.  The tikka masala was more tomato-y than what I've had before and they were very sparse with the chicken. 

Chicken Tikka--2.5/5
Fish Tandoor--4/5
Lamb w/ Cauliflower-3.5/5
Mango Lassi-3/5

The set-up is very strange as well.  You order up front, eat, and then pay later.  So you basically end up waiting in line twice...not very efficient if you ask me.
author: Kim C.

description: BEST INDIAN ANYWHERE!! I usually come here with my boyfriend and we just enjoy it here so much. This place has a very layback atmosphere and they allow u to BYOB which is dope, since they do not serve alcohol. Anyhow, we've driven cross country and have tried many different chicken tikka masalas and lamb briyanis from many different places, but nothing compares to Chutney's. Hands down. Chutney has ruined me on any other Indian spots, as none will ever be the same.
author: dylan t.

description:
Oh yea. The Chicken Tika Masala could become an addiction. Very casual, somewhat strange, atmosphere.

Thinking of getting take-out? Get ready for a bizarre process... if you try to make any sense out of what the guy at the front does and how he keeps track of the orders and food, as it arrives from the kitchen, your brain will start smoking.  There's really no assurances that you'll ever get your food, but somehow, you do.  Eventually.
author: John D.

description:
How disappointing!  Of the 3 places on this corner this is by far the weakest. I'm not Indian nor have I been to India. However, I self taught myself how to cook Indian which I do at least once a week. 

Yeah the food is cheap and fast but this is prepared for white folks. The flavors are mild, bordering on bland.  This is why some of the reviewers think the dishes are watered down. This was easy to notice in the veggie korma I ordered.  The base for korma is dairy, usually milk w/corn starch or cream or yogurt. None of this was found in my dish.  Thus making a usually creamy dish, very watery.  The other flaw in the dish is the use of frozen vegetables.  When ordering a a vegetarian dish, the veggies must shine.  That was not the case.  The lack of flavor didn't stop there. Even the chai was weak.   

To be fair the biryani was tasty and the free salad was decent.  The roti was a little sad but at least it was big.
  
I can see why this place is a little more attractive than it's surrounding competitors since it is cleaner and friendlier but I'd rather eat at a dingier place with better food.
 
Perhaps, my visit was an anomaly? However, my Indian friends agreed with my experience.
author: Roger H.

description:
Chutney is my Favorite Indian Restaurant in San Francisco. As we all know; when it comes to eating Indian Food we really have to think of the consequences. I've been a customer of chutney for almost 6 years & I never had problems ;-). It's Clean, the Food is delicious & it's not too spicy. If you haven't tried their Food or you're a spicy phobic...DO IT, nothing will happen to you. 

The Food is very cheap. Chicken Tikka Masala for ($6) 2 people can share this. I usually order Masala sauce without chicken which cost $3 & I add chicken Boti $6 which is a BIG portion of grilled chicken which should be enough to Feed 3 Normal Human beings. Plain Naan (Bread) is yummy and it cost $1. Ooh I must mention the Kebab (seikh Kebab) only $1.99 best spicy kebab you'll ever eat. Their Food is addictive. Folks if you're feeling down & life isn't treating you right, Go to Chutney it will give you hope.
author: Bara N.

description:
There are no slimy alleys to traverse, no TVs blaring, no fluorescent lights shining at Chutney. I point this out only to establish a pattern in which Chutney blows the roof off its competitors in this curry-rich region of San Francisco. The ordering process is straightforward in its efficiency. Look at the laminated menu, place your order with the handsome, smiling man (he struck me as a South Asian Jesus) behind the counter and take your plastic number to your table. 

Try and fetch your own silverware, napkins and water tureen and you will be gently nudged back to your table - they've got this part covered and will bring everything you need to you. Food arrives in a timely manner and is for the most part delicious - especially considering the price.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Well I would love to give them more stars but we never received our food.

Things started poorly shortly after when we walked in. The gentleman running the cash register never offered to help us (after 8 minutes) until a customer waiting in line to pay for his meal said, "Are you going to help those people first?" He also took one order and a party of four's money (who cut in front of us) first as well. Didn't start us off with the feeling like we were welcome and we should have taken the hint.

He then took our order and pointed to the back where the water and table service was. We took our number, got ourselves water and service, found a table up front and then waited ....and waited ....and waited while we watched people who ordered after us get table service, drinks, salad and tea brought to them.

After about 20 minutes we politely asked if our food was coming up. He said he'd check and then disappeared and never came back to tell us how much longer it would be. 10 minutes later we started seeing people who ordered after us get their warm food.

My husband asked one of the servers if our food was coming out pointing to our number and the server didn't even look at my husband or the number; he just walked right past him like he wasn't even there. We grabbed our coats and walked out. 

We were disappointed as Chutney looked like a very tasty place to eat and we sure were hungry (especially after walking in the door 35 minutes beforehand). We happily spent our money at the sushi restaurant around the corner and promptly told everyone of our negative experience on our Facebook check-in.
author: Deb W.

description: Ok, so I've been on this biriyani rampage. I tried a few Indian places and found this one is the best! I love that their biriyani had a major kick and is sprinkled with tomatoes! It's the BeST! Not only is the biriyani yummy, the lamb curry is bomb.com. I can't wait to go back!!! No other Indian place is hitting the spot. I miss u, chutney.
author: Nance V.

description:
My favorite (indian cuisine) destination in SF.  Chutney started my obsession with the flavors of India over 2 years ago.  I can attribute at least 5 pounds of my body weight to this restaurant.  

Quality and flavor is back.  Eat there!

Must order:
   -Chicken Tikka Malasa
   -Seekh Kabob
   -Beigun Bharta
   -Bhindi Masala
   -Rice
   -Naan

I've eaten here at least "dozens" of times, sometimes twice in a week.  The owners still don't recognize me or my family though...

Excellent value.  Decent prices.  Lively atmosphere.  Extremely noisy.  Can be challenging to find a place to sit, but ABSOLUTELY worth the wait (and a 40 mile roundtrip drive from the San Mateo area).

More later...
author: James G.

description:
This WAS my boyfriend and I's favorite place- we go to both the SF & Fremont location.
Until last night.
I went there with a group of 6, everyone orders Chicken Tikka Masala except for 2 of us. We had Lamb Curry & Lamb Tikka Masala. Guess what...the 2 of us who had lamb got ILL! Everyone else who had the chicken was fine.
So I call and let them know...and the person who answered was rude! Hey man- I'm just trying to help him out but he acted like it wasn't his problem.

So I called the health department on them. Their restaurant inspection from June 2010 got a BAD review.  You can find this info online. Just an FYI.
author: Stacy S.

description:
uhnomnomnom...

Just finished my takeout order from Chutney's and I am one happy camper! Samosas, naan, and lamb vindaloo.

When I arrived, the place had a good number of people enjoying food, which is always a good sign. I was quoted a quick EPT of 15mins, but wasn't able to get to the restaurant for about an hour due to an unplanned shopping trip; so I'm hoping this is the reason why my to-go bag was waiting for me on an unoccupied table near the register, rather than behind the counter? This was my first visit here, so perhaps they use that area regularly for pickups. But, I'm happy to report, this was the only raised eyebrow moment I had during my experience.

To the food:
Samosas (2/order) were a filling, hefty size (compared to other places) filled with soft potatoes, peas and a nice blend of spices for flavor. The sauce had that nice sweet 'n sour taste that makes the samosas that much more delicious.

Naan, oh naan, oh.naan! It's really good. There's two other places in the immediate area and I'm willing to bet dollaz that this place has the best naan. Soft (even when it's not straight out of the oven hot) and fluffy. mmmmmm.

My lamb vindaloo was also good. Though, I think because it had to be packed to-go, there was something to be desired that I can't quite put my finger on. The lamb was tender and soft off the bone, and there wasn't too much fat to pick around on the bone. The potatoes were good and the sauce was tasty as well.
author: Jamie T.

description: Not authentic Indian food at all. The lamb Vindaloo was very mild, not spicy at all. The chicken tikka masala tasted sweet and sour. Chicken biriyani was passable. Maybe, they are trying to meet the tourist's expectation of Indian food, but I can't consider it as good Indian food.
author: Anup K.

description:
OM-GOODNESS! :0) Back to INDIAN food! I love it! I know CURRY isn't the healthiest thing to eat, but sometimes you just have to say, "WHAT THE HECK!" 

This place may not be fancy, you also need to grab your own plates and utensils, but it's totally worth it. I don't mind getting up and serving myself at times because that's a few extra calories being burned!!! whoohoo! 

The must haves:

Aloo Ghobi-Cauliflower and potatoes cooked with herbs and spices. (Cauliflower and potatoes? Sounds bland, but they know how to spice it up and make you say YUM YUM!)

Aloo Naan-Naan Stuffed with Potatoes (First time trying Naan with stuffed potatoes! It was good, but I'd prefer the Naan below this one.)

Garlic Naan-Naan topped with Garlic and Cilantro. (I can never get enough of Naan.)

Chicken Boti- Chicken cubes marinated in spices and cooked in clay oven. (Dipped in Curry Sauce, mmhhmm so satisfying.)

You can't order all this without the Chicken or the Shrimp with Curry. The Curry absolutely completes the whole meal :) Now, after you're done with the meal, go for a jog around the block, and come back for more!
author: Sweet P.

description: Superb! Went with 3 others and we got an absolute feast for $50. The tandoori meats were spicy and succulent and the veggie curries were all excellent, especially the okra. Not much else to say, other than that I'm very pleased to now have a go-to curry spot for future visits to SF.
author: Andy W.

description:
Chutney is my favorite Indian restaurant in the city.  I know that as a Caucasian that has never been to India I have no idea if this is authentic or not. However, I do know that this is my favorite chicken tikka masala in the city (it's super rich and creamy) and that even though Chutney located in the heart of the tenderloin there is no better place for cheap Indian food.

I was there last Thursday night for dinner with a friend who had never been before.  We had lamb saag, chicken tikka masala, aloo gobi and two pieces of garlic na'an (cost w/ tip $28).  He was impressed and we both left very satisfied.


Bonus: Bourbon & Branch is next door. Grab some food at Chutney and then go enjoy some wonderful, old school libations (reservations at B&B required).
author: Lara O.

description: Cleaner than Shalimar and has chicken and lamb vindaloo which I love.  Other than that though think Shalimar has better tandoori and tikki masala.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
I only got takeout.  Service was friendly and fast. 

However i found the meal not that awesome, not bad. Just i wouldn't rave about it.  The sauce was severely watered down, and i do know it has bones in it but it was mostly bones. 

Yeah i know its cheap, but I would eat Indian regularly back home for around the same price but the quality leaves this place for dead.
author: Monica C.

description:
OMG! How could I forget to update my review! I came back a few weeks ago and was eating my favorite chicken tiki masala with my naans! And out the corner of my eye I saw a BIG RAT climb down the corner of a pipe in the restaurant! I was being a kid and screamed and pointed!!! OMG IT WAS SO GROSSSSSSSSSS! But people kept eating after that...LOL 

But definitely downgraded my starsss no no no rats in restaurant please!
author: Alice Z.

description:
I couldn't figure out why people love this place.  I ordered a palak paneer which was really sub-par.  The paneer tasted like it came from frozen, not fresh.  The spinach tasted like it had nothing but ghee in it.  Overall, very bland.  I only ate about 1/3 of the dish and walked away with a slight tummy ache.

Also the ordering/paying system seems really inefficient.  You order at the counter, then sit down, then bring your number to the same counter person to pay.  He's taking orders and taking credit cards at the same time.  He somehow manages, but I'm sure a lot of errors are made this way.
author: Socheata P.

description: YUM. This place was so good, and is great when you want to get a casual bite to eat with friends (this isn't a place to woo your lady).. Got chicken tikka, some meat thing and rice. Yummy. You walk up and order, then take your number and find your own table. It was packed when I went but we found a table ok. They bring out your food and then you pay at the counter at the end. Lacked some ambiance and some customer service....but the food and prices made it worth it. Will definitely be returning.
author: Katrina F.

description: Cheap and delicious. However we needed to wait a little long cuz this restaurant is popular. They served vegetable while we waited. Except this, I like this restaurant! Nan and lam curry is good:)))
author: Natsumi O.

description: Love love love this place!!!! The food is so yum! and being a Pakistani, I know when its made well! The Lamb Biryani is to die for! I make special trips to SFO to come to this place and if I am in the mood for some Indian/Pakistani food I refuse to go anywhere but here!!! Service is not so good but they are really busy and food is awesome so I live with it. Recommend for sure!
author: Zee A.

description: I live SO close to here and yet Ive only ordered from here once, Ive never sat down in there to eat. But today ive decided to order something from them in years...the Lamb Wrap -- delish!!!! When I took the first bite i was like WOW but BECAREFUL it is spicy...I never knew it was spicy til I started chewing. Yummy goodness I would REALLY recommend along with the Mango Lassi it was sweet and tasty! THUMBS UPPERS!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
My friend was more nutty about this place than I was -- you never saw a person get so excited about a plate of Chicken Tikka! -- but it's still a great place for a Monday night nosh, if Lahore Karahi is closed (which it is).
You guys already know how one-dollar naans make me feel all warm and lovey inside.
author: Lisa T.

description:
FOOD/DRINK
1.) Chicken tikka masala = yummyyyy
2.) benghan bharta with naan = This was really good 
3.) free milk tea! = self serve house milk tea with side of sugar for you to stir in yourself



SERVICE:
You order, but come back up to pay after you eat. Which is kind of odd. How do they keep track of everyone? Order at counter, take a number ... 


ATMOSPHERE:
Very casual, very basic, I guess Indian fast food-ish haha.
author: Angela L.

description:
I agree with fellow Yelpers that this place is one of the nicer Pak-Loin joints but I'm still loyal to Shalimar across the street.  For one thing the chicken boti is better at Shalimar.

However, I definitely recommend the nihari -- extremely tender pieces of beef that has been cooked for hours and served in a spicy stew. Unfortunately this dish is a special so it's not always available on the menu but if it is, then you have to try it!
author: Helen Y.

description: Terrible. Location is very shady with lots of homeless people around. Place was unhygienic and food was not good. Avoid completely if you are looking for good Indian food
author: Vivek S.

description:
Chicken vindaloo and naan! Yes
A few grad students and I have made this our go-to stop after late classes and we just want some pipin hot indian food.

There is plenty of seating and the service is pretty fast. They have great tea and coffee as well. I'm a big fan of the mango lassi. :)

The tikka masala is rich and creamy with just enough spice for that "kick". The chicken vindaloo is hot and spicey just how I like it- I usually ask them to make it "super hot" for me.
You can't go wrong with the biryani and the garlic naan is amazing!
author: Amanda S.

description: The chicken tikka masala was tasty and as described: dry-fired chicken (tandoori-like) with a lot of creamy sauce. I'd order it again. The eggplant wasn't stellar and I'd avoid that.
author: Kevin V.

description:
What is there to say that hasn't been said? 

Chicken tikka is addictive... naan is pretty good... everything else is so-so. 

The chicken tikka, even, is clearly watered down- some visits more than others. But it still has a taste that's hard to beat. We keep going there, so it must be pretty good :)
author: A K.

description:
Chutney's exterior looks a bit shady (situated in the Tenderloin) but its interior is a stark contrast and inviting. We thought we made out like bandits with dinner for less than $20 in SF. Nope, their prices are very budget friendly.

If you like Indian and/or Pakistani food, almost everything is safe here. "This is as good as it gets regarding authenticity" is how a Middle Eastern friend of mine put it. I will trust him since he is a food snob.

yum yum, nom nom nom
author: Tony N.

description: One of my first experience on Indian food a la carte. The price is decent, dish portion is small. The naan was very fresh and good. The chicken tiki Masala sauce was delicious, the chicken was a bit dry. Place a little bit messy maybe influence by location. The mango lassi was good in right amount of sweetness and texture, highly recommended.
author: Z G.

description:
My favorite Tenderloin Indian place. Fantastic naan, awesome tikka masala , and great mango lassi. The palak paneer was also really good, though the tofu was a little chewy. I also had an eggplant vegetarian curry that started with "b", and it was fantastic as well.

The highlight of this place is the naan. It's crispy, fluffy, large, and delicious.

This place is also the most aesthetically pleasing of all the local Indian restaurants.
author: Ned D.

description: So good! My first time there. I can't believe I haven't been there after all this time. Prices are so reasonable and location is great - super close to downtown. After eating Chutney, I'm never going back to Naan and Curry again. It's even cheaper (I think) at Chutney than Naan and Curry. Plus, the portions are bigger and it's so much more delicious! We got the chicken tikki masala, lamb curry, chicken byriani and 3 naan for 3 people and we still had leftovers! MMMM! It'll definitely be my new go to for Indian food!! xoxo
author: Sharon G.

description: After seeing a cockroach in my Tikki Masala dish I was sick to my stomach . I will not return .
author: Jennie M.

description:
TASTY TASTY TASTY

everything was good.

we had the beef kafta, chicken kabob chunks aka BOTI and the lamb boti.

the quality of the food was off the charts. The service was good too.
sorta.

we went there on a rainy sat night.here are the reason why this only got three starts.

1. its in the tenderloin...really.get a new location i dont wanna die trying to eat some kabobs( even tho they are good..not worth dying for)
2. They messed up our order. After getting to the restuarant..which felt like WAR because it was raining and there was three kids along with a "almost" freak accident they gave us the opposite of what we ordered.

hella annoying

but we ended up going back on sun and got all we wanted.

in the end the food is tasty...CHECK your order before you leave!
author: Fatte N.

description:
I was in San Francisco on a business conference and didn't want to have crappy buffet food one particular night for dinner. Walked from my Union Station hotel with a coworker, picked up a Lagunitas IPA 6 pack from the liquor store, and made our way to the bum infested Tenderloin. This place was large, dirty, packed with people, but our noses confirmed this was the oasis we had been looking for

We ordered the chicken tikka masala, chicken vindaloo, lamb briyani, and garlic naan at the counter and took a seat. We must have waited until the end of the world but finally our food arrived. The vindaloo was extremely flavorful and had the perfect amount of spice. My favorite dish, the lamb slipped right off the bone in the briyani. Naan perfectly complimented the soupy tikka masala and there was none to be found by the end of the meal.

Indian food done right and cheap. No frills. It's better that way.
author: James B.

description: This is a great restaurant.   The Naan is amazing.  They are nice, clean and quick.  Nice prices too.  They are famous for their chicken Tikka massala.  Addictive.   I love their chicken sausage too.  I haven't completed the menu yet but I'm trying. ..
author: pilou o.

description:
The best Tandoori Llamb Chops I ever tried! You won't be disappointment if you will order this delicious dish.

We got Prawn Tiki Masala -- prawns were a little bit too chewy, but the curry was awesome! 

And special dish -- Tandoori Fish, which we figured out was silver carp -- sweet and tender river fish.

My fiancee run to the liqueur store across the street and picked up 6pack for us, which completed our dinner and we kept it under $50. (beer was $12 -- so get it in a different place)

P.S. They do have the nicest busboy serivce!
author: Anelya S.

description:
this is by far the best Pakistan food restaurant thatt i've been to. 

my family and I started to eat Pakistan food at Shalimar across the street until Chutney opened up and we tried it once. After the first try, we were deciding if we wanted to switch since we been eating at Shalimar for years... and we DID! the food is MUCHHH cheaper and SOO MUCH BETTER after the second time we tried it and finally decided leave Shalimar for good. 

Our usual plates includes:
Chicken Masala: a red/orange curry with about 5 chicken breast chunks in it. it has a sweeter taste to it compared tot he other rich spicy taste of the other curries. very good.

eggplant curry: chopped up eggplant pieces. its a thick curry and also with a sweeter spice taste. this is my all time favorite thing to order whenever i am eating indian food.

chicken curry: its self explanatory. spicy and yummy. 

lamb curry: also another spicy curry dish. 

goat curry: this is their weekend special and its soo good that we order 3 of this dish so noone fights over the goat pieces. 

spinah & potato curry: another self explanatory dish. the potato is so soft in this dish and calms down the spicy spice taste of the curry. 

charboiled chicken breast: another all time favorite dish. the chicken is charbroiled nicely on the outside and the chcken is still soft and moist on the inside. we also order the chicken leg as well which is again, very yummy. 

lambchops: another charbroiled meat dish. the pieces are really thick and juicy. spicyyyyy though.

we order a bunch more other dish but these are the usuals and everyone should try.. everything is eaten with NAAN (their authentic circular bread) and also RICE. without the naan and rice, these dishes cannot be eaten. it just goes 1 on 1 with each other. 

the prices is awesome and we usually pay around 60-70 bucks for a table of 7=8 people. we usually order about 5 curry dishes, a meat dish and naan and rice so thats a pretty good deal. 

but remember to tip the person that brings you your food so u can get better service ;)
author: Linda N.

description:
I don't even want to know the real name of this place. I didn't remember it until I found the listing here on Yelp, and I plan to promptly forget when I'm done writing this review. The only way I have ever and will ever refer to it is "the best tikka masala ever." 

I moved to SF last week and have been exploring the food options near my new apartment. I stumbled across The Best Tikka Masala Ever late one night after parking my car nearby on Jones Street. It was meant to be. 

While I'm sure there are other fabulous items on the menu, all you need is one order of chicken tikka masala, a side of rice, and a mango lassi. Your soul will be reborn in the tenderness of chicken and imbued with a grander sense of purpose by the sweetness of the sauce. I don't even really know what that means, but I'm sure you get the idea.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Great Indian restaurant. The food is prepared fresh, quick and there is plenty of seating inside the restaurant. I usually try their chicken dishes and I love it. 

We also go there for team lunches from my office. There is plenty of dishes for vegetarians as well.
author: Andrew B.

description:
****UPDATE on 12/12/10*****
If you read my review below you will hear me complain about "spices" being in my food. Well I went back to my fav place, Lahore Karahi and they too have the same set of seeds and cinnamon stick spices, but the difference is that they are not broken up in the rice. So, I was ignorant in my review below on some levels and changed my rating from a 1 to a 3, because the food at Chutney was good, but the service sucked and the broken up sticks of wood were in bad form. But now I know, that those seasonings are typical and etc. etc.

So, there.

***********************************

Bad Review ahead...

Me and my girlfriend went here after taking in West Side Story during the day. Lahore Karahi was closed for Halloween partying I'm guessing, so we stood in front of this place and the restaurant across the street from it trying to decide. We went with this one because it appeared to be better than the other visually. 

When we went in we ordered at the counter and sat down. The tables were dirty and food was on the chairs. I know that sometimes bussers will wipe off tables and food goes on the chairs, so no big whoop, but figured I'd mention the messy display.

Then we were brought the weird plate of crappy iceburg lettuce and vegetables that were not appealing. 

We ordered Veggie Korma, Veggie Biryani, Chana Masala and Garlic Naan.

We got up and grabbed our own drinks and the server brought us a pitcher of water and glasses.

First, let me say that everything TASTED just fine. Actually pretty good, even the Naan.

We began to eat and after a few bites into my Biryani I bit something hard and nearly broke a tooth. I stopped chewing, started getting really freaked out, not knowing what was now in my mouth. I tried to be as casual as I could in spitting it into my hand and placing it on my table for examination. After I put it  on the corner of my plate to examine it, it appeared to be a piece of wood. I cleaned it off well with my napkin and it was. Almost like a popsicle stick shard of some sort, but it was darker in color. Then I broke it in half, just to confirm, IT WAS WOOD. Not some spice or something that I was misunderstanding.

At that point I was shellshocked. I began to examine the plate of Biryani more closely. I found more pieces of weird wood chips. My girlfriend suggested maybe they were spices, I pondered that idea, but thought it would be weird to leave such a thing in food and allow your customer the potential to get stabbed by the wood or damage their teeth. 

I continued to dig. 

I then found 2 very large seeds. I would say that they were near the size of a peach seed, but smaller, but larger thn an apricot seed. This seed was definitely covered in some sort of spices or something, it was very dark and gooey. I picked those out. Then I noticed in the mix of rice and veggies there were a large amount of whole cloves. Hard cloves, not soft and cooked like on a ham, these were straight up hard and unpleasant. 

I was flipping out in my head, so I called over the waiter and asked him what that stuff was, he looked at me and barely even gave it a thought and said "Spices" and just walked away without allowing anymore discussion. 

I'm never going here again. I'm sad I tried this place and realize now that I'll just stick with Lahore Karahi when I get an itch for some legit Pakistani/Indian food.
author: Mack L.

description:
This place may be in a sketch sketch sketchy neighborhood but it's worth it to walk the sidewalks amongst the crackheads to get to this food.

Have been here a number of times after shows at the Golden Gate and it's a doable walk distance wise, there's just the above-mentioned crackhead element.

Terrible acoustics and their bathrooms are super tiny and kinda gross but again, worth it for the food.

Everything I've ordered has come out fast and piping hot (not from a microwave, you can see the guys back there slinging this stuff on the stove) and utterly delicious from butter chicken to palak paneer and the naan, my God the naan! Never order enough of it, always want more, especially to mop up all the leftover sauce after you eat up all the rice.

Brave the crackheads and go here.
author: Christine K.

description:
Do you like salt?  A LOT of salt?  Is Dead Sea water your preferred refreshing beverage?  Do you fight with the local herd of deer for your spot at a salt lick?  Chutney's chicken biryani will still be too salty for you.

Oh, and don't forget the chunks of rock hard, inedible anise scattered throughout the dish.  It's pure joy to pick those out of your teeth after every single bite.

Chicken Tikka Masala was passable, but the portion was surprisingly small, and rice/naan are not included.  The dish was quite heavy on the cream.  It's hard to make something taste bad with that much fat.
author: Carlin E.

description:
I am not surprise that Chutney is in the 'Loin, I just don't feel comfortable walking alone in the area.  Umm, I don't know.  I feel like all the good food is always in the 'Loin, where I don't go often. 

I had to go to a volunteer place today in Tenderloin, and my sister was dying for some Indian food.  I let her choose the place and two friends meet up to go.  The environment was pretty nice in the restaurant.  We order three different curries, chicken, lamb, and cheese.  They are all so good.  Not too spicy and the cheese one is actually very sweet.  You get free tea.  The tea is milk tea which makes this experience even better.  The naan was huge and only a dollar.  The staffs were so friendly!  Everything was very spectacular. We all walked out with full stomaches and love it.

Will definitely come back to try other dishes!!
author: Lily L.

description:
I've been here quite a few times, and I've actually really enjoyed it everytime...
great food at a great price i could spend the whole day in here and eat..
the Chicken Tikka Masala is amazing... def gotta try it..

service was quick and food was nice and hot when it got to the table..

i would recommend this place to anyone who is looking for great Indian food!
author: Marty C.

description:
i'm not a huge indian foody since it gives me upset tummyaches. 
BUT,  judging by a lessened tummy ache, this place gets my seal of approval :)

Been here just once, but i'm a fan of this place over Naan & curry.
their courtesy appetizer salad you have to try their green/or red dressing... mmmmm!  
-had a beef skewer... it was alright, but the sight was unappetizing (looked like a log of poo crowned with lemon slices ... so so wrong ... ) 
+their naan is much more softer and tastier than naan & curry's. 
+their prices are also more affordable at $5-$8 for curries.
-park close, im sure you would wet your willies walking (RUNNING) through this crackhead neighborhood

Thanks Chutney, you are my new favorite  indian restaurant  =)
author: Miss J.

description:
Food was good (also I was super hungry)...ordered chicken tikka masala, naan and rice. Curry was good. Naan was very good. Rice was decent. 

However, I will not come back to this place due to slow service (I rather get it to go).  

Food - 3.5
Service -2.5

Total: 3 stars
author: Ji K.

description:
Got a call to meet from friends here today. We were in town for a conference, and I'd so much liked the food in this area that I headed over here quickly. The staff quickly and eagerly greeted and accomodated the 10 of us without a problem, and then brought water all around.

They gave us all menus, but then they made us come to the counter to order. They also would not let us pay until we were done, which was strange because we all stood in line to order than later all stood in line again to pay for our dinners. That was odd for me. That gets a 2.5 or 3, BUT...

The food was everything I expected, which bumped it to a 4-star for me. I enjoy Chicken Boti wherever I go, and this was, once again, awesome. Very good, but don't forget to order rice because it does not come with anything.
author: Devon A.

description:
This is my favorite Indian restaurant in the city. Their vegetable dish is all good, so as fantastic chicken with yummy sauce.
The food is pretty spicy, so watch out!!
author: Yoko S.

description: Great Indian food in the city. Not oily at all and it's fairly cheap. Delivery options are not great though :(
author: Vatsal S.

description:
We found this place from a recommendation by our cab driver when we arrived in San Francisco.  When the rain started falling just around lunch time, we ducked into Chutney for a quick bite and a place to wait out the weather, and we were quite pleased.  The service is fast-food fast, but the quality of the food is far above.

When you go in, you order at the counter and are given a number for your order - menus are at the counter, and then you can sit at any table.  We sat down and waited only a few minutes (during which time they brought us water - including a pitcher for us to refill our drinks on our own - and a little salad plate to split) for the food to arrive.  Very prompt service, and the staff was all friendly as well.

I'm not quite sure what makes an Indian/Pakistani restaurant different from a regular Indian restaurant, but the difference in the food here compared to other Indian places we've gone was mainly in the texture of the sauce.  I got the mattar paneer, and my husband got the goat curry, and both sauces were thinner than we usually see with these dishes.  Honestly, I think I prefer the thicker sauces, but these were not quite as heavy, so we didn't leave the restaurant feeling overly full. Also, we didn't get to specify the spiciness of the dishes, and mine wound up being quite mild, while my husband's was pretty spicy.  The mattar paneer had tomatoes in the sauce, which I haven't seen before.

Since we wanted to be able to do a fair comparison of the place, we got their vegetable samosas, and they were great.  Crispy outside, thick filling, and perfect with the tamarind sauce.  We also got garlic naan, which was huge and delicious.  Tons of garlic flavor, so I was sold.

I liked the fact that the portions were more manageable than a lot of Indian restaurants, since we're staying at a hotel and couldn't really bring back leftovers.  And you can beat the prices here: two entrees, bread, and samosas were less than $25.  I would also imagine this would be a good place for takeout, especially if you were in a rush.

I did find it a little weird to go back up to the counter after we finished eating (you pay at the end of your meal at the same place you ordered), and the area of town is a little sketchy depending on the time of day, but overall, we were glad we checked it out!
author: Jenn T.

description:
This place is good for a quick sit down dinner. You get in line and order, they bring your food out quite quickly, while you wait get some water and free Chai Tea, when you are stuffed head up to the cashier and pay your bill. 

Yeah, the ordering and paying part sounds kinda chaotic, because it kind of is, but its nothing much to complain about when you're only paying about $7 for a curry dish. Also, $1 Naan? That is totally awesome; makes me want to buy 2 just cause its such a good deal. Their Garlic Naan is also incredibly delicious. I would definitely come back for their Chicken Tikka Masala. However, I would pass on the Lamb Vindaloo next time. 

Thanks Chutney for being fast, conveniently located, and delicious!
author: Lisa T.

description:
The quantity of food is "a lottt" but the quality is just meh. 
It's cheap but you have to wait for a long time to get your food.
Their water tastes like plastic for some reason. Their naan is really good though.
author: Farid F.

description:
Do yourself a favor and dont order all the normal stuff you see in Indian restaurants on the menu. I grew up in Delhi and these guys do a goat curry, just as good, if not better than many places in Old Delhi (where the dish originates). Based on this, I imagine the Nihari - which is a very traditional dish of Delhi - which they do not have on the menu everyday will be just as good. Other things that I had that were good, but not exceptional, were the lamb seekh kebabs and the tandoori fish. 

The goat curry alone will keep me coming back again and again. Hope they have the Nihari when I am there next!
author: Joe V.

description: My boss decided to take me here one friday. Alright, so I have never really eaten Indian food but I decided to try it. I think  this place was Gyoood! We ordered the lamb kabob, chicken bbq, Tikka Masala and naan. I loved it. I am definitely recommending this to my friends.
author: Francis J.

description: So freaking delicious! I had chicken masala, the spinach dish that I can never remember the name of, rice and naan with cheese - all were made perfect and super tasty. They have free hot chai tea you can enjoy after your meal. The staff was friendly and they were all smiling and seem happy to work there. I will for sure return to this restaurant during my next visit to SF!
author: Baciula L.

description:
My wife and I ate here for lunch today and really liked it. We had three dishes, naan, and rice. The bengan bharta (smoky eggplant) was the absolute best version of this I've ever had. Creamy, smoky, no astringent eggplant aftertaste. Just delicious.
