And actually, I don't love hanging out on shit corners of the loin and am really thankful that I have a toothbrush and cable TV.

Admittedly, my Tandori chicken salad was extremely tasty.  According to my companion his lamb wrap was worth the wait.  (Which I'm not kidding was over a half hour).  So I am going to be nice and still give them three stars, and make a mental note that I have time to score some crack and get a reasonably priced Thai "massage" while waiting for lamb to cook because they obviously have thicker flesh than other animals.
author: Starla D.

description:
Walking into this place gave me a flashback to Berkeley--Curry house and N'aan and Curry--and that's exactly what this restaurant was, another "curry house" and "n'aan and curry." Ok, maybe not, since Chutney featured some Pakistani dishes.

Me and two other friends noticed how packed the spacious restaurant was and wondered if we should grab a table before we got in line to order. We were stopped and was told we'll be seated. That was different, like weird mix of self serve and not. Do you tip in these cases??

My friend and I ordered our usual, Tiki Marsala with Onion Naan. There was a good 5 minute interval between the two dishes coming out. One dish got colder and the other dish was luke warm, and this was visually apparent since the surface of the sauce got a deeper orange color. I dont think I've seen two of the same dish come out separately like that. It can mean one dish hit bottom of the pan, but if so, why isnt the 2nd dish blazing hot then? Idno.

As far as quality, the chicken was a little dry, but I dont remember any of my other Tiki Marsala experience featuring moist chicken. Naan was alright.

Didnt think this was worth a bus ride from SOMA to the TL.
author: Rena Y.

description:
Star #1: Convenient location for planning an evening out in this part of the TL. Several fine drinking establishments nearby. There are two courses of action one can take: Drink first and load up on the Chutney goodness afterwards, or make a food cushion and then pile on the drinks. 

My most recent visit, we opted for the food cushion.

Star #2: Walked in, surveyed the surroundings, and randomly picked a table to sit and wait for my companions. Prompt service - silverware, plates, water, strange-looking salad of tomatoes, lettuce, and lemon, and menus were brought to the table. Throughout the meal, additional silverware and water was provided upon request.

Star #3: I took Adam W's review into consideration and ordered the Bengan Bharta [smoked eggplant with onions, tomatoes, and spices]. Delicious with the perfect amount of spice! Goes superbly with a garlic naan [or any naan, for that matter]. The price must have increased on the dish though - it's now $5.99. Everything's around that price range and not too expensive, which is fantastic because you can then spend your hard-earned $ on delicious drinks nearby. 

The menu plays well with my adventurous side. If one examines the section of the menu titled "Ask About Our Daily Specials," one would notice an item called Brain Masala - brain of male goat cooked with special herbs!  [http://flickr.com/photos/suki/2361957667/] o.O I love daily specials.
author: Tinna H.

description:
So after trying some more Indian restaurants in SF, I think Chutney is ok. I've tried Alhamra (3 stars) and Pakwan (3.5 stars) in the Mission. Comparing to those places, the chicken breast in the Chicken Tikka Masala at Chutney is a little dry and the sauce does not have any kick to it.

Though, I still love the mango lassi at Chutney. They have the most generous portion for it and I think the best flavor, so it's totally worth ordering it there.
author: Angela H.

description:
This is the best Indian food I've ever eaten.

I had Bengan Bharta (smoked eggplant w/ onions, tomatoes & spice) for the first time here. They say you'll always remember you first time and it remains the best Bengan Bharta ($5) I've had & same goes for the Chicken Tikka Masala ($6).

Very affordable prices; you can get ample amounts of food (eat Bengan Bharta) for two people for well under $20.

Blow out of Bourbon & Branch & chow on the best Bengan Bharta.
author: Adam W.

description: I ordered food over the phone and t was ready in timely matter. The Chicken Boti was a bit dry and Chicken Tikka Masala was a bit watery and creamy. I will try to find a different place.
author: Magda G.

description: Really tasty!! I've been here many times. Food is really good and not expensive. The only thing which is not that good is the environment. It's always very loud.
author: aaron y.

description: So I was in SF for a few days and on a recommendation from the hotel bartender for some great local chow I checked this place out. Don't go for the atmosphere or decor just great food and the prices are really cheap.
author: Rak P.

description: This is my favorite restaurant ever. I wish to eat there every week, but I have to drive if so. Food always the same taste, as expected, and clean, I always request well done for the chicken booty. The Masala dish is good too. prices are very cheap. And the meat/chicken is Halal.
author: Mohamad E.

description:
Our mind is bombarded by millions of sensory stimuli every day. If the mind has to react (and think about) all these zillions of stimulus, it would go (even more) crazy. Hence, it creates categories of structures, models and stereotypes, in order to manage its information overload. However, creating mental categories is making a pact with the devil since over a period of time, they become ossified and we become close minded. Hence, we need to reflect upon and keep changing out mental categories.

Now what has categories to do with Chutney? I have been wanting to categorize Indian restaurants in SF and have come up with the following three categories:

1Cheap eats(North Indian/Pakistani): In this category, Chutney is the clear winner.

2 Fine dining(North Indian/Pakistani): In this category, Rootee(review to follow) is the winner.

3. Fine dining( non North Indian/Pakistani): Dosa(review to follow)is the winner in this category.

In its genre of cheap Indian/Pakistani food in SF, Chutney rules supreme. It is much cleaner than Shalimar and the quality of the food is better and more consistent that Nan and Curry. Whatever attributes you can come up with(quality,cleanliness,service etc)for this category, Chutney will rank in the top 2 everytime.
author: Kaustav C.

description:
I think I'm in love with one of the exotic beauties painted on the wall at Chutney.  She's dark and voluptuous and I want to know her deepest desires.

I think I'm in love with drunken naan and tikka masala fests.

I think I'm dumb.

I went here with a pakistani family once.  My friend Mirza had daughters who looked like the girl on the wall.  Maybe even better, because they talked pretty.  I wanted to marry both of them but I knew he'd have to kill me a thousand times with a thousand knives if I did.  

I'm still single.  

Maybe I'll get married at Chutney next time I go there.  

What the hell am I talking about?  I'm talking about good cheap pakistani food, open 'til 12.
author: chris o.

description:
I don't think I have an especially advanced palate for Indian food, but I know what I like, and I think Chutney is just okay. I wanted to go to Lahore Karahi but I had a temporary moment of ditziness and forgot exactly where it was, not to mention that I woke up from my ipod & recent cody's purchase high and realized : "Damn. I am in a BAD neighborhood" so I wasn't about to pull out my cell phone and google text for the address (yes, I know how close I was so do not even think about just a note-ing me, losers). 

Shalimar was crowded and cash only and thus : Chutney. I appreciate the relative cleanliness & wonderful, clearly fresh baked naan but the chicken tikka masala wasn't spicy enough for me and was kind of like eating chicken in tomato soup.  Raita was also, just okay and raita is totally what makes the meal for me so that was a little upsetting.  You know, I'd come back but you better be paying or really, really cute and with intentions to make out.
author: Maria D.

description: It would have no Stars if I had the choice. My husband and I used to eat here a ton until recently when we saw something crawling on the wall that usually only comes out at night. A big one. Bye Bye Chutney. : (
author: lisa v.

description:
when it comes to quality and value, this is easily my favorite place to eat in the bay area.  Not sure why its taken me this long to yelp the place, I guess i haven't been in the mood to review anything lately.

I eat here at least once a week, sometimes twice.  I tried changing up what I got from time to time, and it was all good, but I kept coming back to the lamb boti so now I just stick with what works.


My girlfriend gets their chicken tikka masala, which she claims is the best she's ever had. Most people who eat there seem to agree with her.
I think its great, but personally I don't think there's enough meat.
I'm back to the Lamb boti each and every time now.  Its fantastic, plenty of lamb pieces, and the onions are absolutely grilled to perfection.
I will add however that its just the lamb pieces, with the grilled onions so its a very dry dish(i highly suggest draining the lemon over it).  I tried getting different curry sauces to add, but since the chicken tikka masala sauce is so good, now I just get a side of that and add a little.
Get the sauce on the side without mentioning that you want it for the boti.  I tried asking them to mix it a few times, they seemed to get confused..

Next comes the garlic Naan which also has cilantro. They're pretty big but we always get 2.  Taste amazing dipped in the masala sauce or:

Bengan Bharta(it sounds more fun when you say it with an accent). This stuff is fantastic(if you like mesquite smoked eggplant cooked with onions, tomatoes and spices) Hmmmm, too good.

We finish the order off with 2 rice.  
Mix the sauce over the rice, add meat, dip naan from time to time, add some bengan bharta and you've got a killer meal all for around $35

I love eating there(they don't charge a corking fee so feel free to bring in wine, or walk in with a 12 pack of beer. they've got a great hot tea for free also, taste a little like chai) but i feel like i get more food in my to go order, plus they put it in nice plastic dishes that you can reuse.
Either way you have to drive into the Tenderloin briefly, which is always good for the soul!
author: Ryan M.

description:
No matter what restaurant i go to, I always seem to lack the ability to order food, except at Chutney's! 

This place is fantastic, whenever i do go in there i feel as if I'm at home, with the great cultural frames and saltry hindi music, brings out everybody's inner Ghandi haha. The outside environment is horrible, cracked out, just like it's reputation, but the food is delicious!! 

The "Chicken Thicka Masala" is my favorite and so is the "Chicken Biryani."

The best part about it all, is that the prices are so reasonable, you'll eat good and go home and take a massive dump. I highly recommend it people.
author: Sani S.

description:
Good, fast, and cheap! 

If you want to get your indian fix this is a solid place to go. Almost every dish is under $10, your food comes out within 5-8 minutes of ordering (although you order at the cashier), the food is tasty, there's ample seating, and they have a nice variety of food that's sure to please everyone in a large group.
author: Richard K.

description:
Huge fan, maybe not quiiite 5 stars.

The Chicken Tikka Masala is pretty amazing and a must have anytime we're here. I also go for the Chana, some rice, and garlic Naan for the win. If anyone can explain how they can possibly get the free Chai as hot as they do, you'll be my hero for life, as I've burned myself on many occasions and think we could possibly use that heat source as a national power reserve. 

Oh, and to all the haters who say the neighborhood is too "sketch", live a little! I'm sure you watch No reservations and think the places Bourdain goes to are amazing, well he would get his Indian from Chutney if he lived in sf so you should too!
author: Patrick K.

description:
Chutney is your typical Indian food establishment: order up-front, take any open table, watch them make your food, and wait to be served. On busy nights, you might have to wait a while, but you will not be disappointed. 

Indian classics such as Chicken Tikka Masala, Garlic Naan, and Mango Lassi are always available and delicious as ever. The Chicken Tikka Masala was perhaps too sweet for my taste on my most recent visit but the saffron-spiced rice helped balance the meal out. 

Chutney is a comfortable place to take family and have a satiating meal. While you should expect a long wait during weekend evenings, you will ultimately be satisfied by their simple, affordable, and authentic approach to Indian food.
author: Seth F.

description:
This place is awesome!  Food for 2 = under $20!  Great service, fresh taste and authentic.  First you order, eat then pay up front.
Don't forget to try the green hot sauce and the FREE Chai tea!

Parking can be a pain, but its worth it!
Also, O'ferrall street can be a bit seedy...
author: Hesam E.

description: Horrible service. We watched the cashier over charge a couple $10. My food had a hair in it. Not very sanitary at all. All around a shady place.
author: Krista M.

description:
My recent increase in gastronomical smugness requires for me to make an update to some of my reviews.

Still like it, but have found that their tikka masala can be inconsistent. Sometimes too ketchupy (catsuppy? ketchuppy?). Also, I seem to remember that their palak paneer was much less...blendered than it was when we went a couple of years ago...

Must try more restaurants in order to properly gauge the true starworthiness of this place.
author: Ruth C.

description:
I feel like I give Indian places a tough time on Yelp so I was so excited when I had a tasty and affordable meal here tonight. This is a solid choice to go soak up your booozed self after a few rounds at B&B next door.

Walk on up to the counter, super patient as we scan the menu. 2 entrees, 2 flavored naan's, they help us find the only free table in the joint, and give us a number. Later on we get water and a plate with iceburg lettuce, onions, tomatoes and lemons. I'm hungry so I decide it's my salad and dig in avoiding the onions.

Ah, the tikka masala sauce. Rich and tomatoey with a wonderful heat to it. It was like eating the most delicious cream of tomato soup ever. I was seriously having to refrain myself from licking the plate. We also ordered another curry of some sort that had a nice sweetness and all spiceish flavor. Both the Naan's were hot, a little crispy on the outside and nice and doughey on the inside. Mmmm, a perfect meal for a cool Autumn evening.

Satisfied but not stuffed we return to the counter to pay. Under 20 dollars! I was thrilled. So satisfying and good deal to boot. I want to try a few more plates, if they all add up we're in 5 star land.

Friendly, festive atmosphere. Totally packed with everyone having a great time.

I also gotta say this is not the sketchy part of the TL - it's more tender nob if anything. Walk a few blocks South and sure, it's rough after 9 but it is totally safe there.
author: Allegra F.

description:
Thanks a lot, Yelp. Because of you, places like Chutney have lost any sense of humility. Once word is out that a place kicks ass (see: 4 star average or higher after 200+ reviews), you can almost guarantee a certain level of snobbishness. Maybe the employees here are jaded from being in this part of town too long, fending off tranny hooker syringe fiends; or maybe they know it ain't their cheerful service that keeps customers wanting more. Either way, your attitude stinks like the homeless tranquilized cat I tripped over on the way in! A bit of advice to newbies...

I've never been to a place where you order at a counter, take a number to a table of your choice, have a waiter bring your food, eat, wait, drink some water, wait, then realize your check isn't coming anytime soon. You sit there clueless, wondering how/when/where to pay. Whaaa? I have to take my number back to the counter, where I ordered, and pay after I eat? Do I tip? Who and where? Is this some kind of test?

You better know the routine before stepping inside because you will get no help from the help. No sir, nuh-uh, not in the Tenderloin. Follow procedure or I will bust a cap in your Tikka Masala loving ass! Foo!

Mmm... speaking of Tikka Masala... oh my! Just like Grandma used to make.* I would pass on the smoked eggplant dish next time - too spicy and mushy. Garlic Naan for a buck, nothin' wrong with that!

Don't walk, RUN to Chutney. Delish Indian/Pakistani/Halal food (whatever the crap Halal is??) at an unbeatable price. It is perfectly Tenderloinesque, with an even balance of sidewalk crackies, little to no eye contact with strangers, and lost, frightened Union Square tourists.



*I am totally podunk. The closest Grandma ever came to Tikka Masala was a Sloppy Joe.
author: Valerie N.

description: I really can't think how this place got a four star review with 700 something reviews, and that too in SF with so many authentic Indian/ Pakistani cuisine places!!!!! It was my first visit to SF and I arrived late from the airport, and we decided to try this place as it was open late. The place was crowded even though it was near closing time. We thought that we had found a gem and were very happy thinking about all the delicious Indian food we would eat ( I come from Seattle, where good Indian food is rare)...We ordered the biriyani and some naan and curry(which I dont even remember). We were waiting in the restaurant for our order when my husband thought he spotted a RAT....I thought he would definitely be mistaken until a few others and I spotted it a few minutes later running around the restaurant...I was shocked!!!!A RAT and that too in a restaurant?????Some customer went and complained to the owner, but he asked the customer to ignore it ...(IGNORE IT?????Seriously?)... Anyways, we took our food and left... After much debate whether we should actually eat the food or not...we took a few bites enough to find out that the food tasted horrible....can safely say that it was the worst Indian food I have eaten. Would definitely not recommend this restaurant to anyone else...
author: Ss S.

description: If you like this place, I guess to each his own.  My wife and I stopped by after reading the initial reviews, but the food was mediocre at best.  The cooks were playing on their iPhones and smacking each other on the a$$ while cooking, no joke.  The food was really just average, but hey, give it a shot if you can't find anything better.
author: Zachary P.

description: Chicken tiki masala. Lamb and I'm done. the problem is that the serving portions are small in the city. sparingly.
author: James J.

description:
Chutney used to be my favorite Indian restaurant in the city, however, I've gotten sick after eating there the last two times.  While tossing and turning with stomach cramps, I decided to look up their health code score.  They received NINE health code violations and a very poor 68 from their January '08 inspection for violations including vermin (rats), inproper hand washing stations, and improper food storage.   That enough to make me wanna throw up.... and never eat there again.  Don't get me wrong, I love this place, but it's not safe to eat there.  Beware!
Health Department Report: http://www.dph.sf.ca.us/eh/Violations/Loc_CurrentViol.asp?LocationID=2112
author: Melissa C.

description:
no more...tried to give them a chance (or 6). last 6 times either waited 25 minutes to get food or waited 35 minutes to be told we lost your order or we are out of lamb biryani...good bye chutney.
some of my friends also saw mice there recently.
author: Sean C.

description:
3.5 stars. A cold and rainy night... Perfect time for some Indian food! 
The first thing I noticed about this place, is that it felt classier (is that the right word?) than the other fast food Indian places in the city. 
We ordered mixed veggie korma, palek paneer, chicken korma, a prawn curry, veggie samosas, some kind of lamb sausage, rice, plain naan, and a naan stuffed with meat. 

The food was brought to our table very quickly. The veggie korma was good, not as creamy as I've had it at other places. But still very good and tasted fresh. The palek paneer, I would recommend passing on. It was too pureed. I like to see some spinach in my palek paneer, but this was just like a light green runny soup. And the cubes of cheese in it, were not flavorful at all. The whole dish tasted like it needed salt. 
The veggie samosas were tasty. Fried food, can't go wrong with that. 

And the meat eaters in the group enjoyed their meats dishes, especially the naan filled with meat. I think that was the favorite surprise of the night. 

Chutney feels much cleaner and less greasier than other places like Shalimar. The food tasted fresher and less heavy. Although as I write this review, it is the day after that meal, and I still feel full of Indian food. Don't know if that's a good or bad thing....Also it was nice to not feel rushed to order and rushed to grab a table and then rushed to eat and get up and clear the table for other customers. It was a leisurely eating experience. I think we were in there for about 2 hours. I'd definitely go back again.

The prices are great, all dishes, 3 drinks and tip: $60 for 4 people.
author: Caroline C.

description: First time going to Chutney in Sf. Went to the Fremont Chutney, years back and the food was sweet and gross; never went back. Our usual spot stopped having a buffet, plus their food was mediocre. We were pleasantly surprised. Amazing chicken tikka masala, Naan is excellent, good seating. Will be coming here from now on.
author: R K.

description: Chicken Masala, Tandoori Chicken, Naan, and some spinach with potatoe thing with rice was $20.  I really thought all was of utmost quality.  A lot of times after Indian meals, I feel sort of BLAH because it's way too salty, but this spot was not the case.  I'll bring in some of my own liquor next time, now that I know you can.  Nice and clean inside.  I like that you pay at the register after your meal whenever you finish.  It's very refined, I feel.  Pitcher of water at the table is something I always appreciate.
author: Marc S.

description: Pasty bland curries for those who have never tasted good Indian food before. If you are looking for an authentic Indian experience look elsewhere.
author: K C.

description:
So after walking out of Grand Cafe from our lunch that never happened, we trolled around the area trying to find something to eat!

We happened to spot this place and proceeded to order up a storm.
Tasty, Tasty Tasty!

WTF were we thinking trying to eat at Grand Cafe (that shit hole)....we were really in the mood for some Indian food!
author: A P.

description:
When I'm downtown and craving some Indian food, I prefer Chutney over Naan n Curry. This place is just nicer and has a cleaner feeling to it. The prices are cheap and the service is very good. Chutney is a very popular place to dine at night. 

I ordered a chicken spinach dish. It was good, but not possible for me to eat unless I had some naan because I couldn't even handle the mild spices! I suck. So I just ate all the chicken and couldn't finish all the spinach. Oh well, you should still try it!
author: Bets Y.

description:
YOU'VE FAILED ME, YELP!!

Well, only this once, at least... But still! How anyone can rate this garbage above 2 stars is beyond me! I don't even know why I'm giving them 2, but I guess it's because they weren't abysmal...

How can they pass this watered-down slop off as curry?! I ordered the Mixed Veggie Tikka Masala and my friend got Lamb Vindaloo... Both curries had the consistency of milk and had a very bland flavor.

We did take out, and the guy we paid was completely vapid! When we asked him if we could both pay separately, we all stood there in silence for about 10 complete seconds while waiting for any inkling of a response from this man! I'm not even kidding!

With virtually the same menu as Naan N Curry with less than half the flavor and texture, you'd be better off going for Naan N Curry... Or better yet, walk a block down to Lahore Karahi, which might be a little slow and forgetful at times, but their food is galaxies apart from this slop shop!
author: P A U L.

description:
When my brother's friend recommended this simple fast-food style Indian restaurant in the Tenderloin neighborhood, I thought to myself "ughhh"! I'm not a snob, but I plainly avoid the Tenderloin unless I need to use the ATM for an emergency!

Boy was I judgemental! The chicken tikka masala was superb, and the vegetable plate was good. Naan was also great, but it took way too long to get another order of it. The mango lassi was the best I've ever had!! I was disappointed with the samosas... they fell short in tastiness. I would steer clear of ordering these unless you're on a bland food diet.

Chutney is clearly a fast-food style restaurant, but the service is a bit too hasty. If service was consistent, I'd give it a higher rating hands down. I suggest dining there for cheap, authentic and tasty Indian food with a group of friends, but certainly not for a romantic night out on the town!
author: Lara D.

description: I went back to Chutney again for maybe the 40th time.  This time I tried the kheer for desert.  It was savory and delicious.  I'm going to get it again soon.  The veggie wrap is still as awesome as it has ever been.  New cashier since last time I went, he speaks Spanish and English and he was very nice.  The whole staff is nice.  If you love Indian food, then you probably already know that Chutney's quality of food cannot be beaten considering the low price.  When you're broke and starving head to Chutney.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
When you walk down Jones St.  you can smell the aromatics coming from both sides,  one from Shalimar and the other from Chutney. But the explosive smells coming from Chutney always puts a smile on my face and of course the belly.

From the time you walk in you already know what you are getting into, because by the time you walk out you are in disbelief that your are absolutely satisfied with the food and reasonable prices.  Whether you are going to have vegetarian dishes or succulent meat dishes you will definitely have orgasms in your mouth and mind trying to figure out the spices that are used.

Try their kebabs, which are not overcooked and still juicy, their Naan which are still crispy on the outside yet so soft inside and their stews (MM MM Yum).

You can't go wrong at Chutney.  So make it a day and go find out how much can the food will make you say "WOW"!
author: Timothy W.

description:
Amazing place to eat at.  I've never been exposed to Indian and Pakistani food before so it was all new to me.  I asked my cousin on a good Indian place around town and she recommended this place to me.

I ended up ordering the Chicken Tikka Masala and my friend ordered the Lamb Biryani.  We also got two orders of the cheese naan.  I never knew Indian food was this great!  The flavors were so good with both meals.  The chicken tikka masala was covered with this nice curry sauce.  It made a great dipping sauce for the cheese filled naan.  The lamb biryani was also a delight.  The rice was so good and the lamb topped it off.  The food is a bit spicy which I love.  I'm definitely coming back to this joint next time.  It's one of my favorite spots in San Francisco.
author: Christian M.

description: There are a lot of Indian and Pakistani restaurants on the east side of the Tenderloin, and this one is excellent. I love that it's cheap and casual. When you order, you're given a little plastic number, then you sit wherever you like and wait for your food to be brought over. Nice noisy cafeteria vibe, good for families, always packed. I'm a white girl who's a bit of a wimp when confronted with chilis, so I stick to the chicken tikka masala. I can't speak for the authenticity of the dishes, or what the more spicy ones are like, but I know what I like and this place is my kind of spot for a quick, cheap eat.
author: Julia K.

description: Not the tastiest chicken tikka masala, aloo vindaloo, or garlic naan I've had. Slightly disappointed. And prices online were less than when I got there, and manager was unaware of this but didn't seem to care. Food prep was fast though.
author: Darron R.

description:
Who you calling Mango Lassie?! For those unfamiliar with Le Loin, be prepared to be approached for cash & coin requests, offers to purchase fictional amounts of one medicinal or another, and on the receiving end of some ribald expletives and gesticulations. Once you get past that, "Welcome to Chutney." The aromas practically guide you there. Pick up & brown bag yer beer fr. the corner sto. 

Enjoyed the many varieties of Naan. The 'tater Naan is a meal unto itself. Amazing curries. Delicious Baigan Bharta and Masalas. On the smokey clothes meter, Chutney places 2nd behind Naan-N-Curry on O'Farrell.
author: Johnny C.

description:
Lets compare the similarities and differences between neighbors Chutney and Shalimar.

Similarites:
Serves Indian food, self-serve, price, lots of brown patrons

Difference:
Shalimar - Indian cooks, filthy, spicy dishes, newspaper menu, unfriendly staff, food that makes you say, "Hot damn, Barnaby!"

Chutney - Mexican cooks, clean, medium-hot dishes, laminated menu, friendlier staff, food that makes you say, "I had a good time, Bob"
author: Jen Y.

description: If you're not a fan of Shalimar, don't come here.  It's practically the same restaurant if you compare the menu.  I do have to say that Chutney seems to be a little cleaner looking than Shalimar.  However, the Chicken tika masala is not as good as that from Shalimar.
author: Victor C.

description: I have a coworker who loves this place. I found the service indifferent and almost hostile. The food was good enough, that I'll give it another try.
author: Tom A.

description: I have been going to chutney for years. i LOVE IT LOVE IT LOVE IT! the food is amazing. i have tried tika masala and potato naan from other restaurants and it does not even compare. also, when i aks my 5 and 7 year old sons what there favorite food is they say "CHUTNEY!!!!"   its definitely my favorite restaurant of all time :)
author: Cameron M.

description:
To all the 3star and below reviews I say: blah-be-di-bliddy-blah-blah.  

Chutney is fantastic.  If I take someone from out of town here once, they always insist on coming back when they return.  I don't know Indian authentic, and have heard Shalimar is more so- but at least my food doesn't swim in oil at Chutney.  Also, this is the only naan/curry type dive that is always packed to the hilt with Indian people.  

Good food.  Great price.  Fast service.  Comfortable interior.  Go now!
author: CAKE E.

description: My go-to place for Indian Curry cravings in the city. Best Aloo Vindhaloo and  Paneer Tikka Masala in town and great service too
author: S K.

description: This was one of the places open after 10:30 on the 3rd of July, so we ate  here...Garlic naan was good, the food was okay-nothing spectacular. I am not sure why the ratings are so high? the service was bad, how do you not have a board with the menu if your not a sit down restaurant? you have to look at the menu when you get to the cashier and then order, uh no that;'s not going to hold up the line and make people leave.....I agree with Mehdi, the area was disgusting, how we found this area and this joint I have no idea-I think I would  have rather found a taco bell.... the place was gross and bathrooms were disgusting, wipe the bathroom doors, there is like black stains on the doors! GROSS!
author: Varsha L.

description:
Shatangi had a spicy lamb wrap. Bomb-diggity!! I got to sample my colleague's'  chickpea and cauliflower dishes as well. Very good food and good service for a very reasonable price. Good for both viggisaurs and meat-o-saurs. The location is crap but the interior is comfortable and well decorated. Great for groups and children.

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
I've probably been to Chutney at least 20 times in the past few years.  Of all the Indian/Pakistani restaurants I've been to in SF/Marin County, it's by far my favorite.

Here's what got me hooked: chicken tikka masala (which absolutely melts in your mouth), bengan bharta (if you're not used to it, it tastes a lot better on the 2nd try), aloo ghobi, naan (an absolute must), lamb vindaloo, and mango lassi (request a glass of ice with it).

I'll admit that the spiciness and flavor aren't always consistent, but that doesn't take away from the fact that it's still really friggin good food!

Chutney is definitely in my Top 10!
author: Kieu L.

description:
I have been going to Chutney since the beginning.  I first stumbled upon their restaurant after being disgusted of finding hair in my food at a restaurant around the corner.  

Pretty much this is the tastiest Indian/Pakistani food I have ever had.  I live in the Sunset, and totally don't mind driving across town to have their food.  

I always get the chicken tikka masala with garlic naan and bengan bharta w/ rice.  

The neighborhood is totally sketchy, but whatever I just park in the parking lot next door as it is convenient and I don't like doing multiple figure eights just to walk a block to the restaurant while fending off drug addicts.

BTW, a good rule of thumb I have found for this place, order 1 entree per person, 2 naans for every 3 persons, and 1 rice for every 2 persons.
author: Dong T.

description:
The Tandoori Fish is a MUST-TRY!  Now we absolutely HAVE to order that when we are at Chutneys.  It comes with 4 skewered fish steaks - moist, tender, to die for.  It has been consistently good - the same delicious taste every single time.  It seems like a bit of an extra wait for this dish, but you won't be sorry.

The lamb and beef kebabs were also well-flavored.
author: A. L.

description: Wandered here because Shalimar was too packed and we had to catch a show in 20 min.: Food is a 3, but prices and service speed bump Chutney up to a 4. It also seems so much cleaner than Shalimar. We had the chicken tikka which was so-so (too creamy/not enough tomato and the gravy was too thin for my taste). However, the garlic naan and yellow dal were solid. 2 dishes, rice, and naan for under $20 = pretty awesome. I've had crappy Indian food truck in the city that costs more than this, without the seating and central location!
author: Pria P.

description: Yes Sir....my favorite place for Indian Pakistani dishes. Their tandoori chicken here is off the hook. Their tandoori garlic naan bread coupled with their tasty masala is mouth melting. For fiber, have to have their mesquite bengan bharta with basmati rice. This is at the Loin, but this is where home cooking at its best.
author: llando d.

description: I was not impressed... I tried the Chicken Vindaloo which was bland and with more bone than meat.  I also had the Chicken Tiki Masala which had good sauce but dry overcooked chicken.  The Garlic Naan was good.  It is also not a true restaurant (but that doesn't factor into my rating).  You order your food at the counter, get a number, food is brought to your table, then you take your number back to the counter to pay.
author: Owen S.

description: I grew up in many parts of the world and had my chance to get in on Indian/Pakistani food in some real  Authentic joints.  I can honestly say that Chutney has been my favorite for years over many of the others in the city.  I've been to all of them and been a customer since Shalimar, Chutney and Na'an n Curry had opened.. Yes been going to all 3 for that long.  Food in consistent and the flavor are amazing.  Chicken Keema is a must which is on a side menu (daily Specials) Try it.
author: momo m.

description: I heard good things about this place .. dropped by to get some take-out.. ordered chicken tikka masala, palak paneer, 3 naans and 2 rices and got the chai to go for $20!  the stuff was delcious too!  the palak paneer was almost pure spinach.. that was some thick curry man. everythign was flavorfull and filling.. can't eat much of it at once since it was so heavy.  the naan are chewy and fluffy at the same time and rice nicely cooked slight saffron taste.  all in all.. would definetly come back to this place... although the area... isn't all that great.
author: Margie C.

description:
I use to really love this place. Their Vindaloos are great. Mango Lassies are perfect. 

BUT

We had a roach in one of our dishes....that was the last time we ate there. Never again. Oh well, what a shame.

Eat there at your own risk.
author: Judith F.

description:
I have been several times and cannot go back.  Sauces tend to rely heavily on cream and are no better than soup from a can.  The on;y chutneys that they have are pre-prepared (the tamarind is pure purchased pulp and corn syrup).

Repeatedly horrible customer service - working in the service industry I've become very tolerant, but I draw the line at places that direct profanity (loudly) at customers.  There are too many other amazing places nearby to waste your time here.

One star for being one of the nicer-looking Indian-Pakastani restaurants in the 'Loin.
author: Angela C.

description:
I've been looking for good Indian/Pakistani food in the city because everything so far has been mediocre. A couple friends recommended Chutneys, and I think my search still continues...

However, I haven't tried enough dishes at Chutneys for a real rating, so I'm not ruling it out just yet.  One thing to keep in mind is that it IS cleaner then the Shalimar across the street... so if you can't handle the atmosphere there, check out Chutneys...the food is decent!
author: Shafaq C.

description:
When Tasty Curry opened not far from my former apartment about 7 years ago I began eating Indian Food religiously.  During that time I have eaten at most of the Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the city and can safely say Chutney is hands down THE BEST!

The portions are huge, the prices are low and best of all the food tastes great.  If you are sick and tired of your regular indian place serving you 4 ounces of chicken with your tikka kebab, and a plate of daal no thicker than a piece of paper; then try Chutney it will not disappoint.

I have been eating there for about two years and have never regretted my choice for dinner.  Though I didn't weigh it, I feel it's safe to say my chicken boti (aka chicken tikka kebab) was at least a pound.  That's 4 times as much meat as some restaurants sell you for more money.

More often that not I order to go, and really appreciate that the guys fill up the containers, unlike some other places that you would be lucky to have a smaller container filled half way.

For under $15 I ordered
Chicken Boti
Potato w/ spinach
and two Roti (whole wheat naan, the best)
FYI this was enough food for at least two meals, my to go bag must have weighed more than 3 pounds

Thanks for reading...
author: Nate K.

description: Trader Joe's has better garlic naan than this place.  Don't get me started on the watery curries here. What else should I expect from an Indian restaurant that has Mexicans cooking in the back?  Plenty of other Indian joints in the area.
author: Dom And Jazz C.

description:
I'm of South Asian heritage and so am picky about desi (South Asian) food.

This is one of the few places I will eat desi food in the city. It's fairly authentic and not as ridiculously greasy as the place across the street, which, while delicious, makes you start belching ten minutes after you're done eating and well into the night. 

Unfortunately, Chutney is like a warehouse and can get extremely loud and smoky from the tandoor oven. The service at the counter isn't particularly nice either. 

Having said that, the daily special chikker cholay, tandoor fish, naan, & biryani are all very good. 

The paneer dish has a delicious sauce but the actual cubes of cheese are too few and far in between to be worthwhile. 

It's usually crowded so there can be a wait, but you can stuff yourself silly for $10 a head once you get in.
author: Sharand N.

description:
My boyfriend lived in India for awhile and this is the only place he will eat Indian food in SF. I went there once for dinner after I had Indian food for lunch and Chutney's food was 10 times better than what I had had for lunch. 

It's a bright cheerful restaurant in a mildly dodgy neighborhood, but worth is.
author: Leslie D.

description: poor service. placed order at 1pm for 6pm pick-up, and they didn't see the actual pick-up time and the food was sitting out for 5 hours. Order their "Kheer" which is supposed to rice pudding (and typically white in color) and it was more of a carrot pudding and orange in color. For the "Salt Lassi" there was a online note to make it with *Less salt, but it was super salty. Called and a guy who claimed to be one of the owners (I don't think he really was) and said both items are pre-made. If something has carrots, it should be described as that. If they can't make a lassi with less salt, they should COMMUNICATE and let the customer know. they should READ THE ORDERS. The guy just said they don't have the ability to describe the food better. What the heck does that mean??? it seemed as if he couldn't care less. -- The guy asked me to drive back and bring the items back for a refund. I didn't want to waste my time.
author: M s.

description:
I'm actually torn between 3 and 4 stars for this place but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt. Why? The service was good!

The food was tasty too but my only complaint is the curry dish we ordered. The chicken tikka masala had only 5 pieces of chicken, literally. What happened to the other parts of the chicken? Everything was good but after a long run and an empty stomach, almost anything tastes good.

For simple India food, I would definitely go back!
author: Michelle H.

description: In the Tenderloin area closer towards Union Square, there exists a cluster Indian/Pakistani restaurants. The Shalimar, the Pakwan, the Naan n Curry just to name a few. They are wonderful places to eat for real cheap and they all serve great food. This afternoon I went to the Chutney on Jones steet. The Chutney is no exception to the other. It's nicer and cleaner than Shalimar. It's food is delicious and the service was quick. I had the lamb saag and chicken breast tandoori.  I give it the same high score as the others. It is great living in an area with a plethora of Indian/Pakistani restaurants to choose from..
author: Mike L.

description:
Four stars for being my local, being cheap, good people watching and being all around tasty.

Gone are the days of an easy to find, good meal for about 5 bucks in the Loin.  I have worked in the neighborhood for 6 years and miss the days of $5 thai or burrito.  Even Subway doesn't satiate my appetite for under 6 bones.  But Chutney, Allah bless this place.  You can get yourself a wrap, which is bloody delicious for 5.  Or a tandoori chicken salad, I have eaten a thousand of them.  YOU CAN BRING IN BOOZE.  

Here is a Haiku:

Chutney of my heart
You are not Italian food
South Asia delight

Here is another one:

Jones street and Geary
Throw your damn hands in the air
And go crazy man

Their food is probably more like 3 star goods.  Lots of sauce but not a lot of meat.  You know, stuff like that.  Fortunately their naan is only a buck so you can just dip all day without breaking the bank.
author: Jeff B.

description: Paneer like rubber. Vindaloo that tastes like tomato broth. Good garlic naan but that can't save the dishes served. Shocked this place averages 4 stars. This is hardly Indian food.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Indian food and my stomach have had a difficult relationship over the years.  Whenever I have it, I love the moment, but my stomach regrets it the next day (sometimes sooner).  

My coworker, who's the same way, convinced me to give it another shot at Chutney.  So a group of us went one evening and ordered a meal that was probably befitting an army...chicken tikki masala, biryani, the boti, naan, and more.  It was DELISH!  I couldn't stop slurping up the tikki masala sauce, which I could have had all night with some rice.  And, the price was amazingly reasonable.

The best part?  No stomach ache!  Four stars for the food and one star for my stomach's new BFF!
author: Abby N.

description:
WTF happened Chutney?!?!??!?!?!  I know you used to have delicious food!  I swear!  It couldn't have been drug induced psychosis; nothing I've hallucinated has tasted this good.

I've been coming here for about two years and twas my fav indian spot in the city despite the sketchy area. Well tbh my friends live on Jones and Ellis and I love bringing people to the heart of the TL. 

Anyway, time before last that we patronized this establishment, the food was so-so and they ran out of RICE.  NO RICE IN AN INDIAN RESTAURANT?  So I ran down to Pakwan and got a large rice to go for us to eat at Chutney.  Mistake... we should have known there was something off.

The chicken tikki masala was not spicy anymore, the garlic naan no longer crispy, and worst of all; the lamb was mushy.  I'm not sure if there's  some sort of mutiny from the kitchen staff or new owners changing everything but nothing tastes the same.  Now I'll have to go to the mission for mah curry :(    

Also there was a large party and someone's car got towed which caused some random b*tch to shove me hard into the door while running to yell at the poor tow guy.  Dude it's your own GD fault that you can't see through ten layers of mascara and eyeshadow...  yeah that's a red zone.   Learn how to park in the city or go back to Castro Valley.  Hella TRASHY. Ugh.  Her friends tried to apologize but the staff didn't bat an eye.  *sigh* enough is enough.  

Thank you very much Chutney for once being so awesome but I'm gonna have to say goodbye now.  Sometimes you just have to hit it and know when to quit it.
author: dr S.

description: Chicken tikka masala is soooo good.
author: Heather H.

description:
I think Chutney used to have better food. Standard spread of Indian Fare with a few daily specials. The first few times I went here I couldn't get enough but more recently it seems that their food has gone down in quality. Well not quality but flavor at least. I could care less if it were low quality for the price it was sold for but I do demand flavor. As always with Indian restaurants in the bay, somehow you can magically bring booze into this place free of charge and ridicule. 

Extra story that you might not care about:

This was the first restaurant I ever "yelped" before visiting. The yelp article I read said something about how the costumer had walked in and saw a cockroach on the floor and was totally disgusted and left. 

On my very first visit I walked in and was telling my friend that exact same story when a cockroach scurried out from underneath the front counter. The gentleman at the counter proceeded to walk around the counter and crush it, after which he returned to his place behind the counter and asked us what we would like to eat. It was totally hilarious.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
My friend introduced me to this place last week.  It was really busy- always a good sign.  The food was great.  Love that naan!  I ordered the lamb mesala, which was tender, juicy and full of flavor.  I wish they gave you more, though!..haha  Still, load up on some more naan, have a few cups of the free, self-serve chai, and check out other treats on their hefty-size menu.  You'll love it!

Bon appetit!
author: M S.

description: The Chicken Tikka Masala is very good.
author: Jim J.

description:
Chutney is my favorite Indian restaurant in the Tandoor-loin. I was a regular when I lived in the city.

I've had a number of their dishes, but I prefer the vegetarian ones. Their Palak Aloo Methi is the best. It has fenugreek (I think?) or some spice that is whole in the dish that makes it different from teh rest.

Plus, you get an iceberg lettuce salad and chai with your meal. What a deal! Very pleasant to sit down in (unlike across the street Shalimar, gross), and take your time, it's never been that crowded, even during dinner.

All in all, my favorite for a lunch in the city.
author: Luke J.

description:
Hoorah for Chutney!

This place...
- is cheap
- is delicious
- lets you BYOB
- gives you really decent portions
- has the best tandoori fish I've ever tasted

Yum. Yum.  And more Yum.
author: Whitney H.

description:
Clean and semi-exotic decor, the Indian food was good, but thats all it was. plain good. 

Shalimar across the street is great! yeah..its kinda dingy and you have to walk through hobos and such, but the food is great...don't forget that.
author: Janelle H.

description: My number one Indian joint...and it's not just because it's in my hood either! Most of my folks agree! It's bomb! This place took my Indian cuisine virginity. I don't know, that  might have some influence over why it's my top. I've been to many other Indian restaurants since then, but I just keep coming back here. This spot is the only location I CRAVE for! Their green chutney burns like no other and I love it! It makes the chutney elsewhere taste like water. I prefer their "tikka masalas" over others, especially the lamb one. I prefer their "seekh kabobs" over others, something about the texture. Ooh, and their "brain masala" is like biting into gushy, mushy heaven! Suck it in and roll it on the roof of your mouth. *drool* Most other joints may have a salad bar..with their dull chutneys, but this spot you get your salad served to you...and they set your table. Love! Love! Love! Love! Love!
author: Helen L.

description:
Fun cheap yum! Perfect for a quick lunch! The place is not really about atmosphere -- it looks a bit like a high school cafeteria. But, somehow, it's just... fitting. You order the food at the counter, sit, and they bring it to you.  By the looks of the place, there's an impression that the food may second-class fast-food, but it's absolutely delicious, flavorful, well-made Indian food!

The service too was fantastic. I actually broke my entire mango lahsee glass! What an embarrassment. But not only did they clean it up quickly, but they made me a brand new one without me even asking for one! So nice.
author: Natasha H.

description:
Chicken Tikka Masala goodness! After one work day and some shopping, I decided to walk around the 'Loin looking for a yummy and cheap place for dinner. I stumbled upon Chutney and boy, oh boy, I was hooked the moment I had some of their Tikka Masala. I had it with Basmati rice and Naan. Both were superb as well. Most if not all of the entrees are less than 10 bucks. They also serve you with a simple complimentary salad of greens, tomatoes and onions as well. 

Needless to say, after 10725563 Chutney visits, this place hasn't failed me once. All their entrees are very authentic and reasonably priced. If you can get over the "occasional" sketchiness of the T-loin, then you just found yourself a place that makes yummy Indian goodness at incredibly cheap prices. A staple in my restaurant list!
author: Erika I.

description: Very authentic. Full of Indian people which seems like the sign of a good Indian restaurant! wonderful aloo naan. Chicken korma was good though not as creamy as I'm used to but the mango lassi was as delicious as it always is. Incredible prices. Cheap and hearty!
author: Phil R.

description:
with my buddies, there are the three dishes we always get: chicken tikka masala, palak paneer and aloo ghobi. 

im the palak paneer fan and i was not a fan of this one. it was so bland. and the cubes of cheese were too big, that it accetuated the blandness of the dish.

good thing the chicken tikka masala and aloo ghobi were ordered because they were yummy and flavorful. i liked the aloo ghobi the best. 

ordered take out but the place looked pretty nice/clean. it was pretty busy for 5pm on a sun too.
author: Sabrina T.

description:
You know, I love the cheap Indian/Pakistani food, but the spinach in my mattar paneer was watery and straight from the freezer. And while the Tikka Masala tasted great, there was only about 4 pieces of chicken in it. 

I much prefer Pakwan.
author: Emily L.

description:
If you don't mind taking a stroll in the Tenderloin, check out Chutney!  There are quite a few Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the Tenderloin and Chutney definitely is one of the better ones.  Last time I was there I had the naan, basmati rice, spinach w/ cheese cubes, tandoori chicken, mango chutney and lentils.  They were all delicious.  The naan was perfect - not too burnt or dry.  

I like Indian restaurants in general where you can grab your own drinks, plates, and utensils and pack your food to go at will.  It makes everything so much easier and much more efficient.
author: Lillian M.

description:
We went here because Shalimar across the street was unable to seat our party of 3 thanks to their poor forward thinking when seating other customers.

My girlfriend & friend enjoyed their tikka masala dishes. I, however, did not. I had the chicken korma. The sauce tasted okay. The chicken was still on the bone, which is fine provided the bones are still intact and there is plenty of meat.

But it wasn't. It appeared as if someone had hacked at my meal with a hatchet before serving it. There was very little meat on some of the pieces, and when I put some sauce on my rice, I got a nice surprise. There were tiny shards of bone that were just sitting in the sauce with no meat at all. That's a great way for someone to crack a tooth.

When I paid, the cashier asked me how the food was, and I told him about the loose bones. He was surprised and he said he would talk to the kitchen. That might help future customers, but it provided no satisfaction to me, the recipient of the bone shards.
author: Jon S.

description: Food is ok. I have had really good Nihari, Chicken Kofta, Aloo Gobi and few other items. I don't think they are really expensive either, but lately I have been getting really old and nasty food their service is really slow and if you ordered to go please check your food before you leave they have made mistakes and gave me something different. I had to go back and wait another 15 mins for them to pack the right thing. There is a parking garage next to the restaurant so those of you who are driving there you can park there and it is safe there better than parking in Tenderloin.
author: fizza m.

description:
Chutney is that girl who has it all but never amounted to much.  It's way cleaner than Shalimar across the street, better decorated, a much more creative menu, more upscale dishes, they try harder.  You feel better about yourself being here.  Technically, everything about Chutney -- one of SF's trademark style of Pakistani restaurants if you must know -- is better.

But it's not Shalimar.  Just doesn't have the magic.
author: Gil S.

description:
Chutney plusses: Very clean, good ambiance for the Tendernob area, plentiful freeflowing chai, generous portions, good prices, and you don't emerge from the restaurant smelling like curry spices.

This is a great place to bring your friends who may not be the biggest Indian food fans - clean, cute, good solid Indian food that is "nonthreatening".  But for your Indian food aficionados, Chutney might hold its own on the Chicken Tikka Masala scale but there are some more stellar places around the corner for food though they lack ambiance.
author: Jane A.

description:
You must try the Chicken Tikka Masala! Amazing Sauces. 

The staff is very helpful, the food is quick and delicious. When I get back from my travels Chutney is the first place I go to. 

I only wish they delivered......

WHAT, WHAT in the CHUT?

I highly recommend this spot to anyone who grew up eating indian/pakistani or have never had it before in their life. 

Amazing!
author: Dane B.

description:
I think they're pretty good, altho the rockin' Shalimar is right across the street!  What you can expect here is soft and sultry Indo-Pak food.  I'm not sure I'd call them the cheapest but I found their curries to be more "silky".  The naan was tasty but a bit on the soft side---I like mine slightly crispy.  I remember their goat was tasty.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
What Sooj fails to mention is that the food arrived in about two seconds.  In fact, I think it arrived before we ordered it.   The Naan was nice and big and fresh and poofy.  The plate of perfectly cooked basmati rice was large as well.  The three meal parts - rice, naan, meal, were all in proportion - exactly the right amount of everything.  

I liked how the lamb saag was less saag-y (heh) than usual.  Not that I don't love it creamy and pureed as well, but the spinach in this version was on the other end of the saag spectrum, it seemed to me.   Not al dente or anything, but more like chopped spinach.  But well chopped.  And well cooked.  I'm having trouble describing it in a way that conveys how tasty it was.   It was just perfect in every way.  I will have to try it again, though, because the four honey-basil gimlet thingies from that black padded Ambassador place may have put a slant of some sort on my opinion.
author: April D.

description:
Now this is pretty good Indian food. Their lamb chops are amazing. The place is CLEAN (unlike thier neighbor across the street (read - Shalimar)). Their good hygiene alone makes me want to come back here. The place is affordable as well.

Check it out, yo.

"ai"
author: Anand I.

description: Wow! By far the best Indian restaurant we have been to while staying in the San Fran area.  Great food, good sized portions, and cheap compared to other places we have been to.
author: Kristopher T.

description: Horrible! Saw all the good reviews and was misled. At least if u r Indian/desi avoid it at all costs. Roti was fat, heavy and tasteless. Matar paneer was a sad attempt at creating something mediocre. The ambience is just the cherry on the top - or none at that. I would rather go hungry than eat here again.
author: abhishek p.

description: I love this place! It's super close to my place and the lamb curry is amaaaazing! Open until midnight, so when I have those later night cravings for some delicious Indian food (which is often), you know where to find me.
author: Jessica L.

description: don't order chicken vindaloo or chicken korma unless you want boney soup. the worst indian food i've ever eaten & i have had an array of indian food. naan & curry is 5 stars in comparison. i will not be eating here ever again.
author: Roxanne R.

description:
You can always get a decent meal here, so why only 3 stars? The deal is this: While this place is actually pretty good, I just have a few things that I would prefer left the way they should be. First is that the Palak Paneer at this place has WAY too much cream in it. Same for the Tikka Masala. Also service is scetchy in that they always, and I mean always forget part of our order. Just gets old...
I do recommend the Goat Curry here which sounds kinda knarly, but is slow cooked and fabulous...always.
author: Ross J.

description:
IMO, chutney is one of the weirder indian restaurants in SF.  my gut feeling tells me that they should offer more "chunky" (not chutney) dishes for vegetarians.
i certainly haven't had everything on the menu, but what i have was too runny (contrary to what another person said- i think they're probably a meat eater).

i was a bit worried that i would be sick the next day, but i wasn't! :)
yeaye for me (and you).

i do like their atmosphere, the flavors of what i tried, and i love the brb rule.  that's what gives them 3 here.

i think the quality here seems to be superior to naan 'n' curry; but it's almost a toss-up.

ld
author: linden d.

description:
i am sort of regular at this place. It is one of the cleanest, decently priced Indian/ Pakistani restaurant. There lamb and beef dishes never disappoint me where as chicken dishes rarely impress me. 
Seekh kabob and mice meat is really good. Request him to make boneless chicken dish in NON-Butter curry. It is not in the menu and they do spectacular job in making it. the butter chicken is extremely disappointing and chicken tikka is blend. 
IF u stick with lamb and beef you will be a happy camper. I spend approx $10 and i have enough left for net day :)
author: Hasham Y.

description:
Good Kabobs .. nicer place compared to others.
and for a change they happen to accpet Visa and Master.
author: Hash K.

description: Been to this place a lot of times. Favorites include chicken tandoori, fish tandoori, and garlic naan. Try the mango chutney and shrimp tikka masala as well. Quite cheap - around $10/person. Drawback - you will smell like curry (place needs to be ventilated more), and you have to line up at cashier twice (first to order, and then after you eat to pay).
author: Ryan M.

description: I'm not sure, but I think this place gave me the runs.  Everything tasted great, but I was horribly sick and on the toilet all morning the next day.  Granted, I think I was already dehydrated and getting sick, but I dont think my intestines were done any favors by eating here.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
I am not one of those people who crave Indian or Paskistani food.  However, tonight as I am staying at the Hotel Serrano (fabulous by the way) in San Francisco I asked the Bellman "seriously, where do you eat?" He rambled off several but even the concierge perked up when he mentioned Chutney.  Fine, Indian it was.
         I owe them a huge tip.  Extremely short walk through a shady area, yes the other reviews are spot-on, I walked in and ordered exactly how the concierge told me to: Chicken Boti with a side of Tika Masala sauce so I would get more chicken (someday they will catch on to this one), Garlic Naan, basmati rice, and for fun I added Samosas.  Mistake, HUGE mistake.  
        Food was incredibly balanced: sweet, savory, spicy, and earthy.  The mistake was I ordered way too much.  How on earth can one human finish this much food???  Seriously, I am sitting beside a container with so many leftovers wondering if this will fit in the mini-bar for a night so I can have it for breakfast in the morning. 
         I honestly do not see where the comments regarding the fantastic, polite service come from.  The guy who took my order frankly could care less, he was more interested in his Iphone, but he was polite, just distracted.  
        To sit and watch the cooks work is a double-edged sword: It is interesting to watch them put meat and bread in and out of these hot tandoor ovens, but as you sit there the aromas just soak into your clothes, hair, any exposed area of your body.  I sit here and still smell the spices and the food has been put away.
        Bottom line, go if you are in the area.  I would not drive from Oakland just for this, but if you are in the City and hungry for some great Indian food come on by.  I dont care what the negative reviewers say, this place has it going on.  Solid, solid solid.  
Now, excuse me while I sit and enjoy my food coma.
author: Mario N.

description:
This is a great place. It's the kind of place that for several reasons--if you want to have dinner with some buddies--is awesome.
 
First of all, girls never want to go there, which is great. It's in the Tenderloin, so you know it's an adventure, and the clientele is just shady enough that you need to watch your back while you eat; keeps your metabolism up.
 
The food is good and cheap, which is kind of trademark of most Indian joints these days, but it's feeling as shit.
 
I go there with this friend of mine who always over orders, but at this place it doesn't matter, because for 2 people the bill is never over $30.
 
Also, there's this crackhead out front who seems to know me, and every time I pull up he's got a spot reserved for me right out front.
author: eric f.

description:
Not as good as Lahore. So on my trek to good indian places in the tenderloin this one fell of the list. I liked naan n curry and lahore (whatever it is) better. Still have others to try.

I mean, it didn't suck. But with so many great places around the corner it couldn't compete.
author: Margie L.

description: Not much ambiance(think budget cafereria)  but very good prices. You order at the cashier, find a seat, and your arrives. Prices are very low, so we over-ordered. The lamb with spinach (lamb saag) was excellent.  Cauliflowers and potatoes (aloo ghobi) under $6. The keema naan (bread stuffed with ground beef) is hard to find and interesting.   Raita and chutney were OK, but only a buck. You can buy beer across the street (they have some large cans from microbreweries such as Laguniatas.  An outstanding value but the food lacked the fire of Shalimar (across the street).
author: art f.

description:
This should be the Happy Meal place!  Everything is so good here for such a bargain price.  

I went here last night after the DYL at Ambassador, and it was a perfect cheap meal after the Basil Gimlets at the Ambassador and a great contrast to the posh interiors as well.  

I had the lamb tikka masala with the naan and rice.  What was it like: lovely cubes of lamb drenched in a mellow orange-colored sauce.  I put some basmati rice onto my plate, spooned some of the beautiful stuff over it, took a bite from the plate, and then sopped my naan into the sauce...the whole meal was like that, a bite of rice with the sauce/meat, a bite of naan with the sauce.  At the end, so content.  

Does life get better than this?  I doubt it.
___________

Update: so more Chutney after Ambassador.  I could sooo get used to this.

But the real reason I am updating: they have goat meat!  Love it.
______

Another update: the samosa is quite nice as well. Meat mixed in with potato.  Good large size.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Bleh. Serendipity either leads you to fortune or disaster and the only reason I ended up here tonight was because I couldn't locate the mysterious Naan N Curry joint which shall remain the Mystery Spot of the Tenderloin (http://www.yelp.com/biz/9PlpuRgRzm-PlHMUoKnT5g). 

My to-go order was atrocious. The Naan was chewy and bland. The chicken vindaloo was an equally bland, soupy concoction with a very cheap cut of bony chicken. The chana masala and aloo gobi weren't as bad but not inspired. 

It's a shame to waste a meal in the City of food.
author: Jim S.

description:
Thanks to the fabulous Miriam W, I've become a regular in the Tandoor-loin lately.  Sure you have to step over the occasional passed out, er maybe dead body, be accosted by 2-3 dozen mentally challenged folks and the smell of urine is rife in the air but its small price to pay for the cheap prices you pay for quality North Indian-Pakistani food.

Chutney gets it all right. Friendly service, clean menu, well designed restaurant (o the lighting!) with a clean bathroom and really good food that doesn't leave you gasping for the water but doesn't leave you licking your lips wishing there was something else added to the dish.
author: Sean S.

description: Great food and service. Thank you Arfan for taking care of me and my family last night. This guy is awesome and he made us feel like we were eating at home. I am absolutely going back there, so I can enjoy the yummy food.
author: Weezy F.

description:
Ever-since the disappearance of The Little Indian Deli across the street, I have been at a loss for good Indian food. It's been a while that the Little Deli has been gone, but I guess I have not fully recovered from the loss and am a bit bitter....

Chutney doesn't compare, but it proves to be cleaner and have a better atmosphere than any other of the Indian restaurants in the neighborhood right now, and so, when in dire need, that's where I'll go.

Love the Mango lassies, and the hot tea with milk is so comforting on a rainy day... I think there could be some improvement on some of their dishes, but the Biagan Bartha and the Palak Paneer are quite nice.

I discovered that the "big boys", whoever they may be, eat in a hidden basement.... If you sit next to the basement door, you will notice that big plates of food get brought through this side door in a secretive sort of way. Gets me kinda curious... Who eats down there?!?!

Update (02/05/06): Last time I ate here will be my last. This is not Indian food. I don't know why I subject myself to this torture. There are many better places to go, and especially now that Little Delhi is open, I have no reason to ever frequent this place again.

Ehh, spare yourself. This is not Indian/Pakistani food..... At least not the good kind...
author: Janel A.

description:
If you love cheap, awesome Indian food and need some serious stomach-coating chicken tikka masala, look no further than this pee-splattered dive in the police-raiding Tenderloin district. 

Yes, you will step over passed-out homeless people and slop through human pee puddles. Yes, there may be a crack deal going on right outside the door. 

Yes, it's worth it.

Because inside is a cozy enclave of San Franciscans both brave and wise enough to be here. Aren't THESE the people you want to know? Aren't THESE the people you should be friends with?

Sure, you could go to the Marina for sushi or Nob Hill for Italian, but once, just once, say like on a slow Sunday evening (which is when my gaggle of friends always goes), wouldn't you like to try something different, something AWESOME, and see how a lot of San Franciscans REALLY live? 

Because life is not sugar-coated down here. Just, perhaps, a tad in the masala...
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Let me start out by saying this place popped my aloo nann cherry.  It was amazing...  Potato and peas with spicy spices stuffed in nann....
My bf likes to get these spicy meat logs that resemble Mr. Hanky.  They are delicious, tho too hot for me.  He fondly refers to them as "poo logs."
The people who take your order are helpful and the wait staff is great.  The prices have gone up a little bit, I think, but the food is still pretty cheap.  And you can get complimentary chai!  
The neighborhood seems iffy, but I've never been hassled.  I think the locals are too busy shooting up (yes, we have witnessed this...) to bother us.  We often get asked by a friendly bum or two if we have any food to spare.  We are usually able to give them our leftover naan, which they appreciate.

Edit: FLAMING poo logs...
author: Caitlin B.

description: This place was amazing! Came here for the second time last week - the lamb curry was really tasty and the garlic naan was the best I've ever had. I took my family along and they were really impressed by the food. Also, if you get a chance to try the rice pudding (they run out kind of fast, I guess), definitely go for it!
author: Rachel T.

description:
two words: bottomless chai.

it does however go quickly, so hope for a table in the back, right by the source. 

being a creature of habit, i almost always go for the bengan bharta, and it never disappoints. occasionally, i''ll go ahead and try something new, and i've yet to try a dish i didn't like there. 

i can not however, speak for any of the non-vegetarian dishes. my girlfriend will vouch for chicken tikka masala, if that's more up your alley than an eggplant dish.

did i mention the place is pretty solidly cheap? it is. 

3 stars, because the service leaves plenty to be desired. to say the least. i'm really not picky when it comes to customer service, but some of the front of the house employees are borderline jerks. as far as the service, hope for the best.

the food, a pretty risk free commitment no matter which way you decide to swing.
author: Amy P.

description: Can't speak for the food there, but I was craving for chai and happened to stumble onto this restaurant and the guy there gave it to me for free =)! And it tasted good too!
author: Michelle N.

description:
I love Chutney!!!  I love it so much that everytime I'm in the mood for Indian food, I must go there and only there.  I've heard a few other places are just as good, but I can never bring myself to give them a chance.  I think it drives my husband insane, but if we try another place, it means missing out on Chutney's lamb tikka masala, which is my FAVORITE!  I always order it!!!  I'm not a huge lamb fan, but I love this dish.  They also have chicken tikka masala, which I'd think I'd like more (being I'm a fish and chicken person) but it does no justice to the lamb tikka masala, so try it!  Everything on the menu is cheap and every dish I've tried has not disappointed me.  I also love their chicken botti and all their vegeterian dishes.

They also have really yummy mango lassi, which is a perfect compliment to their spicy dishes.  

***an added bonus: my daughter loves the food here too!
author: quel c.

description:
In brief:

Price: On the cheap side ($5.99 for a curry plate, $1.00 for plain naan)
Service:  Good (partially self-service)
Food:  Ok
Atmosphere:  Good
Would I go there again?:  If I had to, but would pick  Naan-N-Curry instead if I was looking for cheap Indian food

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

I met 3 friends for a late lunch here yesterday and the first thing I said was "So this is basically like a clean  Naan-N-Curry."  Ok, I know Naan and Curry is not the epitome of 5-star Indian food, but given Chutney's set-up, prices, and menu it's the best comparison I can think of.

You order your food from the counter (curry plates, naans, etc.), take a plastic number to your table, and grab your own water, glass, plates, utensils, etc.  You then pay at the counter after the meal, which I don't think is the case at  Naan-N-Curry.

I'm not an Indian food connoisseur by far so I can't vouch for the authenticity of the food,  but it wasn't bad.  We had lamb saag, chicken saag and two other chicken dishes for which I can't recall the exact name.  However, the naan (we had both the plain and garlic & cilantro naan) was definitely not as good as  Naan-N-Curry's.  And the naan is what I like the best so my experience is going to be skewed by this.  The naan was not as fluffy and doughy as  Naan-N-Curry's and it was actually kind of dry and flat.

Price-wise, I think Naan-N-Curry may be a bit cheaper for exactly the same thing.  The big plus about Chutney though is that it is cleaner and less smelly by far, especially the restroom.

Overall, if I was craving cheap Indian food, I would hit up the Naan and Curry on Irving given that its closer to where I live and the naan is yummier.  Unless you're already in the neighborhood (and on foot), I don't think Chutney is worth the 20 minute parking safari.
author: Amy C.

description:
I love this place! Try the Chicken tikki mansala, mixed vegetable korma, kabab, and of course the naan. I'm salivating just thinking about this place. Everyone I have taken to dine here has fallen in love.
"Warning" "Warning" once you start chutney you will not stop! "May lead to addiction"
author: Kelli H.

description:
I'm a local to this restaurant. Perfect Food is served at this joint. Anyone have some questions just purchase the following for yourself.
- Rice
- 2 Naan
- 1 Chicken Marsala in a bowl

This Place is so good
author: Robert C.

description:
Really really good chicken tikka masala! (i'm drooling just thinking about it). the price is really affordable, which is perfect for a student like me. i went here with a friend, and in the end our total was only like 10 dollars.
i think i'll be eating here on a weekly basis.
author: Libby K.

description:
When it comes to cheap Indian food we choose Chutney for their quality for the price.

Pros:
Cheap (don't charge tax)
Salad dish with every meal
Service is great for Indian restaurant 
BYOB
Not too greasy as some of the other Indian restaurants we've visited

Cons:
Sometimes a wait for tables
author: L L.

description:
I love chutney b/c it's probably one of the only Indian restaurants that doesn't leave u're clothes smelling like the food after a meal.

U have to order the chicken tikka masala (chicken cooked in a buttery sauce).  The sauce is perfect for dipping your naan.    You get a fresh plate of chopped lettuce/tomatoes/onios w/ your order too!  

The dinner and lunch menu have the same items and price.  I like how there is free chai tea which makes a good end to the meal.

I can't give it 5 stars b/c the guy who takes the order...usually the same guy all the time is kinda stuck up.   It's like he thinks he's the hottest guy on earth.  But I'm there to eat so don't really care.
author: J B.

description: the food tastes good but it never sits well with me.  i've eaten at chutney about a dozen times and the same odd feeling returns, almost like a strong kinetosis, then at 3:00am i need to drink a gallon of water.  each time i vow to never return.  i'm usually fine with vegetarian indian food so go figure.
author: Noel J.

description:
Ok so I'm a BIG fan of hole-in-the-wall places with excellent food. For me, that's what Yelp is all about: Those secret spots with all the good dishes. Chutney is one of those places. 
The Tikka Masala sauce is AWESOME and will have you dipping your Naan bread into it to get every last drop. (I am partial to the Chicken Tikka Masala) Couple it with the Tandoori Prawns and you'll be fighting with whoever you take there for the last morsel. The prices are good, the staff is efficient, and the ambiance is.. well it's not about the ambiance! (Hole in the wall.. remember?) The neighborhood is kinda sketch, but I've never had a problem parking there. It's all worth it for the best Indian food in SF. Eat here. Claim victory over mediocrity!
author: Daniel C.

description:
So I am San Fran for my last week on this project.  None of my friends can make it out and I am on a bit of a budget so being solo wasn't that bad of a thing.
So I search for Cheap food in San Fran and this was one of the top 5 places that pops up and it's within walking distance from the hotel.  It's  decent walk but glad I did it as you will see at the end of the review.
Who'd a thunk it!  Little India/Pakistan on O'farrel street.  Only in San Fran I guess.  As I cross Jones St., I get a whiff of Tandoori that brought me back to Mumbai.  It was awesome and, since I was starving, got me all excited.
As you walk in, you feel like you are 12 hours ahead on the sub-continent.  The menu is simple and to the point.  It's laminated and one-sided.  That's all you need if you know how to order.
I got the Aloo Gobi, some garlic Naan, a Tandoori chicken leg (of course), and little lamb kebab.
The Curry came first with the garlic naan.  Man, that aloo Gobi was awesome!  So fresh and not salty.  Take that with some naan, and I was in heaven.  Well, almost.  I needed some spice so I could build up a nice sweat.  :)  There is a fridge in the back and they have two types of hot sauce.  I don't know the name of the brown one, but it's sweet at first and then spicy. The Green one was a typical chutney for the meats.
The Tandoori and kebab came out next.  The Tandoori is something to write home about.  Cooked to perfection with the most real Tandoori flavor I have had in a while.

Why is it 5 stars?
