Price -- For the volume of food I got, $17 in DT San Fran is peanuts.
Quality -- the salad traditionally given before the meal was fresh as were all the ingredients in all the dishes.
Cleanliness -- very clean
Service -- fast enough and friendly.

NOTE: This is not some fancy joint.  Remember that I searched for cheap food.
simple food prepared perfectly with little to no fare.

Enjoy!!
author: gabriel m.

description:
Well, I've been here twice and it's pretty nice, since the interior is clean and such but the food I haven't been as impressed with both times I've been there.  The chicken isn't as flaky in the various dishes as I've had elsewhere and the spicy flavors seem slightly muted. 

Maybe I like more bold flavors from a dulled palette or something but I just don't get that pop with the food here.

It's not bad by any means, but since there are so many other great options in the city (and even nearby) I'll usually opt for one of them like Shalimar right across the street.
author: Gene X.

description: Definitely try the chicken and lamb boti khabobs.
author: michael j.

description:
I have been on a kick lately, trying to get to know the restaurants in my neighborhood.  So, last night I gave Chutney a try.  It was great!  I had a vegetarian dish- daal (lentils) masala-  and my date had chicken vindaloo.  We shared a mango lassi, pappadum and garlic and cilantro naan, finishing up with rice pudding.  It was all good.  The food was hot and fresh-tasting and it really hit the spot.  

This would be a good place if you are vegetarian and if you are on a budget.  

It seems to be a very busy place, so if you are going on a weekend night, like I did, you might prepare for a line.
author: Elli F.

description: My favorite authentic cheap Indian restaurant in the bay area.  Sometimes the biryani varies a bit, but it's usually on-point especially for the price.  I've loved everything I've eaten here - it's best to go with people and share since this isn't your neighborhood buffet.  Speaking of, the area is slightly hood, but we never had any problems.  If anything, I get the rare privilege of helping blind homeless men across the street who then ask me for burger money when I was the one helping them.  I mean, who should tip whom?  The only down side of this place is that on the rare hot day in SF, be aware that they don't have air conditioning.  I guess also you might smell like curry after leaving, but to me that's kind of a gift to remind me how great my food was that day.
author: Sia K.

description: I literally found the food at this place disgusting and inedible. I have no clue why people go here. My friends agree with this wholeheartedly. Ick.
author: Andrew K.

description: This is the best place to go to for cheap and amazingly good Pakistani/Indian Food. I always get the Aloo Naan, Chicken Tiki Masala, and Mango Lassi when I go there, yummy! I wish their Samosas were better, but I don't go there for their Samosas and you shouldn't either. Try their curries and rice plates. Oh and the Aloo Naan is heaven. Its a way better version of a similar place that shall remain nameless. Love this place, only downside is the location.
author: Theresa D.

description: My favorite restaurant! They open late, and their food is soooo good. I used to go with my friend for dinner in the late hours, and my favorite dish is the Benghan Bharta. I order it every time I go there, it's my favorite dish ever. Prices are very reasonable too.
author: Sam T.

description: By far the best Indian-Pakistani food in the city... the food is always right on point...so fresh... and never greasy or too much oil  like other places. ...this place has a pretty loyal following..there's not a time i go to eat without seeing someone i know...my pregnant friend craved chutney almost everyday.. eatin sometimes twice a day lol...so lets say i have been there a lot the last 7 months...:) again halal...with lots of vegetarian options.. ...
author: Piper a.

description:
In the Tenderloin, Indian food isn't scarce.  I can think of three other places within a block of this one.  And I do go to almost all of them depending on who I am with.  

When I go here, what do I get?  Almost always, chicken tikka masala (sp?).  It is spicy and slightly sweet and oh so good with warm nan.  

The place is pretty clean and feels kind of cozy.  If you have an entertainment book, use your coupon and try it out.
author: Mark C.

description: The food is good, WAY inexpensive. Garlic naan is fab. Great for large groups.  Worth tripping over the random 'loin scenery on the sidewalks. And oh, your hair and clothes will smell like Indian spices the next day. So...eat well, but don't wear porous clothing (like a sweater) b/c that shit will absorb all them spices!!!!
author: Caroline I.

description:
We ended up here when we discovered Mela, the Shalimar off-shoot with better ambiance, had closed.  The service is very quick.  The majority of the food was pretty good and fairly inexpensive.  The chicken tikka masala wasn't the greatest according to the hubby and he would know as this is his favorite dish.  

Not bad... not Mela, but not bad.
author: LeSLiE W.

description: OMG I love this place!! Found it once while walking around in the strange neighborhood. Then re-found it a few years later when we drove up from LA with my woman! I wish I had some right now!!!
author: Joel A.

description: I guess I'm a stereotypical amateur indian foody because a.) my first indian food experience was at Naan n' Curry, and b.) I would usually get the Chicken Tikka Masala.  But since recently becoming a vegetarian I was forced to venture out of my comfort zone of mild creamy deliciousness, and pick one of the dozen veggie curries that Chutney offers.  I settled on Bengan Bharta, an eggplant curry, and it was radness.  It had a perfect spicy hum, and accompanied with a $1.00 piece of naan and the complementary salad (a pretty pathetic salad, but hey I got some ruffage!) I was stuffed.  This place is always a great experience, and the guy that takes your order is super nice.  Plus, there is just a certain lovable charm about the neighborhood that I can't quite put my finger on!
author: George B.

description: This was the first time I had Chutneys, and my brother's recommendations that it was a great spot were, well, spot on. I ordered the Lamb Tikka Masala, and some Nan. The price wasn't bad at all considering what you got. The portion was pretty big, and the sauce was on point, with only a few of the spices left at the bottom of my plate not suited to my taste. The Nan was delicious, and was paired perfectly with the sauce. The ambience is alright, but its not like its a fancy restaurant. Definitely worth your time, but this was just my first try, I'll definitely go again.
author: Christian Y.

description:
It is a bare bones type of restaurant.  Your place your order, sit down, grab your silverware and NON-Alcoholic beverage from the tepid refrigerator in the back of the restaurant and wait to be served.

The Chicken Tikka Masala that I ordered was good, but not great.  The samosas that I ordered was horribly dry.  The naan was ok and the rice was dry.  All in all, I was not impressed with the food.

The price was good.  This restaurant is clean and that is a positive.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
Thank you Chutney.  I had a fantastic hangover that was relieved after pigging out at your restaurant today.  And you brought the medicine to me so quickly.  My curry, naan and rice disappeared before my eyes and I was instantly feeling like a champ again.  But not only today, on many occassions you have delivered tasty curries to my table and minutes flat.  End of note to Chutney

Note to yelpers.  Chutney is good, cheap, and QUICK!  But what I love best is that you can go to the corner store, buy a six pack and bring it into Chutney to enjoy with your kickin curry.  Me gusta.
author: Alexis M.

description:
Not quite a four star review, but not three either.  I'm rounding up since I eat here all the time.  I think you can do better (by quite a bit) in this neighborhood, but it's my curry pal's favorite place and I'll put up with it for that.
For cheap indian, this is one of the places with "nicer" ambiance.  You place or order at the counter, help yourself to chai, sit, and you'll be brought a plate with lettuce, tomato, onion & some water and after a brief wait, you'll get your food.  Prices are higher than naan & curry, but still very reasonable.  

As for the food, it's not bad, especially when the price is considered.  The naan is good, but I prefer it crispier.  The Tikka Masala is very skimpy on the chicken, so you might want to order some chicken on the side.  It's tasty, but not my favorite Tikka Masala.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
Good fast (as in quick) Indian food

Intimidated by the line at Dottie's across the street, we strolled on over to Chutney for a spicy brunch.  The place is huge among restaurants in the 'loin, so it as very easy to find a seat.

I tried the usual palak/saag paneer, and paneer tikka masala to compare.  The flavors were good, but the Paneer tikka Masala was a bit lacking in flavor (Sameer even added salt).  The saag/palak paneer was a over pureed, but still enjoyable.  Served with sides of naan and rice, it made for a nice brunch.

I'm a bit surprised at how high the Yelp rating is for this place.  I'll definitely be back, but I'll try other dishes next time.

Solid three stars!
author: Shea G.

description:
Where I work, we have a team lunch every Friday. Most of my coworkers are Indian, so we hit an Indian restaurant every other week. This week, I convinced them to try out Chutney to take a break from the popular Shalimar or the Naan and Curry also in the Tenderloin. Chutney was recomended by an Indian woman I work with, who mentioned there were more varied vegetarian dishes there. 

The food there was quite tasty. But in comparison to the two other restaurants, I just mentioned, Chutney just wasn't quite as good overall. I have to admit that I am quite influenced by the opinions of the several Indian guys who I ate with who seriously thought it sucked.

I had a couple of my favorite dishes: Bhindi masala and palak paneer. Stay clear from the palak paneer, as it is practically a soup. The okra was nicely spiced, but not exceptional. I tried a bite of the tandoori smoked fish (bad vegetarian) and it was nice, smokey and tender. The naan was on the fluffier side, and worked well to sop up the curries.
author: Ron L.

description:
Firstly, i usually eat here about once a week.  BEST chicken tikka masala i've had ever.  Quality chunks of white meat happily drowned in the most beautiful of sauces.  Whenever I eat here with someone, we are usually tempted to just pick up the plates and literally lick them clean.  I probably have at some point, but I eat here so much i couldn't remember.  Basically,  shit's amazing.  I haven't tried many other dishes because i'm picky, especially when it comes to meat, and besides, chicken tikka masala beckons.  But i did try the palak paneer which was way too spicy for my debilitated digestive track.  I didn't care for the consistency either, which was too pureed for my taste.
service has always been fast, except for one time when I went with a big group on a busy friday nite, which was understandable.  the place is surprisingly clean, especially compared to the street it's on.  If you order smart with other people, you can get away with spending $6 and stuff the hell out of yourself.
Be forewarned:  don't plan on being far from a bathroom after your meal...unless you have intestines of steel.  But believe me, it's worth it.
author: jess l.

description:
I only ate here once, but I was pleasantly surprised by the fare considering the location. (um, sketchy. Funny story - I actually WAS going to go to Naan N Curry down the street, but there were police barricades in front of it).

I had sheekh kabab, garlic naan, and the vindaloo. Sheekh kabab = insanely good. I wasn't expecting anything, it was just $1.99 so I decided to order it because it was cheap and easy. What a treat - the spices were perfect, and it tasted great paired with the onions it came with. Delish. he vindaloo, however; I must say, I've had better. The sauce really wasn't as flavorful as a few places I've had in Massachusetts, of all places, and it wasn't spicy enough for me. My least favorite part of the vindaloo was the fact that the chicken was done more authentically, which means it was chopped up as a chicken instead of using just the meat. Why do I not care about authenticity here? Because of the really insane amount of bones that kept getting stuck in my teeth. 

Reading all the other yelpers on here, I really wish I had tried some of the specials. . .that's for next time. A really nice interior in a not as nice part of town, good food, friendly people inside, and cool menu options.
author: Stephen J.

description:
More like 3.5 stars.  I really enjoyed the chicken tikka, lamb chops, and mango lassie,  but  there were a few glaring minuses.  

Worst of all: the samosas.  They were unacceptably cold in the middle, and even the warm outside wasn't all that flavorful.

Service was also off.  New entrees were hustled onto a crowded  table without removing finished ones.  I don't expect French Laundy style choreography, but this is pretty basic, common sense stuff.  I just ended up stacking them under the plate I was eating off.  It also took way too long to get an extra order of naan.  

With some more consistency, Chutney gets a higher rating.
author: Leon R.

description:
Food is very average .. I cook better chicken biriyani and chicken curry than this place. The curry preperations sucks. All the curries tastes the same to me. Also after you come out of the place you stink like a Indian / Pakistani kitchen.

But the food is cheap and accessible.
author: Amlan S.

description:
This is the place for inexpensive, fast, and excellent Indian food in San Francisco.  Yes, it's in the Tenderloin, the neighborhood is a tad sketchy, but it's worth it.  Try the benghun bharta, the palak aloo mehti, the tandoori chicken salad -- heck, try anything, it's all good.  Chutney puts Naan n' Curry and Shalimar to shame -- once you've tried Chutney, you won't be able to return to those subpar establishments.  And if you manage to run up a bill of more that $20 at Chutney, you'll be eating leftovers for a week.

Chutney has no liqour license, but the convenience store across the street has a plentiful supply of inexpensive beers.
author: Marco C.

description:
In the cut throat world of Indian quick eateries, there's a pretty stiff divide between Naan n Curry and Shalimar people. I like shalimar, but I've always been a fan of Naan n Curry. Say what you will about it being more oily or whatever, but it's comfort food at its best. Shalimar is good too, but some of the stuff there seems a bit bland to me.

My friend told me she only eats Chutney, when it comes to indian food. so we had to try it. and I was very happy with it. it's not as oily as naan n curry, but i thought it was more flavorful than shalimar... and cleaner, too!

So while I still hold a special place in my heart for naan n curry, I will definitely be checking out Chutney next time in the TL.
author: Bernie L.

description:
I can't speak to authenticity, but the food is inexpensive, and delicious. We always order too much.  The menu is pretty complete:  curry, tandoori, etc.  And always hot chai in the thermos/carafe thingy in the back.

Order up front, seat yourself with a number, and they deliver to your table.

I don't know what it is with the Chicken Tika Masala at every place I go.  It's like they keep trying to under-do each other by serving the fewest pieces of meat on a plate of sauce.  Double up on this dish if you do order it.
author: Ken B.

description:
If your in the mood for Indian/Pakistani food and you have to be walking on O'Farrel, your first thought would be "Sweet, theres a Naan and Curry!". As we all know Naan and Curry doesn't disapoint right? How about I say yes, it does disappoint when compared to the likes of Chutney? Its a few more blocks away and it may be a bit more sketchy for some Yelpers out there. May I suggest you bring some pepper spray to ward off the vagrants? 
I got the chicken tikka masala and it is the most tastiest Tikka Masala I have ever had. I was never aware that this was how Tikka Masala was supposed to taste like, I guess Naan and Curry did it wrong the whole time. My only complaint is the Chai,  I will admit that Naan and Curry kicks Chutney's ass in the Chai territory.
author: Harry B.

description:
A bit nicer than the place across the street in terms of ambiance, decor, cleanliness. Food wise, I think Shalimar is better. Location is a bit sketchy, but that doesn't stop us from coming here. Fast service and they bring silverware and all to you. I liked the ground lamb kebab and the chicken korma out of all the ones we ordered. 

Decent prices, fast service, clean, good for groups, and excellent food.
author: Linda C.

description: Found this spot 2 years ago when I was working in the area, recommended from a friend. Favorite spot in SF for good eats, love it here! Every time I come in for a bite, I am always introducing the cuisine to a new friend. Order at the counter- usually Chicken Tikka Masala (sauce and meat is amaaaazing), Biriyani (chicken or prawn), 2-3 Garlic naan (or regular), Sikh kabob, and a new random dish every time (this time it was an eggplant dish and Indian pickles on the side). To wash it all down, LOVE the Mango Lassi (cant believe its only two bucks for a large glass) and Chai tea (free refills). For dinner tonight, it all came out to $32 for a party of 3 (and plenty of leftovers) Parking garage is next door, usually $8 for a few hours.
author: J L.

description:
*** DO NOT EAT HERE!!***

I will NEVER again go to this place. I was completely appalled by the attitude I received from the owner of this establishment. I was yelled at in front of my girlfriend for a mistake made in my order. 
1. He approached me with the wrong tone of voice 
2. Told me that I was at fault for the mistake of the order
3. Explained how the cooks where mad at him( Probably for previous mistakes)  and he is losing money by writing down an incorrect order.
4. He expressed that I needed to pay for His mistake.
5. Cursed at me and said " I don't give a $h!# "  
 The owner came to my table and had the nerve to tell me that everything was my fault for an issue that could have easy been resolved. I took a stand and expressed how his LACK OF CUSTOMER SERVICE is affecting his business and that KNOW ONE especially a customer should be treated like this. I WAS a frequent guest at Chutney... I enjoyed many meals here but this is now my last visit. To Top it all off before leaving in the middle of our meal... I told him I was gonna go out of my way to write a yelp review and he responded in " I DON'T CARE ABOUT MY REVIEWS! " 

If it was possible I would have put 0 star...
Lets see who's laughing now.
author: Javier S.

description: Having enjoyed every other Pakistani house in the city (Shalimars, Pak wans, Naan and Curry, Lahore's , Tikka Masala, etc) I can safely say that Chutney's is the best. They are super cheap, never costing more than $30 for a SHIT-TON of food (at least 4 or more dishes....). It's so good in fact, my stepfather who lives in Reno orders either my mother or myself to send him one of everything at least once a month. DEFINITELY order the Chicken Achar, Aloo Ghobi, Brain Masala, Lamb biriyani, Saag Paneer, Seikh Kebabs, and Aloo Naan. You WONT be disappointed.
author: CHRISTIAN P.

description:
My co-worker is the best and most beautiful person in the world. When I am feeling down, she helps me by making me walk at least ten blocks to one of the most relaxing dining area that I can think about. 
Did I mention I have a car and was wearing heels? 

I really like this place because it is simple and comfort food. The chicken vindaloo was delicious, not too spicy and what I like about it was that it still had the bones in tact. I love bones in the chicken, it just brings out the extra flavor. And of course, there is nothing like fresh naan to soak up the wonderful sauce. 

Self-serve all the way. I got my own big pitcher of water from the fridge and five feet away, got the cups and utensils. The food was served quickly, which I gobbled down pretty quickly.

So thanks to Yuri for finding this gem amongst half a dozen Indian restaurants around it.
author: Thia T.

description: We got "CURRIED" away.  Yes, I went there.  Most of you true curry fanatics know that its all about the heat to flavor profile.  But, its also about the ingredient quality and perfect blend of meat to spice ratio.  Chutney had it all.  Its a little hole in the wall spot that is clean (even the bathroom), staff are friendly, and relatively easy to find.  Our group, all of which were English/ Pakistani, were eager to find some delicious curry at all costs.  And by all costs I mean walking blocks and blocks of the San Francisco downtown.   As tired as I may have been it was so worth it once we came upon the delicious grilled kebobs they were cooking out front.   Once we walked in and exchanged pleasantries with the chef we ordered all of the house specialities, Tikka Masala, Kebobs in both beef and chicken, Dahl (Lentils), Saag Aloo, Vindaloo, and Briyani.  As I mentioned, we were hungry.   Everything was divine.  Flavorful, spicy, rich, and all around yummy.  DO NOT MISS THIS if you are looking for a true curry experience.
author: Maria Y.

description:
I cannot believe that this place has 4 stars, or the crowd this place manages to draw. We came here based on the Yelp reviews and I really regret that decision!
I've eaten Indian food from both fancy places and holes in the walls, in big cities like Manhattan, London, and Bangkok; and in smaller cities like Austin and Indianapolis. This is the worst I've had---by far. The tikka masala tasted like it was made with canned tomato paste and half and half. The paneer was tough and had a bland, strange taste. While the chana masala was decent, it was a little sweet with not enough spice.

The place is cheap, but it's still not worth it.

And, to top it all off, the man taking orders at the front was short with me, trying to hurry me along, and ultimately got my order wrong because he wasn't paying attention. At least the table-service waiter, while too busy to be attentive, was polite in correcting the mistake.
author: Stacy S.

description: Awesome Tikka Masala! This place is a hole in the wall and not in a great neighborhood, but, unless you are a snob you won't mind as soon as you have a bite of their food!
author: Tim C.

description: I've been coming here for years, and obviously there's a reason. The food is great and you can bring your own booze. What more could you ask for?
author: Andrus H.

description: I wake up in the morning salivating for Chutney. Dreams of tikka masala and bengan bharta and naan. mmmm. I'd eat here everyday, breakfast, lunch, and dinner if I could. I like it.
author: cait b.

description: Love the CTM medium with rice and garlic naan and some green and brown sauce. I wish I lived closer so I could eat here everyday. It's like comfort food with a twist I love chutney so so good!
author: Jeni Z.

description:
I used to go to this place before and I think it was decent. Went there recently after many years and I pretty much got served CRAP on a plate. The stuff we ordered was vegetarian, but I think any decent place would take pride in whatever they serve.

Never going back there again!!
author: Vineet G.

description: I just visited this place and am obsessed with the Chicken Rice Biryani! It is so flavorful and delish. The pricing was fairly cheap. I also had the Chicken Tikka Masala which was definitely a treat as well.
author: Imani G.

description: What can I say, I pick up food here at least once a week and gorge myself on the orange gooey deliciousness that is Chutney's paneer tikka masala (I ask them to add green peas and wow what a dish).  Other favorites: Lamb boti, bengun bharta, aloo gobi, chicken tikka masala and garlic naan.  They are quick and very friendly.  I have been eating here since they first opened and have never been disappointed.  Go Chutney!
author: moodyfoodie m.

description:
I always have a ton of fun when I wander into this tenderloin Indian joint.  Order at the register and wait for deliciousness to arrive.  This place isn't big on frills, but the food and the fact that it is B.Y.O.B. with a decent liquor store right across the street make for a very good meal, and a fun group environment.

Their Chicken Tikka Masala is amazing here, with lots of sauce to be soaked up by the naan.  Their naan, btw is very well done and is always made just right; order lots of it and forget the rice.  I'm a huge seafood fan, and not many Indian places have Tandoori Fish as tasty as this one.  

Every time I come here I do so with a group to be able to try most of the things on their menu at one sitting; I recommend bringing your friends with you when you try it!
author: Lemar H.

description: I give them 3 stars because I think that they have delicious tikka masala,but this restaurant has a serious HYGIENE problem. I dont think they ever cleaned the restaurant since they opened. If you go there pay attention to the walls, floor and under the counter (where they cook). It's very dirty.
author: Sinan S.

description:
Cheap and delicious Indian restaurant in the city!!  Highly and highly recommended.

Their Chicken Tikka Masala is the best.  Their Naan is served hot and soft.  Ahh, my mouth is watering just thinking about it.

It is self-service restaurant but the food comes out pretty fast.  

Definitely will go back there whenever I go up to the city.  Ahhh, so nice~!
author: Misty C.

description:
Best Indian Food!

Watch out Naan-N-Curry, I found another spot, "CHUTNEY" for some good Indian eat'n!

Same set up as Naan-N-Curry but not a chain.  Dinning is still pretty much the same: order @ the counter, get a #, find a seat,  your complimentary salad will fallow. Utensils & water are available for self serve but usually accompany ur salad.   Chai Tea is offered (self serve) @ no cost.....   I am not reviewing this place for the atmosphere,decor, or ambiance even though it is a little better then its chain competitor/s.  This review is all about the food!  
I recommend the Tandoori Lamb Chops, U hav to get some Naan, flavored rice, & my Favorite here is the "Marsala "(I usually get Chicken Marsala).  Plain would be okay with me. You could almost drink it, it is so good.  

I know I said it was all about the food but I have to comment about the staff, "Friendly"!  My last dinner here was with some female friends, one who is fluent in Spanish.  Hey a chicka speak'n Spanish means extra Marsala & Naan @ no charge!  So bring the Spanish speak'n ladies whit-cha & U won't go hungry, the bus boys will take care of ya! ( ;   If its ur off night & U can't find any Spanish speak'n ladies to accompany U, no worries, the prices are as good as the food.
author: Nader O.

description:
Chutney is a blend of a little ambience, fast service, cheap food, and great taste. None done to perfection, but when combined....it's perfect. Perfect to the point where my girlfriend has Chutney's number on her cell. 

As an Indian, I'm giving chutney some props. Not overspiced, but still has a little kick. My mom's food still kick's chutney, but hey thats an unfair comparison

The smoky Baigan Bharta and Lamb Boti are my faves. 

Only minus...it does get a little loud in there.
author: Kishore H.

description:
Oooooo....curry.  This gotta be the cleanest Indian restaurant I've been to.  The walls are not oily!!  Another gem in the TL, the curry here is really good and cheap.  Aside from the neighborhoods goodies(ie, hookers/bums on the street, no parking, and smells like urine), I definitely prefer Chutney's over the Naan N Curry that's been popping up everywhere.

I recommend the charbroiled chicken (leg and thigh), chicken masala, their garlic naan and the  vegetable curry.  Their special there is pretty good as well (I think they specialize in Lamb because the past few times I was there...their special was "lamb").  Their curry sauce is thick, tasty and spicy.  If you ever intend to bring a date to grab some curry....definitely come here because it's CLEAN.

- Yummy for my tummmy
author: Dave L.

description:
Yet another of those standard Indian/Pakistani restaurants. It's almost as if all of them used the same interior designer.

But who cares about the interior? HOW'S THE FOOD???

The food is decent at this place. It was served quickly, and serving sizes were good. We forgot to mention that we wanted it "muy picosa", so it was not as spicy as we would have liked.

The garlic naan was good. The chicken tikka was well done and flavorful. They had 'chicken seekh kebab', which is not so common (because chicken meat doesn't bind as well as lamb, so it's harder to work with it ground). A plate of chicken seekh kebab for $2.99 can't be beat...

All in all, while this may not be a first date place, it serves its purpose: it'll fill you up without emptying your wallet.
author: A J.

description:
Definitely way better and cleaner than Naan and Curry! Good news is, prices are pretty low. The restaurant is big and roomy, and the service is friendly. 

Ok, here comes the food. For some reason, they curry and masala seems bolder and taste better, compare to Naan. Granted I don't know much about authentic indian food but I do know that it's full of spices and should taste bold. Naan didn't have the flavor but Chutney certainly delivers. Oh, they also bring you a plate of lettuce, tomatoes, and onions to accompay your dishes. It's like a side salad; pretty refreshing. 

BONUS: They give free hot milk tea. Check it out!
author: My V.

description:
This place is amazing.  I eat here at least once every two weeks.

The food is consistently the best Indian I've ever had.  Every dish I've had on their menu is delicious, filled with flavor; they know how to cook with their spices.  

The atmosphere is what I look for in a restaurant that I want to visit on a regular basis.  It smells wonderful and is always filled with a lively crowd.  The food comes quick and is very reasonably priced.  They also have excellent Chai that is actually free of charge; my only complaint is that it goes quick and it seems l'm always waiting for a fresh brew.

Don't tell me there is another place in San Francisco with better Indian until you've tried Chutney.
author: Ken F.

description:
I just came back from a 10 day trip to India - New Delhi and Mumbai.

I ate fantastic food everywhere I visited...and I still think Chutney has some of the best Indian/Pakistani food on the planet.

It's so good, I brought colleagues to Chutney for a business meal, we brought in a fantastic bottle of wine and drank it out of warm glass tumblers.

Cost of wine: $56.00
Cost of dinner for four: $50.00

The colleagues LOVED it, they were tired of eating at places that stretch the expense account - places just like you'd find anywhere else (who really needs a hamachi appetizer anyway?).

I love Chutney. Jaden loves Chutney.  Chutney is rad.

So the business dinner worked out - after dinner took a strange twist when I took the out of towners to the glass dildo shop...but that's another review altogether
author: Nathan W.

description:
Its been quite awhile since my visiting of this little known Indian joint, 1 year probably to be exact.

I've only ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala and it was quite tasty. The sauce was rich but not overwhelming, the rice was moist but not mushy and the chicken was tender.  Not much to say about the place itself, just a bunch of tables and chairs, the people are kinda rude and the food takes at least 12-15 minutes.

I wouldnt find myself going there often.
author: riz l.

description: Delicious food, great price, friendly service. A fun local SF restaurant to go to for lunch or dinner any day!
author: Mallory F.

description: Reasonable quality.  Quick takeout.  But their "spicy" was totally bland!  I even asked for the *VINDALOO* to be extra spicy!!  And nothing.  It was about as spicy as raisin bran.  Way to care for the details...
author: ben y.

description:
OK at best... 
Food is mediocre, bland and tateless. If it wasn't for the mint chutny and the lemons, it would be dry, and almost unedible. Best thing on the menu by far are the seekh kababs, but nothing I felt that deserves any praise whatsoever.
Prices are very reasonable, but then again, given the quality and taste of food you get, I don't think this is a plus point.
Service is good however. The cashier and all bus boys were very nice and welcoming. So that was a definite plus.
Interior is beat up, crowded and loud. Not at all the place if you are looking for good ambiance... althought the hustle and bustle of a kabab place can be appealing at times.

Bottom line: Average food, good prices... bring your own masala!
author: Aman A.

description: This is hands down THE best Indian/Pakistani restaurant you'll find in the area. The portions are generous and the prices are very reasonable. The place is clean, the food is delicious, and the servers are friendly. Overall a pleasant environment. This is a nice change from other places where servers check on you every few minutes, which can get obnoxious. During one visit, we'd parked in a no-parking zone and our car was towed. The owner was so nice, driving us to get our car and offering to comp our meal. If you visit Chutney, try the Chicken Tikka Masala, Naan, the Seekh Kabab, and the Mango Lassi.
author: Ariana A.

description: I really love this place. I go there at least ones a week. Food is super tasty and I think prices are really cheap. If you never been there I strongly recommend you visit this place. Good Luck! :)
author: Erkindjon P.

description:
I've probably eaten at this restaurant more than any other in the city, and that's saying allot! I have a special craving for Lamb Boti, and Aloo Naan. The Chicken Tiki Masala is delicious also. Most of all, the Chutney sauce is to die for! no wonder they named the place after the sauce!

bring a 6 pack from the bodega across the street,  Indian places are always BYOB.
author: Jevir G.

description:
This is by far my most favorite Indian restaurant in the city. Yes, it's in the dirty Tenderloin. Yes, you should wash your hands before eating. And yes, the line can often get out of control. But the food is so worth it. 

First off, let's talk about the prices. Each dish is around $7, with samosas/apps even cheaper than that. The portions are heathly -- I always share a rice and naan with whoever I am eating with. 

Although they don't use organic food (like some snobs have knocked them for), it's Indian. Who cares? The whole point is the experience of the restaurant, and enjoying another culture's foods. 

I've taken several people here and none have been disappointed. I look forward to going back soon.
author: William d.

description:
This is my new favorite place... The food is TAST-Y, service is quick and you can even bring in your own alcohol without having to pay corkage fee.
Get the Chicken Boti with the tiki marsala sauce.... YUM YUM.
author: J J.

description:
So I haven't been here is about two years, but I loved it when I went! I am in San Francisco two or three times a year usually, and every time I have come I always try to make it a point to come back to this restaurant, but it never works out! 
What I remember is that it was super cheap, and being from Albuquerque, cheap Indian food is unheard of! Especially cheap Indian food that is so delicious! I ate here for three meals in a row on that trip to the city, I just couldn't get enough! Best naan I have ever had....
I am going to be in San Francisco next week.... nothing is going to stop me from eating more than I should at this place...
author: Andrew J.

description:
This is a great place to get your India dishes without the frills. A straight to the point type of eatery. You go to the register, pick up a menu, order and pay. Find an open table, seat yourself, get comfy and wait for your food to be deliver. The sauces here are amazing. Best part, it is so affordable and so close to all of the great shopping locations like H&M, Zara and of course all of the luxury boutique. Perfect for a quickie lunch but still nice and hardy to the soul.

Happy eating
author: Steven L.

description:
This was our first stop when we arrived to The City.
We actually found it by accident while we were meandering the oh so safe tenderloin district.
How we pick good restaurants (and hasn't failed us yet) is to look inside for some key elements. 
1. Are there people eating in the restruant
2. If this is an ethnic restaurant- are those people eating in that res truant
3. Do the staff look too anxious for foot traffic

When we walked into Chutneys, it passed our criteria. 
The food was amazing and came fast.
I had a cold that week and the spices in the food clear my sinuses right up.
author: E C.

description:
I always like a place where I can see the food being cooked.  Right behind the counter you can watch your order going into the tandoori. The aromas coming from the tandoori are very enticing.  My favorites here are the spinach with potatoes and fenugreek and of course fresh hot naan bread.  
Not a "Fine Dining" establishment.  If you are looking for that go elsewhere.  But if you want tasty, spicy, cheap Indian food this is a good spot for it.  Every time I've been here there have been a lot of Indian men eating here.  That is always a good sign to me.
author: Rosemary B.

description:
I've finally come back for a second visit and it was just as good as the first. Though since then, I have eaten at other Tender-nob Indian/Pakistani places, but Chutney is one the less shady looking joints in the area.

The Chicken Tikka Masala, Palak Aloo Metir, Lamb Kebab, rice, and naan were all delicious. I took my friend here who isn't all that familiar with food from the region and she LOVED it. Prices were good (20 bucks for the both of us). However, I wasn't offered crack or a fake rolex outside this time. Not sure how I feel about that.

They also had this huge platter of fried 'stuff', since I didn't know what it was, and a platter of fruit. People were helping themselves to it, but I had no idea what it was for. Ramadan?

Chutney is good, but then again so is Shalimar. I'll have to compare it with Lahore Karahi to really determine whats the best in the area.
author: Rocky K.

description:
A couple of friends introduced me to this place and now I crave it. It's got the casual Indian vibe, of ordering from the counter and finding a table, which is popular in SF, and the food is really good.

Most dishes are spiced for great, strong flavors, and a little bit of kick. We've loved the saag and vindaloo; but based on advice, we now always get a grilled chicken leg which has become one of the reasons we crave this place.
author: Saren S.

description: Very good food. While the ambience and location is not the greatest, the food is great. Especially the daal. Their desserts, lassi and naans are pretty awesome too. Large portions too!
author: Abhishek S.

description:
I defenitely love this restaurant.
They have lots of delicious food, and the prices are great.
My favourite is actually the naan bread. It is fresh, and tastes great with the red dipping sauce.

The negative about it is that it is located in Tenderloin. I, as a girl, would never have dared to go there alone in the evening.
author: Malin A.

description:
I am not so impressed with this place, and I consider my self fairly experienced in eating Indian/Pakistani food.  We ordered Tandoori Fish (it said Chef recommended on the menu) and it was dry and fishy tasting.  I wasn't overly impressed with the other items we ordered -- okra and vegetable biryani.

That said, everyone in the restaurant seemed to be eating chicken (which I don't eat), so perhaps I ordered the bum items on the menu and this is the place to eat chicken (and nothing else).  Diners did seem happy eating their chicken!
author: Jessica P.

description: Chicken tikka masala was all cream. Asked for super spicy & it was the least spicy I ever tasted. Tandoori chicken was charred & not very flavorful.  Salad was a piece of yellowing iceberg lettuce. Chai was good though.
author: Priscilla L.

description: This is my favorite Indian place period.  The onion naan bread is delicious and not greasy at all.  My go to dishes are the aloo gobi and the chicken tikka marsala.  The dude that owns the place is always there taking orders, he is very friendly and always rockin his SF Giants hat!!!  This is not a fancy place but for tasty and inexpensive Indian it cannot be beat...
author: Austin P.

description:
I have been eating at Chutney for five years and have always used this place as a basis of comparison for every indian/pakistan restaurant I've tried in the Bay. So far, Chutney beats them. I've tried 70% of the menu already and found all the plates to be less oily and more flavorful than the rest of the indo/pak places like Naan N Curry.

I bring all my friends here and found the more people you bring the more your taste buds and wallet will thank you--you can share more dishes, be full as fuck, and still contribute less than $10 toward the bill. My faves include the chicken tikka masala (best I've had so far), bengan bharta, and mango lassi (the best I've had) to subside the fire in your mouth.
author: Nancy B.

description: Sure, Chutney is, and has been since I moved to SF in 2003, my go-to for cheap Indian food.  It's in the crusty heart of the loin, and despite improvements over the years, it's ain't fancy inside.  Service is pretty basic - order in front, take a number, food is delivered, pay when you're done.  And yet, the consistent excellence of the flavors themselves have not been topped by any other Indian/South Asian restaurants I've tried in SF, regardless of whether the eatery was up- or downscale.  Sure, I've seen more creative menus elsewhere, but if you want to get some really delicious, spicy curry every time, Chutney will serve it to you.  I've brought tons of visiting friends/family and they always dug it (especially if they'd been in SF for a few days and were tiring of how damned expensive everything is here).  The veggie wrap is fantastic.  Come early, before they run out of samosas - they're sooooo good.
author: Keegan R.

description:
another indian place down on our list.

i was really excited to try this place. we had garlic naan, chicken tikka, lamb curry, and an appetizer. the lamb curry was alright, the meat was kinda fatty. garic naan was excellent. chicken tikka masala was so-so. all the flavor was in the sauce and the chicken was just bland.

not sure i'll be back...
author: laura f.

description: Ordered my food to go and I was told it will be ready 15-20 minutes. After repeatedly asking for it, I was told the food is coming up any minute, and finally got it after 35 minutes of wait. I believe, it's too long of a wait. Allow ample time to get your food or order ahead of time. Food is not bad but the place needs some organization at the counter. For people eating in the restaurant, salad and water is served quickly which is a good gesture, but to get the food, it may take a while, especially on a Friday night.
author: Bakht K.

description:
Yum, yum and yum. I went to this place with a group of friends for some pre-party alcohol absorbing food. Everything we ordered was excellent, masala, vindaloo, naan, roti, kebabs. We polished off all the plates except for the plates of salad that came with the meal. 

This place is quick and extremely good for being so damn cheap AND they let you BYOB (booze).
author: melissa g.

description:
I used to go to here for lunch at work quite often and I MISS IT!!!  For LESS than the price of just Chicken Tikka Masala in the Peninsula, I could get Rice, Nan, AND Chicken Tikka Masala.  And the most amazing part is that it is consistently delicious.  Some other places, like Naan N Curry, have their good days and bad days.  
The only downside to this place is that you get the random crackhead wandering in and wanting to start fights with the staff.  Besides that, it's perfect. :-)
author: Hey La P.

description:
If you want good Indian food at a reasonable price for its quality, Chutney fits the bill.  My Indian friend said that they put too much cream in their dishes, so it's a bit heavier than traditional Indian fare.  However, he said the flavors are fine.

In any case, I live in the Marina and I still make the trek to eat at Chutney.
author: Kelvin K.

description:
Better ( and cleaner) than most of the Pakistani restaurants in the city. I liked the biryani and main courses compared to Naan n curry and the others. 
The service is pretty quick and this place doesnt feel like another pakistani restaurant in tenderloin.
author: Rahul P.

description:
The absolute best tikka masala anywhere.  
They actually make your food spicy when you say you want it spicy.
It's cheap as hell.
Everything I've ever eaten here is delicious, good enough to eat everyday!
author: J P.

description:
The first time I came here was about 3 years ago for a friend's mom's birthday, and to say the very least, I was TERRIFIED! I was your typical sheltered Westmoor kid who thought that exotic food meant a big bowl of noodles from the Pho place a block away from school.

The super orange-y chicken tikka masala came to the table, I was scared. The yellow, brown-ish chicken korma curry came, along with this potato spinach dish, two plates LOADED with naan and several glasses of mango lassi.

To cut an incredibly long story short...Chutney = best Indian/Pakistani food in the City. My personal faves when I go there are of course the chicken tikka masala, mango lassi and garlic naan. Their lamb biryani is pretty awesome too, and shame on all of you that say it's "too spicy!" Wuss!! And don't forget to grab a free up of their chai before you leave!!

Only downsides are the neighborhood -yeah it's the TL get over it!- and parking. But the crackheads don't have any effect on how delicious their food is.
author: Daneca V.

description:
The best PAKI/INDIAN food I've ever had is at Chutneys. Great service, great portions, great prices. I've never had a bad experience here when it comes to ordering food .

The Chicken Tika Massla is off the hook and the best I've tasted ever.
author: Nael M.

description:
Chutney is not located at the best areas, but the food is worth it! 

Good Stuff:
* Chicken Tikka Masala 
* Onion Naan
* Lamb Vindaloo
* Chicken Biryani
* Tandoori Chicken
* Rice Pullao
author: Eva L.

description:
Definite fan of this place...One of the few places where you get naan that actually tastes like naan should taste, freshly made (Not microwaved).

Tikka Masala is the signature dish here, IMHO.

No frills Indian joint but your 'bang for the buck' is terrific
author: Barca F.

description: What can I say. This is the best Indian food I ever had. Don 't forget to try the tea (free), it is so good. Chicken taandori is my favorite. On the other side the service is not so good but that's probably why it's cheap lol.
author: Thierry W.

description:
First i got here, i was not impressed with the ambiance and refused to eat anything! mistake!!! then, slowly started one dish at a time...ohh boy, is the food good!!! it is the BEST indian around! Their chicken tikka masala and chicken biryani are sooo good and prices are perfect!!

Dont judge a book by its cover and try it, if you like indian food, this is the best secret in town!
author: C A.

description:
Cheap and great South Asian food.   It is like Shalimar where you order up front and get your own water from the fridge.  Free chai for the taking.  Pretty hard to damage your wallet stuffing your face even if you are very very hungry.  

We had some really good biryani and chicken tikka masala (yeah yea... no creativity on our part) here.  Will come back again.
author: sb T.

description:
This is decent, quick, and reasonably priced Indian food. I am a vegetarian, so I don't have to worry about the "chunks" of bone that others have complained about. But my girlfriend got the chicken tikka masala, and she thoroughly enjoyed it. I had the Palak Paneer. They were a little stingy on  the cheese cubes, but it was delicious. The sauce was kinda creamy, and not greasy (which has been my experience at neighboring Shalimar).

We went here before seeing a play at A.C.T. and it hit the spot. The two of us had full meals (plus a mango lassi) for about $20. You can't beat that!
author: sam h.

description: Food is good! Price is reasonable! I got 7 Naan, chicken masala, 2 kebab, spinach lamb, two rice, one biryani rice, one chicken leg, one chicken wrap, two chicken breast and LAST OF THE MOST RECOMMENDED...LAMB VINDALOO. I got all that fo just $58 BUCKS!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Islam N.

description:
Great food, although picking what you want is tough
Good service
Dirty bathroom
author: John L.

description: I think it's pretty difficult to find good fast Indian food and in the city there is soooo much to choose from.  My friend told me about this place and I was very pleased by the recommendation.  I ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala and the Paneer Tikka Masala.  Why did I order both Tikka Masala?  I don't know!! haha it was the safest.  Alongside I also had some basmati rice and garlic naan.  The food was sooooooo good! Another time, I had aloo globi which was also very good.  I don't think I can give this place a bad review...it's just waaaay too good!  Not to mention, the prices were very reasonable!  It's definitely worth a shot to come here, I hope you will like it just as much as I did!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description: Set our sights on Grill House for Mediterranean food with Chutney Restaurant on my list as a back up. Good thing for two reasons. 1) Grill House is closed, like in closed down with another Pakistani restaurant fixin' to take its place. 2) Chutney easily filled the bill for good food and good eats. We ordered the chicken tikka masala, chicken korma curry, and the ol' my goodness good tandoori fish. The flavors and the moistness of the first two were very good. A wonderful blending of spices. Now the fish was other worldly. Like I'd have thought I needed a passport to taste food like this. The outer skin was crispy black but the fish inside was meaty, moist, and flavorful. Glad we choose this "Chef Recommended" dish. The garlic naan was average. Seemed like a long time between ordering and receiving our food. But then again, think of all the time we saved by not having to leave far from home to eat food like this.
author: Valerie F.

description: Great food, fast service, tons of free chai, and salad that comes right to the table to compliment the tasty dishes.  We had the tikka masala, garlic naan, broiled trout, some veggie side dishes, with chickpeas and potatoes, all of it was excellent!
author: Erin W.

description: Everything is perfect at Chutney! Authentic, delicious and plentiful food at untouchable prices! Free salad, water pitchers and milk tea for dining in, and quick seat yourself service. Hard not to be a regular here. Try the lamb kebab or lamb chutney with your choice of naan-killer combo.
author: Josh M.

description: Let me keep this short and simple... I tried this place 2 months ago and i go back at least once a week now. When I first tried it, I went back every single day for 5 days...Prices are extremley reasonable service is great!
author: T A.

description:
Doods, if you've ever had authentic paki/indian food..you'll realize this is a watered down version of it, for less adventurous palates. 

The chicken tikka sauce was flavorless tomato sauce. Seriously. 
The biryani was spicy but not blended effortlessly into the rice.
Stay away from the Paneer Tikka Masala. The cheese sucked. 

The STAR of the visit was the garlic naan... GET THE GARLIC NAAN. THE BEST THING HERE! IT IS REALLY REALLY GOOD.

The complimentary tea is pretty good too. 

Also, try to pay the guy as soon as you order as you might have to wait another 25 min to pay if you don't. Second tip, if they won't let you pay immediately (don't ask... it happened to me), don't wait in line to pay.. there's a second line next to the guy taking the order... which only regulars know about. 

Lastly, wish i could tip the guys bringing out the food and cleaning up after the clientele as they do an excellent job of keeping the place running. 5 STARs for them.
author: carmen l.

description: My boyfriend and I were in town for the New Year and after a few nights at pricey restaurants, we decided to take it easy and try Chutney based on other reviews. Not only were the prices great but the food was incredible. The neighborhood is definitely colorful but worth the trip- just keep an eye out.
author: Gemma P.

description: Used to be good. Ingredients don't seem very fresh and the food tastes a bit processed. Kind of too greasy as well.
author: Bayarea K.

description: The tikka masala is 5 stars and nothing else actually matters, although the facts that the naan is good, the prices are great, the service is pleasant, and they will actually make it extra spicy if you ask don't hurt.  Know what you're getting though, this is a neighborhood quick-food, in-and-out, more speed and no doilies kind of place.  You're not going to impress that date here, unless they aren't pretentious and like Indian food.  In THAT case go here for sure.
author: Michael G.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city!!! excellent food taste. I love their chicken tikka masala, chicken biryani and tandoori roti.
author: Its M.

description:
I have to say that Chutney is a wonderful spot in the tenderloin area. I've always been a fan of ethnic foods such as Indian/Pakistani, Thai, Chinese, Japanese and etc. 

I had my first experience at Chutney on Monday with some friends. I've read the reviews and been wanting to try it and I was glad that got the chance. 

We ordered Lamb Tikka Masala, Chicken Korma, Chana Curry, Garlic Naan and Rice. 

The Lamb was tender and the sauce had the right amount of heat, mild. The korma was creamy to die for. I've never been of Chana but they changed my mind. It was delicious. 

The only thing I had a slight problem with was the naan. I've have some wonderful naan and this doesn't hold a candle to it. If you want some great naan visit Ashoka in the marina. 

This reasonably price jewel was worth every penny and minute. If the price doesn't sell you it's the atmosphere of the whole place. There are wonderful paintings and a mural adorning the wall of this charming place. 

I am definitely coming back! Thanks Maahum.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Chutney's never let me down.

Yay Paneer Tikka Masala !!!!!!
author: Sevn M.

description:
When I get Indian food I expect to have some heavily sauced dish where after I'm done eating the main entree I can wipe the plate clean with my warm naan bread.  Chutney unfortunately was a bit too 'clean' if that makes sense.  The okra dish I ordered was okay but there wasn't too much of it and it left behind zero sauce on the plate after I finished it.

The rice and the naan were fine.  Free tea is always welcome and their's is quite good.  This place is more Pakistani than Indian as the owner explained to me.  He said they market it more as an Indian restaurant because that's what people are more familiar with.  I wish they'd market it how it really is so I can expect the right food.

One thing I do expect is I won't go to this place again soon just because there are lots of other options within 1 block of here, including Lahore Karahi, one of my faves.
author: Emile B.

description:
My first formal introduction to Indian food -- and I'm so glad for it!

I have learned phrases like: "Palak Panir" and "Tika Masala" [please forgive any mis-spelling on my part].  I am starting to drool just thinking about the fabulous taste!  And their mango juice drink is off the chart!

If you've never had Indian food, then make Chutney's your first!
author: M.Scott C.

description:
the counter-style ordering threw me off because it's a nice big open restaurant with a lot of seating that you'd think would have waiter service. the guy behind the counter was stone-faced the entire time we ordered and looked at us kind of like we were bothering him, so i can understand why people wrote the service here is terrible. but he spoke to us later in our meal and was actually really nice, as is the other guy who runs the place. i think he just happens to have one of those faces where if he's not smiling he looks stand-offish.

they bring a plate of salad to every table and a pitcher of water. there's sodas and coffee in the back of the dining room that are self-serve. it's kind of an honor system thing that you inform the cashier you had a drink other than water.

we had the palak paneer ($8), which i thought was bland and wasn't too fond of the pureed consistency, but that's my fault because i mistakenly thought i ordered saag paneer. we also had the aloo gabi ($6) which was delicious. it's more dry than i've had in other places and it's got a real nice charred edge to it, i would definitely order it again. their eggplant curry was ok ($6), it had a very cheesy taste to me which was odd because there was no cheese in it. the chicken briyani ($7) is really flavorful and spicy, and the veggie samosas (2 pieces for $3) are ok. large, but the outside of the samosa is so heavy and dense. we also got basmati rice and naan ($1 for 1 large piece). the naan is divine. my goodness. i've had a lot of naan at other places, but this one was light and fluffy and thick and chewy in all the right places. i'm disgustingly full, but i am still craving Chutney's naan. 

the prices are pretty good and again, i had no problem with the service. i'll definitely be back.
author: Melissa N.

description:
the last time i had indian was a couple months ago in new zealand, and i was not entirely impressed on their dishes.  over there their concept of spicy does not even tease your tongue, so i was excited to have some indian fare where they know what i mean when i want my dish hot.  we shared shrimp tikka masala, the okra dish, and he had goat curry (i'm not too mad on goat myself).  our dishes had great flavors, and they were spicy enough to make you break a sweat.  the garlic naan and potato naan were cooked perfectly, and soaked up the sauces.

it's very clean and well lighted.  they also serve you your cutlery, dishes, glasses and water, unlike other indian restaurants.  

although the food gave us a massive gut bomb and food coma, but that's due to ourselves stuffing our face, we'll definitely be back for more!
author: Sheri N.

description: By far some of the best saffron rice, Tikka Masala & Naan bread in town! For the price, it can't be beat. And despite the fact that it sits in the ghetto of the tenderloin, the interior is very accommodating of large or small groups. They always provide free water (in pitchers) alongside fresh cuts of ice-berg lettuce, onions & tomatoes. Their food has become my gold standard!
author: Carlos H.

description:
Good options for veggies. Bengan ka bharta was awesome!

Parathas are good and imo they need to work on their paneer paratha, 'twas well just paneer with no flavor compared to different things I had before.

Complimentary tea is not as good as found elsewhere - lacking the "masala"
author: Bhushan S.

description:
Chutney 
Looking for a place to have dinner with my father, we were walking on Jones Street, saw the restaurant and decided to try it.
We were accommodated by the owner who's from Pakistan and who advices you on what kind of food you should eat depending on if you want chicken, vegetable, or beef etc...
I had the Tikka Massala Chicken which was really delicious with a plate of rice and a garlic Naan. The portions weren't not huge but big enough and looked and smelled very good! The Pakistani and Indian food is really nice at this place.
The food is cheap and when you are waiting for your main course to come they give you a salad plate with lettuce, tomatos, carrots and cucumbers...
The atmosphere is nice and clean but I'll bet it could  sometimes be a bit crowded because there are a lot of tables in the room.
The service is really welcoming, and makes sure that everything goes right during your diner.
I really recommend this place to have a cheap and tasty lunch or dinner!
author: ILSC S.

description: I discovered this restaurant in 2003.  Always love their chicken masala, chicken curry and chicken biriyani.  I normally goes when they are slow, I remembered that I had to wait for a table for more than 40 minutes years ago.  Nowadays, the food is not as good as before.  That's why I go to the one across the street instead (the green store-front).  If you are on the go, their chicken wrap is great.  Tea is free.  I haven't ordered mango lassi for long time from them, so no going to commend.  Yes, the cashier's people are not the most friendly or focused folks out there, that's why i normally go after rush hour, so food should be fresh.  Rush hour, they made naans all the times and let them pipe up, either cold or burn.   I only ordered chicken biriyani from them now for grandmom since it's her favorite.
author: W l.

description: my favorite indian place in sf. If i decide to eat indian food... i only eat here. i have tried many places and this is by far the best... ive been eating here for 6 years and you should always get the chicken tika masala... the tandoori fish is amazin and the lamb chops..mmmm
author: janat s.

description: This place is sooo goood! Love their chicken tika masala and pretty much the entrie menu. The price is very affordable for the one of the best Indian restaurants I have eaten in the entire Bay Area... I'd say this one is a notch above Spicy Bite in the Bernal Heights district.Even though parking if rough inthe area, there's a garage next door that you can park at for 6 dollars VS. a $35-$50 ticket for an expired meter in San Francisco.
author: Erick V.

description: LOVE LOVE LOOOVE THIS PLACE.   After you have Chutney's, it's hard to compete with the other places.  It's really affordable, good porportions, and the food is really great.  Every winterbreak/springbreak/ summer, my friends and I try to meet here.
author: Lily W.

description: Great food. Love their Paneer Tikka Masala. Usually very busy.
author: N P.

description: Amazing food for a great price. In my opinion the most authentic Indian food in the area. Smells great as soon as you walk in. Good and fast service too.
author: Kay D.

description: This isn't a sit down and order type of restaurant, it's a stand in line and place your order, BYOB, look for a table and grab your own utensils type of restaurant.  Located in a bit of a sketchy neighborhood it's quite lively at night and a bit on the loud side.  Good environment for friends.  The best dish was one that the guy at the counter recommended - chicken gulta - not the the menu but definitely should be  =)
author: M W.

description:
Hands down, the chicken tikka masala is excellent here-- the sauce is rich and creamy and the chicken very tender. The basmati rice and garlic naan were solid. Spicy beef naan only so so.

Ambiance is decent and the place relatively clean. Location a bit sketchy but that won't deter me from coming one bit. Been here several times and the place has been consistent.

Definitely a great place for Indian food.
author: Bundy C.

description: A nice little no-fuss place in the downtown area. It's good for the price. I think you have to know the good dishes. We ordered three dishes, one was excellent, one was decent, and the third one was not good at all. You probably are better off ordering meat dishes as it seemed like a Pakistani place (they area known for their meat dishes).
author: J N.

description: Chicken Tikka Masal and Naan. Expected bill is under $10. There's nothing unique or special about this place. It's just like a naan n curry, but that's not a bad thing. I'd definitely come here again, but just not on my own accord. If a friend wants to come, I'm okay with it.
author: Tushar K.

description:
Chutney is the best indian curry I've ever had! They've been my favorite for years, and everytime I try other curry places, none of places can beat Chutney.  I always go back to Chutney because they are the best!

I normally get Aloo Gobi with rice and Mango Lassi.  Their Aloo Gobi is the best! Also their spinach curry and chicken tiki masala (I only eat the soup part with fresh naan, and my bf eats the rest) is good!  

I love Chutney!  It's located in kinda scary area, but who cares!  I don't mind to go through the scary part of town to get awesome curry!
author: moshi m.

description:
Looking for cheap "Indian" food...this is the place. Anyone who cannot cook lentils indian style does not know anything about Indian cooking. And at chutney the very basic of lentils dish was watered down, hardly authentic and tasteless. The Naan is tasteless. Food scores 2.

Ambiance ...just a wee bit better than Naan N Curry on O'Farrell, scores a 2

Service Scores negative 10 - the cashier taking orders seems to be the Naan N Curry cashiers brother....same unfriendly attitude....dont care a rats ass

Value for money - Good!! if you dont know what indian food is!!

Wouldnt go  there if i were you.
author: Sankar B.

description: Instead of settling for Naan n' Curry all the time I sometimes wander to Chutney to get my fix. Of all the times I've came to Chutney each experience has been great. The curry here is good and is consistent unlike Naan n' Curry where sometimes it tastes one way and the next time another. Nuh uh, Not here at Chutney! Their chicken tikka masala is prob most popular, but it is sooooo delicious. They have a huge menu of different curry, but I'm not adventurous enough to pick something new, but if I had to this would be the place I would do it.
author: Jackie M.

description: i love all quick and delicious (and reasonably priced) indian joints in the TL. this place was one of those.
author: Ameer N.

description: Nice food. If you want to less spicy and decent Indo Pak food. Chutney is good place
author: Aman K.

description: Best Indian food ever! Well, my favorite anyway. I used to live in SF, and I come here whenever I am in town. The chicken tikka masala is the greatest. Wait time for your food is hit or miss, but I have never had a big problem. If I am going to dine in somewhere I am never in a hurry anyway. Besides, you can sip on free chai while you wait.
author: Jessica H.

description: The Mixed Vegetable Tikka Masala is YUM!
author: Jason D.

description:
Chutney's is my faithful Indian joint, the place I hit most often when I'm feeling the fix.  It's definitely no-frills dining, you order at the counter, take a number back to your table, get your own water and chutney, and sit down.  They bring you your food, you eat, you go up to the register and pay.  It's affordable, with most of the dishes between 6 and 8 bucks.

But the food is what really counts, and Chutney brings the flavor.  The naan is excellent, both the garlic and cheese naan are as good as any in the city.  Their vegetarian dishes are great, and the lamb is delicious.  The only downer I've hit on the menu was the chicken curry, which just wasn't up to the quality of the rest of their food.  Also, if you order samosas, they're coming with the meal and not as an appetizer, which is a bit of a downer, because by then I'm too busy shoveling naan, rice and mutter paneer (or whatever my dish of the day is) to give the samosas their proper attention.

It's the definition of a 4-star restaurant.  Excellent food with a few flaws that keep them off the top shelf.
author: Harrison A.

description:
BEST Indian food in SF. Period.

*I highly suggest the lamb tikka masala, as opposed to the traditional chicken version.
author: Not U.

description:
back in the day, when presented with the choice of either shalimar or chutney, i would always go for chutney because i could always count on eating there without smelling like the food when i got home. but on my last visit there, alas, i could not escape the wrath of delicious indian aromas on my clothes. farewell to the good ole days, i guess!

all jokes aside, i do prefer chutney over shalimar any day because of the huge menu selection and big dining area; even on busier days you can always find a seat.

chicken tikka masala is a sure bet here; every other table seems to have it. on my most recent trip i tried the chicken korma which was pretty good. i also had the lamb biryani which was also good. and always remember to wash it all down with a tall glass of mango lassi!
author: Andrey C.

description: One of the best places for Indian food and at an incredibly reasonable price.  There is always a line no matter when you go.  The staff is very very friendly and food is delicious (since I am from India i know what is delicious in Indian food).
author: Lalit K.

description: Ate here late last night with hubby.  First of all, I love Indian food and get cravings for it regularly. So it was last night, roaming the streets of San Francisco looking for a place to grab a bite. We consulted Yelp of course and saw this place was rated 4 stars.  Sorry to say, I disagree with you Yelpers!  This is clearly an average place not deserving more than 3 stars!  The best thing about this restaurant was that every dish was about $6.99 - cheap!  The taste of the food was not bad but the chicken in my tikki masala was tough and I expect soft, melt in your mouth chicken for 4 stars.  My hubby's dish was lamb and lentils and it was just a bit too spicy for my taste but again not bad. My mango lassi was nice. Can't speak for the naan - I love it but can't eat it.  It did appear yummy though.  The system of standing in line twice once to order and again to pay was unusual.  I wonder how that works when there is a rush.  Overall, not a terrible place but I just had to review to say "not a 4 star people!"  Next time I will try a new place but don't rule out coming back here for some cheap eats.
author: Lisa F.

description: This is my favorite Indian-Pakistani restaurant in the City.  I have been here many times.  Last Saturday's dinner here was so good.  The chicken tikka malasa was so creamy, the aloo gobi had the right amount of spiciness, the naan was fluffy and crispy and mango lassi was the best I had in a long time.  It was crowded, but we were seated fairly quickly and the food came out fast.
author: Benny A.

description:
This is the best Indian/Pakistani place in SF.

The best parts we found in this place are
1) Great food.
2) Cleanliness.
3) Good service.
4) Cheap.
5) Close to all shopping places.

Bad parts?????
I can't think about !!!!!
Have u seen any ????
author: Hasan A.

description:
What an awesome find! I had the audacity to ask a taxi driver where to find good Indian food. After enthusiastically urging us to have dinner at his home with his family, he reluctantly suggested Chutney. 

Let me just say it was simply awesome. Decided to share multiple dishes with a friend... it was so cheap we ordered practically half the menu. Tandoori chicken, lamb sausage, curry shrimp (Bombay style), lamb curry, mango chutney, and of course fried rice and too many pieces of naan. Wow.

So the verdict is great food, friendly staff, and decent decor for an ethnic restaurant. Although if you're a germophobe (and don't like semi-dirty glasses that make you feel like you're drinking straight from the Ganges) or feel uncomfortable trekking around Tenderloin (there was a large bullet hole in the window by our table) I'd suggest you skip it. But hey, be daring! This is food worthy of a last meal any day.

Oddly enough, when we went back to the hotel to rave about the place to the concierge, he seemed truly aghast that us n00bs had ventured into Tenderloin without the benefit of firearm protection... but I never felt at risk. 

Personally, I'd eat there again and again. Delicious!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Chutney is great, and unlike other indian restaurants in the tenderloin you only need to bring a single layer plastic bag to keep your jacket and anything else in there that you don't want to smell like curry when you leave. Chutney has great portions and they are roomier than other places in the area

I'm not like the others. I don't always get Chicken Masala. I pass on the heavy cream and get Ahlo Gobi (cauliflower veg. dish) and add either grilled chicken or a beef skewer. Service is great compromise between not having to ask for anything and getting what you want if you do
author: Dylan M.

description: This is one of the best Pakistani/ Indian restaurants in San Francisco, as far as the taste of the food goes. Service isn't bad either, but it's packed with loads of people all the time. I recommend this place to everyone, especially if you like spicy food!!! Enjoy!
author: Moe L.

description: Although this is in a shady part of town, it's a definite must go if you want good Indian food, and it is sooo cheap.  Check it out, and let me know what you think.
author: David M.

description: With a restaurant like this and Shalimar across the street, you don't need to look far to find good, cheap indian food. It runs about 10$ a person for a meal and all of the food that we ordered was delicious. My only main complaint is how the skimped on the prawns in the prawn marsala. It was almost entirely sauce with 4 little prawns hiding in the sauce. That said, the sauce was delicious and I would order it again.
author: Michael P.

description:
It's simply the optimum Indian/Pakistani food place for varibales which include price, taste, speed, convenience and cleanliness. They have the most unique and best tasting Tikka Massala. Their Tandoori selections are pretty good in terms of variety, taste and price. Atmosphere is extremely casual. Don't expect a nice, calmy, elegant place. I used to live in the neighborhood n used to eat there at least 2-3 times a week. I still go but less often lately. 

If you have stomach problems, do not eat there because it will give you pain. Food is unhealthy by nature, and some of them are really spicy. Best taste, best price, but almost worst for your healh. Once a month is enough.
author: Jim H.

description:
We decided to try this place since the line at Shalimar (across the street) was too long. The food was a bit disappointing though. 
Lamb, Chicken, Beef sheesh-kabab - all really yummy
Tandoori fish - was not expecting bones & skin! Flavor was ok. 
Chicken Tikka Masala - the blandest I have tasted. Just felt like tomatoes and cream. I brought it up with the staff & he was willing to send another plate, decided to try something else. 
Aloo-methi-palak (Potaties and spinach) - quite good. 
Would rather go to Shalimar (532 Jones) or Pakwan (3180 16th St)
author: Nilofer M.

description: Good food, fair price, awful location.
author: Narg R.

description: Worth the trip if you're looking for good, inexpensive fare.
author: Mike S.

description: I had heard good things so i went there for lunch and ordered the chicken korma curry and the lamb tikka masala. The lamb was ok..but the chicken korma sauce was runny and not tasty. It also still had chicken bones. The garlic naan was good but the paneer nan was not as crispy or tasty. So stick to what people recommend which is the masala and the garlic naan.
author: Jex A.

description:
I'm sitting at work right now and I'm extremely hungry. I work at the cross of Post and Jones and I need something that'll be made quick, I can pick up quick, is inexpensive, and will have a ton of food. If you are like me, Chutney's is the only place to go for Indian. 15 to 20 dollars buys me Naan, Rice, Tikka Masala, 2 orders of Samosas, and a Mango Lassi. You can't beat that. Well, according to my friend Johnny from Birmingham, England, you can beat that price... You'll just have to fly to merry old England.
For their best dishes, go with lamb and beef over their chicken and paneer. The chicken always seems to be to dry/ overcooked when I get it and the cheese they put in their paneer dishes has a huge lack of flavor. Always get their Samosas. They're beyond good.
What you'll notice when looking for Indian in the TL is that there are a lot of places to choose from. On the corner of Jones and Ofarrell alone you have 4 places to choose from. Trust me, Chutney's is the best, and the cleanest. Well My food is ready and I have to go grab it. Yum Yum time.
author: Zane C.

description: This place is alright.  no nevermind, its pretty good.  im not gonna lie.  But you havent tasted how this food was supposed to be prepared until you taste the food across the street at shalimar.  It is Chutneys enemy restuarant except Chgutney is that bad guy who will eventually loose in the end.  You will know what i am talking about, just go to Shalimar.  Dont be scared!!!!!
author: Chris C.

description:
OMG! 

NEVER IN MY LIFE HAVE I TRIED CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA LIKE THE ONE SERVED AT CHUTNEY'S!

its MIND BLOWING  and leaves your stomach crying for more!

Last time I went there was a couple months ago, but I swear my mouth is watering thinking about it again.

maybe its time for me to go back again. . . .
author: Yelp F.

description:
I love this place, I live just around the corner and can barely keep myself out. when the first opened I was in there 2 -3 times a week. I had to force myself not to go. I have a few favorite dishes.
1. Chicken  Tikka Massala
2. Chicken or lamb Saag
3. Lamb Birianni 
4. Bindhi Massala 
add in a Na an
and a good buddy and you have a great little meal.
author: Stan P.

description: Hole in the wall kind of place, but I have to say the food was really tasty. I was a little disappointed they didn't have Malai Kofta as a regular on the menu, but I had the Palak Paneer and I wasn't disappointed. Service was fast even on a busy saturday night.
author: Ajay P.

description:
My review should be read most I'm Indian and I know what I am eating lol.  Indian food should t only taste good but the spices must be in Harmony.  The Kebobs and nano are very good here.  If you vet anything else you get the masala from India thick and that's all you can taste.  Stick to the Kebob and naans and you are good

Also you must not mind over crowded

Oh
author: shakeel T.

description: I've experienced a restaurant unforgivable. During dinner with a friend, seated next to the kitchen, we heard the unmistakable sound of someone spitting. This was not quiet, it was loud and very clear. Next to the food prep area, there were 2 men cooking, We know what we heard, shocked that someone would do that in the open food area, visible to the restaurant. If it was on the floor or in someones meal it didn't matter, we were done. That is not a sound I'm comfortable hearing from a food service worker. Horrified, we paid and left immediately. Sorry to say that I won't be back.
author: Alex T.

description: This place has really authentic, delicious, cheap food. I had the Chicken Tikka Masala and naan. I have no complainants.
